Preface
The aim of this Handbook is to acquaint the reader with the current status of the theory
of evolutionary partial differential equations, and with some of its applications. This is
not an easy task: Unlike other mathematical theories which exhibit a tree-like structure,
with clearly distinguishable trunk, main and secondary branches, the theory of partial dif-
ferential equations has the appearance of a bush with very complex structure. Its roots as
well as its Ô¨Çowers are often related to the physical world, and it is fertilized by ideas and
techniques borrowed from virtually every other area of mathematics.
Evolutionary partial differential equations made their Ô¨Årst appearance in the 18th cen-
tury, in the endeavor to understand the motion of Ô¨Çuids and other continuous media. It is
remarkable that this research program is still ongoing and many fundamental questions
remain unanswered. Beyond this area, however, evolutionary partial differential equations
have become ubiquitous, as they seem to govern the dynamics of any physical, chemical
biological, ecological or economic system whose state is described by spatially depen-
dent variables.
The active research effort over the span of two centuries, combined with the wide vari-
ety of physical phenomena that had to be explained, has resulted in an enormous body of
literature. Any attempt to produce a comprehensive survey would be futile. The aim here is
to collect review articles, written by leading experts, which will highlight the present and
expected future directions of development of the Ô¨Åeld. The emphasis will be on nonlinear
equations, which pose the most challenging problems today. The various articles will offer
the reader the opportunity to compare and contrast the behavior of hyperbolic and parabolic
equations. Hyperbolic equations are typically associated with media exhibiting ‚Äúelastic‚Äù
response, and encompass the notoriously difÔ¨Åcult class of ‚Äúhyperbolic conservation laws‚Äù.
Parabolic equations are associated with various diffusive mechanisms. An extremely im-
portant and challenging example is the Navier‚ÄìStokes equation.
Volume I of this Handbook will focus on the abstract theory of evolutionary equations,
addressing questions of existence, uniqueness and other general qualitative properties of
solutions. Future volumes will consider more concrete problems relating to speciÔ¨Åc appli-
cations. Our hope is that the handbook will provide a panorama of this amazingly complex
and rapidly developing branch of mathematics.
Constantin Dafermos
Eduard Feireisl
v

Abstract
This is a survey on recent developments of the theory of one-parameter semigroups and
evolution equations with special emphasis on functional calculus and kernel estimates. Also
other topics as asymptotic behavior for large time and holomorphic semigroups are discussed.
As main application we consider elliptic operators with various boundary conditions.

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
3
Introduction
The theory of one-parameter semigroups provides a framework and tools to solve evolu-
tionary problems. It is impossible to give an account of this rich and most active Ô¨Åeld.
In this chapter we rather try to present a survey on a particular subject, namely functional
calculus, maximal regularity and kernel estimates which, in our eyes, has seen a most
spectacular development, and which, so far, is not presented in book form. We comment
on these three subjects:
1. Functional calculus (Section 4).
If A is a self-adjoint operator, one can deÔ¨Åne f (A)
for all bounded complex-valued measurable functions deÔ¨Åned on the spectrum of A. It was
McIntosh who initiated and developed a theory of functional calculus for a less restricted
large class of operators, namely sectorial operators; i.e., operators whose spectrum is in-
cluded in a sector and whose resolvent satisÔ¨Åes a certain estimate. Negative generators
of bounded holomorphic semigroups are sectorial operators and are our main subject of
investigation. And indeed, for these operators f (A) can be deÔ¨Åned for a large class of
holomorphic functions deÔ¨Åned on a sector containing the spectrum. Taking f (z) = e‚àítz
leads to the semigroup e‚àítA, the function f (z) = zŒ± to the fractional power of such an
operator A. One important reason to study functional calculus is the Dore‚ÄìVenni theorem.
In its hypotheses functional calculus plays a role; the conclusion is the invertibility of the
sum of two operators A and B. Thus, the Dore‚ÄìVenni theorem asserts that the equation
Ax + Bx = y
has a unique solution x ‚ààD(A)‚à©D(B). To say that the solution is at the same time in both
domains can be rephrased by saying that the solution has ‚Äúmaximal regularity‚Äù, a crucial
property in many circumstances.
2. Form methods (Section 5).
On Hilbert space the functional calculus behaves particu-
larly well as we show in Sections 4 and 5. Most interesting is the close connection with
form methods. Basically, the following is true: an operator is associated with a form if
and only if it has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus. Form methods, based on the fundamental Lax‚Äì
Milgram lemma, allow a most efÔ¨Åcient treatment of elliptic and parabolic problems as we
show later.
3. Maximal regularity and Fourier transform (Section 6).
The following particular prob-
lem of maximal regularity is important for solving nonlinear equations: The genera-
tor A of a semigroup T is said to have property (MR) if T ‚àóf ‚ààW 1,2((0,1);X) for
all f ‚ààL2((0,1);X). On Hilbert spaces every generator of a holomorphic semigroup
has (MR); but a striking result of Kalton‚ÄìLancien asserts that this fact characterizes
Hilbert spaces (among a large class of Banach spaces). On the other hand, in recent
years it has been understood which role ‚Äúunconditional properties‚Äù play for operator-
valued Fourier transform and Cauchy problems. So one may characterize property (MR)
by R-boundedness, a property deÔ¨Åning ‚Äúunconditional boundedness‚Äù of sets of operators.

4
W. Arendt
4. Kernel estimates (Section 7).
Gaussian estimates for the kernels of parabolic equations
have been investigated for many years. It is most interesting in its own right that the solu-
tions of a parabolic equation with measurable coefÔ¨Åcients are very close to the Gaussian
semigroup. But Gaussian estimates have also striking consequences for the underlying
semigroup. For example, we show that they do imply boundedness of the H ‚àû-calculus.
5. Elliptic operators (Section 8).
The theory presented here can be applied to elliptic op-
erators with measurable coefÔ¨Åcients to which Section 8 is devoted. We will explain Kato‚Äôs
square root problem, the most difÔ¨Åcult question of coincidence of form domain and the
domain of the square root, which has been solved recently by Auscher, Hofmann, Lacey,
McIntosh and Tchamitchian.
We start the chapter by putting together some basic properties of semigroups which
are particularly useful in the sequel. Special attention is given to holomorphic semigroups
(Section 2) and to the theory of asymptotic behavior (Section 3). As prototype example
in this account serve the Laplacian with Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions:
On spaces of continuous functions this operator will be considered in Section 2, later its
Lp-properties are established. Concerning the results on asymptotic behavior we concen-
trate on those which can be applied to parabolic equations in Section 8.
Most of the results are presented without proof, referring to the literature. Frequently,
only particular cases which are easy to formulate are presented; and in a few cases we give
proofs. Some of them are new, not very well known or particularly elegant. The article
presents a special choice, guided by personal taste, even in this narrow subject. We hope
that the numerous references allow reader to go beyond that choice and that the list of
monographs at the end helps them to view the subject in a broader context.
1. Semigroups
In this introductory section we present semigroups from three different points of view.
We mention few properties but refer to the various text books concerning the theory.
1.1. The algebraic approach
Let X be a complex Banach space, let C(R+,X) be the space of all continuous functions
deÔ¨Åned on R+ := [0,‚àû) with values in X. A C0-semigroup is a mapping T :R+ ‚ÜíL(X)
such that
(a) T (¬∑)x ‚ààC(R+,X) for all x ‚ààX;
(b) T (0) = I;
(c) T (s + t) = T (s)T (t), s,t ‚ààR+.
Given a C0-semigroup T on X, one deÔ¨Ånes the generator A of T as an unbounded operator
on X by
Ax = lim
t‚Üì0
T (t)x ‚àíx
t

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
5
with domain D(A) := {x ‚ààX: limt‚Üì0 T (t)x‚àíx
t
exists}. Then D(A) is dense in X and A is
closed and linear. In other words, A is the derivative of T in 0 (in the strong sense) and for
this reason one also calls A the inÔ¨Ånitesimal generator of T .
The second approach involves the Cauchy problem.
1.2. The Cauchy problem
Let A be a closed linear operator on X. Let J ‚äÇR be an interval. A mild solution of the
differential equation

u(t) ‚àíu(s). A classical solution is a function u ‚ààC1(J,X) such that u(t) ‚ààD(A) and
Àôu(t) = Au(t) for all t ‚ààJ. Since A is closed, a mild solution u is a classical solution if and
only if u ‚ààC1(J,X).
THEOREM [[ABHN01], 3.1.12]. Let J = [0,‚àû). The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) A generates a C0-semigroup T ;
(ii) for all x ‚ààX, there exists a unique mild solution u of (1.1) satisfying u(0) = x.
In that case u(t) = T (t)x, t ‚©æ0.
The theorem implies in particular that the generator A determines uniquely the semi-
group. Here is the third approach.
1.3. Semigroups and Laplace transforms

for all x ‚ààX. Then T is a C0-semigroup and A its generator.
Thus generators of C0-semigroups are precisely those operators whose resolvent is a
Laplace transform. Laplace transform techniques play an important role in semigroup the-
ory (see [[ABHN01]] for a systematic theory).
1.4. More general C0-semigroups
In order to talk about Dirichlet boundary conditions we need more general semigroups (cf.
Section 2.5). A strongly continuous function T :(0,‚àû) ‚ÜíL(X) is called a (nondegenerate
locally bounded) semigroup if
(a) T (t)T (s) = T (t + s), t,s > 0;
(b) sup0<t‚©Ω1 ‚à•T (t)‚à•< ‚àû;
(c) T (t)x = 0 for all t > 0 implies x = 0.
As a consequence œâ(T ) < ‚àûand there exists a unique operator A such that (œâ(T ),‚àû) ‚äÇ
œÅ(A) and R(Œª,A)x =  ‚àû
0 e‚àíŒªtT (t)x dt for all x ‚ààX and Œª > œâ(T ). We call A the gener-
ator of T (see [[ABHN01], 3.2]). Then T is a C0-semigroup if and only if D(A) = X. If
X is reÔ¨Çexive, then this is automatically true.

2. Holomorphic semigroups
A semigroup T :(0,‚àû) ‚ÜíX (in the sense of Section 1.4) is called holomorphic if there
exists Œ∏ ‚àà(0,œÄ/2] such that T has a holomorphic extension T :Œ£Œ∏ ‚ÜíL(X) which is
bounded on {z ‚ààŒ£Œ∏: |z| ‚©Ω1}. In that case, this holomorphic extension is unique and
satisÔ¨Åes T (z1 + z2) = T (z1)T (z2) for all z1,z2 ‚ààŒ£Œ∏. If T is a C0-semigroup, then
lim
z‚Üí0
z‚ààŒ£Œ∏
T (z)x = x
for all x ‚ààX, and we call T a holomorphic C0-semigroup. If the extension T is bounded
on Œ£Œ∏, we call T a bounded holomorphic semigroup. Thus, for this property, it does not
sufÔ¨Åce that T is bounded on [0,‚àû). Take for example, T (t) = eit on X = C.
2.1. Characterization of bounded holomorphic semigroups
Let A be an operator on X. The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) A generates a bounded holomorphic semigroup T ;
(ii) one has Œª ‚ààœÅ(A) whenever ReŒª > 0 and supReŒª>0 ‚à•ŒªR(Œª,A)‚à•< ‚àû;
(iii) there exists Œ± ‚àà(0,œÄ/2) such that e¬±iŒ±A generates a bounded semigroup.
In that case (T (e¬±iŒ±t))t‚©æ0 is the semigroup generated by e¬±iŒ±A. Moreover, T is a
C0-semigroup if and only if D(A) is dense. This is automatic whenever X is reÔ¨Çexive.
2.2. Characterization of holomorphic semigroups
An operator A generates a holomorphic semigroup T if and only if there exists œâ such that
A ‚àíœâ generates a bounded holomorphic semigroup S. In that case T (t) = eœâtS(t), t ‚©æ0.
2.3. Boundary groups
Let A be the generator of a C0-semigroup T having a holomorphic extension to the
half-plane C+ = {Œª ‚ààC: ReŒª > 0}. Then iA generates a C0-group U if and only if
supRez>0,|z|‚©Ω1 ‚à•T (z)‚à•< ‚àû.
In that case we call U the boundary group of T and write U(s) =: T (is), s ‚ààR.

2.6. The Neumann Laplacian on C( 

holomorphic, positive C0-semigroup (etN
Œ©)t‚©æ0 on L2(Œ©). We refer to Section 5.3.3 for

THEOREM [FT95]. Let Œ© be bounded with Lipschitz-boundary. Then C( 
Œ©) is in-

Œ©)t‚©æ0 and the restriction is a bounded holomorphic

Œ©).
The main point in the proof is to show invariance of C( 
Œ©) by the semigroup or the
resolvent. Holomorphy can be shown with the help of Gaussian estimates (Section 7.4.3).
We also mention that the semigroup T induced on C( 
Œ©) is compact, i.e., each T (t) is
compact for t > 0. This follows from ultracontractivity (Sections 7.3.3 and 7.3.7).

THEOREM. The operator A generates a positive, compact and holomorphic C0-semigroup
on C( 

Favini, Goldstein, Goldstein and Romanelli [FGGR02] were the Ô¨Årst to prove that A is
a generator with the help of dissipativity. An approach by form methods was then given
in [AMPR03]. Warma [War03b] proved analyticity in the case where Œ© is an interval.
It was Engel [Eng04] who succeeded to prove that the semigroup is holomorphic in the
general case.
The boundary conditions incorporated into the domain of A express in fact dynamic
boundary conditions for the evolution equation. To see this, denote by T the semigroup
generated by A. Let f ‚ààC( 

3. Asymptotics
Most important and interesting is the study of the asymptotic behavior of a semigroup T (t)
for t ‚Üí‚àû. The philosophy is, as for other questions, that one knows better the generator
and its resolvent than the semigroup. Thus the challenge is to deduce the asymptotic behav-
ior from spectral properties of the generator. Here we will describe some principal results
with emphasis on those which can be applied to parabolic equations in Section 8. We re-
fer to [[ABHN01]] and [[Nee96]] for a systematic theory of the asymptotic behavior of
semigroups and to [[EN00]] for other kinds of examples.
3.1. Exponential stability
Let T be a C0-semigroup with generator A. By
s(A) = supReŒª: Œª ‚ààœÉ(A)
we denote the spectral bound of A. We say that T is exponentially stable if œâ(T ) < 0; i.e.,
if there exist Œµ > 0, M ‚©æ0 such that
T (t)
 ‚©ΩMe‚àíŒµt,
t ‚©æ0.
It is easy to see that T is exponentially stable if and only if
lim
t‚Üí‚àû
T (t)
 = 0.

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
13
FUNDAMENTAL QUESTION. Does s(A) < 0 imply that T is exponentially stable? In gen-
eral this is not true. The realization of the Cauchy problem
 ‚àÇu
‚àÇt (t,s) = s ‚àÇu
‚àÇs (t,s),
t > 0,s > 1,
u(0,s) = u0(s),
s > 1,
in the Sobolev space W 1,2(1,‚àû) leads to a C0-semigroup T whose generator A has spec-
tral bound s(A) < ‚àí1
2 but T is unbounded [[ABHN01], p. 350]. An example of a hyper-
bolic equation is given by Renardy [Ren94].
However, additional hypotheses are known, which lead to a positive answer. Here we
consider three important cases corresponding to a regularity assumption, semigroups on
Hilbert space and a positivity assumption.
3.1.1. Eventually norm continuous semigroups.
A C0-semigroup T is called eventu-
ally norm-continuous if limt‚Üì0 ‚à•T (t0 + t) ‚àíT (t0)‚à•= 0 for some t0 > 0, and T is called
norm-continuous if this holds for all t0 > 0. Of course, each holomorphic semigroup has
this property.
THEOREM. Let A be the generator of an eventually norm-continuous semigroup T .
If s(A) < 0, then T is exponentially stable.
For further extensions we refer to [[ABHN01], Chapter 5], [Bla01], [BBN01].
We mention some perturbation results: If A generates an eventually norm continu-
ous C0-semigroup T on X and B ‚ààL(X) is compact, then A + B also generates an
eventually norm-continuous C0-semigroup. The compactness assumption cannot be omit-
ted, in general. It can be omitted if T is norm-continuous on (0,‚àû). Eventually norm-
continuous semigroups appear in models for cell growth. We refer to [[Nag86], A-II.1.30
and C-IV.2.15].
3.1.2. The Gearhart‚ÄìPr√ºss theorem.
Let H be a Hilbert space. Assume that s(A) < 0
and supReŒª>0 ‚à•R(Œª,A)‚à•< ‚àû. Then T is exponentially stable.
There are several proofs of this result which all depend on the fact that the vector-valued
Fourier transform is an isomorphism for Hilbert spaces. Pr√ºss‚Äô proof [Pr√º84] uses Fourier-
series. The above result is not true on Lp-spaces for 1 ‚©Ωp ‚©Ω‚àû, p Ã∏= 2; see [ArBu02],
Example 3.7.
3.1.3. Positive semigroups on Lp-spaces.
In the next result we consider a C0-semigroup
T on Lp(Œ©,Œ£,Œº), where (Œ©,Œ£,Œº) is a measure space and 1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû. The semigroup
is called positive if T (t)f ‚©æ0 for each 0 ‚©Ωf ‚ààLp(Œ©,Œ£,Œº). Of course, here f ‚©æ0
means that f (x) ‚©æ0 Œº-a.e. For positive semigroups, there is an easy criterion for negative
spectral bound: One has
s(A) < 0 if and only if A is invertible and A‚àí1 ‚©Ω0.

14
W. Arendt
THEOREM (Weis [Wei95]). Let A be the generator of a positive C0-semigroup T
on Lp(Œ©), 1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû. If s(A) < 0, then T is exponentially stable.
For a proof and further references we refer to [[ABHN01], 5.3.6] and [[Nee96]]. A sim-
ilar result is true on C0(Œ©), where Œ© is a locally compact space [[ABHN01], 5.3.8], but
false on a space Lp ‚à©Lq [[ABHN01], 5.1.11].
3.2. Ergodic semigroups
Let T be a bounded C0-semigroup on a Banach space X. Denote by A the generator of T
and by A‚àóthe adjoint of A. We say that T is ergodic if
Px = lim
t‚Üí‚àû
1
t
 t
0
T (s)x ds
exists for all x ‚ààX.
ERGODIC THEOREM. The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) T is ergodic;
(ii) X = kerA ‚äïR(A);
(iii) kerA separates kerA‚àó.
In that case P is the projection onto kerA along R(A).
Here we denote by R(A) = {Ax: x ‚ààD(A)} the range of A. One has always
kerA ‚à©R(A) = {0}. To say that kerA separates kerA‚àómeans that for all x‚àó‚ààkerA‚àó,
x‚àóÃ∏= 0, there exists x ‚ààkerA such that ‚ü®x‚àó,x‚ü©Ã∏= 0. Note that kerA‚àóalways separates
kerA (by the Hahn‚ÄìBanach theorem). Thus on reÔ¨Çexive spaces, ergodicity is automatic.
THEOREM. Every bounded C0-semigroup on a reÔ¨Çexive space is ergodic.
It is interesting to know whether reÔ¨Çexivity is the best possible hypothesis on the Ba-
nach space in order to guarantee automatic ergodicity. And indeed it is, under some ad-
ditional hypothesis. In fact, on a general Banach space no method is known to construct
nontrivial C0-semigroups. For this reason one has to suppose some geometric property.
We will assume that X has a Schauder basis. See Section 4.5.2 for the precise deÔ¨Åni-
tion and also for a method to construct diagonal semigroups under this hypothesis. The
following theorem is a semigroup version of a result on power bounded operators by Fonf‚Äì
Lin‚ÄìWojtaszcyk [FLW01] which was recently given by Mugnolo [Mug02].
THEOREM. Let X be a Banach space with a Schauder basis. Assume that each bounded
C0-semigroup on X is ergodic. Then X is reÔ¨Çexive.
We conclude by an example. Denote by Gp the Gaussian semigroup, on Lp(Rn),
1 ‚©Ωp ‚©Ω‚àû, and by p its generator (see Section 2.4). Then G1 is not ergodic since

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
15
ker1 = 0 and ker‚àû= R ¬∑ 1. The semigroup Gp is ergodic for 1 < p < ‚àû. But one
can even show that limt‚Üí‚àûGp(t) = 0 strongly in Lp(Rn), 1 < p < ‚àû. Strong conver-
gence, and not merely convergence in mean, is the subject of the next section and the result
for the Gaussian semigroup follows from Section 3.3.2.
3.3. Convergence and asymptotically almost periodicity
In the preceding section we described when a semigroup converges in mean. Now we in-
vestigate a stronger property, namely strong convergence (see Theorem 2 of Section 3.3.2).
More generally, we consider semigroups which can be decomposed into a semigroup con-
verging strongly to zero and an almost periodic group.
Let T be a bounded C0-semigroup on X with generator A. We say that T is asymptoti-
cally almost periodic if X = X0 ‚äïXap, where
X0 :=

x ‚ààX: lim
t‚Üì0 T (t)x = 0

Xap := spanx ‚ààX: ‚àÉŒ∑ ‚ààR,T (t)x = eiŒ∑tx.
Note that X0 and Xap are invariant under the semigroup. Moreover, there exists a bounded
C0-semigroup U on Xap such that T (t)|Xap = U(t), t ‚©æ0. Let œÉp(A) := {Œª ‚ààC: ‚àÉx ‚àà
D(A),x Ã∏= 0,Ax = Œªx} be the point spectrum of A. If œÉp(A)‚à©iR ‚äÇ{0}, then Xap = kerA.
In that case T is asymptotically almost periodic if and only if Px := limt‚Üí‚àûT (t)x con-
verges for all x ‚ààX (and not just only in mean as considered in the previous section).
3.3.1. Compact resolvent.
Let A be an operator with nonempty resolvent set œÅ(A).
We say that A has compact resolvent if R(Œª,A) is compact for all (equivalently one)
Œª ‚ààœÅ(A). This is equivalent to saying that the injection D(A) ‚ÜíX is compact where
D(A) carries the graph norm. It implies that œÉ(A) = œÉp(A) is a sequence converging to ‚àû
(unless dimX < ‚àû).
THEOREM [[ABHN01], p. 361]. Let T be a bounded C0-semigroup whose generator has
compact resolvent. Then T is asymptotically almost periodic.
This result can be generalized to the case where œÉ(A) ‚à©iR is countable with more
involved proofs, though.
3.3.2. Countable spectrum.
Let T be a bounded C0-semigroup with generator A.
THEOREM 1. Assume that X is reÔ¨Çexive and œÉ(A) ‚à©iR is countable. Then T is asymptot-
ically almost periodic.
If X is not reÔ¨Çexive, one needs an ergodicity hypothesis.
THEOREM 2. Assume that
(a) œÉ(A) ‚à©iR is countable;

16
W. Arendt
(b) œÉp(A‚àó) ‚à©iR ‚äÇ{0};
(c) T is ergodic.
Then Px = limt‚Üí‚àûT (t)x converges for all x ‚ààX.
REFERENCES: [[ABHN01], Chapter 5], [Vu97]. So far, there does not exist a (spectral)
characterization of strong convergence. But we refer to Chill and Tomilov [CT03,CT04]
for very interesting (not purely spectral) conditions.
3.4. Positive semigroups
The asymptotic behavior of positive semigroups is most interesting and has applications
to many areas, for example population dynamics and transport theory (see [[EN00]],
[[Mok97]], [[Nag86]]). Here we think more of applications to parabolic equations and
establish a result on convergence to a rank-1-projection which will be applied to a second-
order parabolic equation (see Section 3.5.1 and (8.5)). We also present some other results
which are obtained by putting together the results on countable spectrum of Section 3.3
and Perron‚ÄìFrobenius theory for positive semigroups. Throughout this section we assume
that X is a space of the following two kinds:
(a) X = Lp(Œ©), 1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû, where (Œ©,Œ£,Œº) is a œÉ-Ô¨Ånite measure space, or
(b) X = C0(K), where K is locally compact.
Here we let C0(K) := {f :K ‚ÜíC continuous: for each Œµ > 0 there exists a compact
set KŒµ ‚äÇK such that |f (x)| ‚©ΩŒµ for x ‚ààK \ KŒµ}. Of course, if K is compact, then
C0(K) = C(K).
By X+ we denote the cone of all functions f in X which are positive almost everywhere
if X = Lp and everywhere if X = C0(K). Let T be a positive C0-semigroup on X; i.e.,
T satisÔ¨Åes T (t)X+ ‚äÇX+ for all t > 0. Denote by A the generator of T . At Ô¨Årst we recall
that
s(A) = œâ(T )
(3.1)
and s(A) ‚ààœÉ(A) if œÉ(A) Ã∏= ‚àÖ, two important special properties of positive C0-semigroups
on X (see Section 1.3 for the deÔ¨Ånition of œâ(T ), and [[ABHN01], Theorems 5.3.6
and 5.3.1] for the proofs).
THEOREM. Let T be a bounded, ergodic, eventually norm-continuous, positive C0-
semigroup on X. Then
Pf = lim

exists for all f ‚ààX.
As a consequence P is a positive projection, the projection onto kerA along R(A).
Recall that each holomorphic semigroup is eventually norm-continuous and ergodicity is
automatic if X = Lp, 1 < p < ‚àû.

It is a remarkable result of Perron‚ÄìFrobenius theory that œÉ(A) ‚à©iR ‚äÇ{0} whenever
T is positive, bounded and eventually norm-continuous, [[Nag86], C-III.2.10, p. 202 and
A-II.1.20, p. 38]. Thus the theorem follows from Theorem 2 in Section 3.3.
3.5. Positive irreducible semigroup
We assume again that X = Lp(Œ©), 1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû, or X = C0(K) as in Section 3.4. An
element f ‚ààLp(Œ©) is called strictly positive if f (x) > 0 a.e. An element f ‚ààC0(K) is
called strictly positive if f (x) > 0 for all x ‚ààK. Finally, a functional œï ‚ààC0(K)‚àóis called
strictly positive if
‚ü®œï,f ‚ü©> 0
for all f ‚ààC0(K)+ \ {0}.
Let u ‚ààX and œï ‚ààX‚àóbe strictly positive such that ‚ü®œï,u‚ü©= 1. Then Pf = ‚ü®œï,f ‚ü©u deÔ¨Ånes
a projection on X. We call P a strictly positive rank-1-projection.
DEFINITION [[Nag86], p. 306]. A positive C0-semigroup is irreducible if for some
(equivalently all) Œª > s(A) the function R(Œª,A)f is strictly positive for all f ‚ààX+ \ {0}.
Irreducibility has many remarkable consequences (see [[Nag86], p. 306]). For exam-
ple, if X = C0(K), it implies that œÉ(A) Ã∏= ‚àÖ. This also remains true on X = Lp(Œ©),
1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû, if in addition we assume that T (t0) is compact for some t0 > 0. However,
this case is more difÔ¨Åcult and depends on a deep result of de Pagter [[Nag86], C-III-3.7].
3.5.1. Convergence to a rank-1-projection.
In the following theorem we assume that
T (t0) is compact for some t0 > 0. This implies that T (t) is compact for all t > t0 and that
T is norm-continuous on [t0,‚àû). For example, if T is holomorphic and A has compact
resolvent, then T (t) is compact for all t > 0.
THEOREM. Let T be a positive, irreducible C0-semigroup on X. Assume that T (t0) is
compact for some t0 > 0. Then s(A) > ‚àí‚àûand there exists a strictly positive rank-1-
projection P such that
e‚àís(A)tT (t) ‚àíP
 ‚©ΩMe‚àíŒµt,
t ‚©æ0,
for some M ‚©æ0, Œµ > 0.
Thus the rescaled semigroup converges exponentially to a rank-1-projection. Such
rescaled convergence is sometimes called balanced exponential growth and plays an im-
portant role for models describing cell growth (see [Web87]). Here the theorem will be
applied to parabolic equations (see Section 8.5).
PROOF OF THEOREM. Since œÉ(A) Ã∏= ‚àÖwe can assume that s(A) > ‚àí‚àû. Since T (t0) is
compact, T is quasicompact [[Nag86], B-IV.2.8, p. 214]. Now the result follows from
[[Nag86], C-IV.2.1, p. 343, and C-III.3.5(d), p. 310].

3.5.2. Convergence to a periodic group.
The following result is a combination of Perron‚Äì
Frobenius theory for positive semigroups and the results on countable spectrum of Sec-
tion 3.3. Let T be a bounded C0-semigroup with generator A. Assume that A has compact
resolvent. Then we know from Section 3.3 that X = X0 ‚äïXap, where X0 and Xap are
invariant under T . Moreover, there exists a C0-group U on Xap such that U(t) = T (t)|Xap
for t ‚©æ0.
THEOREM. In addition to the assumptions made above, if T is positive and irreducible,
then U is periodic.
PROOF. If s(A) < 0, then Xap = {0}. If œÉ(A) ‚à©iR = {0}, then Xap = kerA; i.e., U(t) ‚â°I.

x ‚ààXap.

4. Functional calculus
In this section we consider sectorial operators. These are unbounded operators whose spec-
tra lie in a sector. Generators of bounded C0-semigroups are of this type. If A is such an
operator, we will deÔ¨Åne closed operators f (A) for a large class of holomorphic functions
deÔ¨Åned on a sector. Of particular importance are fractional powers AŒ±. We will introduce
the class BIP which is important to establish theorems of maximal regularity but also for
results on interpolation. Throughout this chapter X is a complex Banach space.
4.1. Sectorial operators
Given an angle 0 < œï < œÄ, we consider the open sector
Œ£œï :=

œï-sectorial. In that case we deÔ¨Åne the sectoriality angle œïsec(A) of A by

4.1.1. Simple criterion.
If (‚àí‚àû,0) ‚äÇœÅ(A) and

This follows from the power series expansion of the resolvent.
4.1.2. Bounded holomorphic semigroups.
An operator A is sectorial with œïsec(A) < œÄ
2
if and only if ‚àíA generates a bounded holomorphic semigroup T . It is a C0-semigroup if
and only if D(A) is dense. This is automatically the case if X is reÔ¨Çexive.
4.1.3. Bounded semigroups.
If ‚àíA generates a bounded C0-semigroup, then A is secto-
rial and œïsec(A) ‚©ΩœÄ
2 .
4.1.4. Injective operators.
Let A be a sectorial operator with range R(A) := {Ax: x ‚àà
D(A)}. If A is injective, then A‚àí1 with domain D(A‚àí1) = R(A) is sectorial and
œïsec(A‚àí1) = œïsec(A).
4.1.5. ReÔ¨Çexive spaces.
If A is an injective sectorial operator on a reÔ¨Çexive space, then
D(A) ‚à©R(A) is dense.
4.1.6. Warning.
The notion of sectorial operators is not universal in the literature. In par-
ticular, it does not coincide with Kato‚Äôs deÔ¨Ånition in [[Kat66]]. In [PS90], [DHP01]
and [[Pr√º93]] the additional assumption that A is injective, densely deÔ¨Åned with dense
image is incorporated into the deÔ¨Ånition of sectorial. This implies in particular that
D(A) ‚à©R(A) is dense.
4.2. The sum of commuting operators
Many interesting problems can be formulated in the following form. Let A and B be oper-
ators on a Banach space: Under which conditions is the problem
Ax + Bx = y
(P )
well posed? This means that for all y ‚ààX there exists a unique x ‚ààD(A) ‚à©D(B) solv-
ing (P). In this section we will establish a spectral theoretical approach which leads to a
‚Äúweak solution‚Äù. We deÔ¨Åne the operator A+B on the domain D(A+B) := D(A)‚à©D(B)
by (A + B)x = Ax + Bx.
Assume that œÅ(A) ‚à©œÅ(B) Ã∏= ‚àÖ. We say that A and B commute if R(Œª,A)R(Œª,B) =
R(Œª,B)R(Œª,A) for all (equivalently one) Œª ‚ààœÅ(A) ‚à©œÅ(B). This is equivalent to saying
that for some (equivalently all) Œª ‚ààœÅ(A) one has R(Œª,A)D(B) ‚äÇD(B) and BR(Œª,A)x =
R(Œª,A)Bx for all x ‚ààD(B). For example, if A and B generate C0-semigroups S and T ,
then A and B commute if and only if S(t)T (t) = T (t)S(t) for all t ‚©æ0. In that case
U(t) = T (t)S(t) is a C0-semigroup, the operator A + B is closable and A + B is the
generator of U.

20
W. Arendt
THEOREM. Let A, B be two commuting sectorial operators such that
œïsec(A) + œïsec(B) < œÄ.
Then A + B has a unique extension (A + B)‚àºsuch that (œâ,‚àû) ‚äÇœÅ((A + B)‚àº) for some
œâ ‚ààR and such that (A + B)‚àºcommutes with A. Moreover,
œÉ

(A + B)‚àº	
‚äÇœÉ(A) + œÉ(B).
(4.4)
If D(A) is dense in X, then A + B is closable and (A + B)‚àºis the closure of A + B.
Note that by (4.4), (A + B)‚àºis invertible if 0 ‚ààœÅ(A) or 0 ‚ààœÅ(B). This result is due to
Da Prato and Grisvard [DPG75], Th√©or√®me 3.7, under the assumption that D(A) is dense.
The spectral inclusion (4.2.1) was proved in [[Pr√º93], Theorem 8.5] and in [ARS94], where
also nondensely deÔ¨Åned operators are considered.
If A or B is invertible, then by the Theorem, for each y ‚ààX, there exists a unique
x ‚ààD((A + B)‚àº) such that
(A + B)‚àºx = y.
One aim of the functional calculus to be developed here is to establish conditions un-
der which x ‚ààD(A) ‚à©D(B), which is expressed by saying that the solution has maxi-
mal regularity.

In fact, (A‚àíŒ±)ReŒ±>0 is a bounded holomorphic semigroup. Its generator is ‚àílogA (which

(i.e., if and only if (A‚àíŒ±)ReŒ±>0 is a C0-semigroup).
A particular case of Section 4.4.1 occurs when ‚àíA generates an exponentially stable

invertible and A‚àíŒ± can be expressed in terms of the semigroup instead of the resolvent as

Next we consider imaginary powers Ais of an injective sectorial operator. They play an
important role for regularity theory and also for interpolation theory.

4.4.3. Characterization of BIP.
Let A be a sectorial injective operator on X. Then by
Section 4.4.2 we can deÔ¨Åne the closed operators Ais, s ‚ààR, and also the closed operator
logA (by Section 4.3.6).
THEOREM. The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) D(A) ‚à©R(A) is dense and Ais ‚ààL(X) for all s ‚ààR.
(ii) The operator ilogA generates a C0-group U.
In that case U(s) = Ais, s ‚ààR.
DEFINITION. We say that A has bounded imaginary powers and write A ‚ààBIP, if A is
injective, sectorial and if the two equivalent conditions of Theorem are satisÔ¨Åed.
Note that this includes the hypothesis that D(A) ‚à©R(A) be dense in X. Recall however,
that D(A)‚à©R(A) is automatically dense in X if X is reÔ¨Çexive and A is a sectorial, injective
operator. It is obvious that
A ‚ààBIP
if and only if
A‚àí1 ‚ààBIP,
(4.23)
References: [Haa03a], [[Pr√º93]].
4.4.4. BIP for invertible operators.
Property BIP can be formulated in a different way if
the operator is invertible. Let A be sectorial of dense domain. Assume that 0 ‚ààœÅ(A). Then,
for ReŒ± > 0, the operator A‚àíŒ± ‚ààL(X) was deÔ¨Åned in Section 4.4.1, and we had seen that
(A‚àíŒ±)ReŒ±>0 is a holomorphic C0-semigroup which is bounded on Œ£œï for each 0 < œï < œÄ
2 .
The generator of this semigroup is ‚àílogA. Now it follows from Section 2.3 that A ‚ààBIP
if and only if the holomorphic C0-semigroup (A‚àíŒ±)ReŒ±>0 has a trace. We formulate this
as a theorem.
THEOREM. Let A be a sectorial densely deÔ¨Åned operator with 0 ‚ààœÅ(A). The following
assertion are equivalent:
(i) A ‚ààBIP;
(ii) there exists c > 0 such that ‚à•A‚àíŒ±‚à•‚©Ωc whenever ReŒ± > 0, |Œ±| ‚©Ω1.
4.4.5. The BIP-type.
Let A ‚ààBIP. Then we denote by
œïbip(A) = infœâ ‚ààR: ‚àÉM ‚©æ0 such that
Ais ‚©ΩMeœâ|s| for all s ‚ààR
the group-type of the C0-group (Ais)s‚ààR. We call œïbip(A) the BIP-type of A. One al-
ways has
œïsec(A) ‚©Ωœïbip(A).
(4.24)
Recall from (4.10) that œïsec(A) = œâst(logA). If X is a Hilbert space, then œâst(logA) =
œïbip(A) (by (4.12)). Thus we obtain
œïbip(A) = œïsec(A)
on Hilbert space.
(4.25)

26
W. Arendt
This is McIntosh‚Äôs result with a new proof due to Haase. The identity (4.25) is no longer
true on Banach spaces. Recently, an example is given by Haase [Haa03a,Haa03b] where
œïsec(A) < œÄ < œïbip(A)
on a UMD-space X.
(4.26)
In fact, X = Lp(R,œâ1 dx) ‚à©Lq(R,œâ2 dx) for 1 < p < 2 < q < ‚àûand œâ1,œâ2 strictly
positive measurable functions. Another example of different sectorial and BIP-angle is
given independently by Kalton [Kal03], where the operator has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus,
in addition.
4.4.6. An inverse theorem for BIP operators.
If A ‚ààBIP, then (Ais)s‚ààR is a C0-group.
Which groups occur in this manner? There is a very satisfying answer if the underlying
Banach space has some geometric properties. We refer to Section 6.1.3 for the deÔ¨Ånition
of UMD-spaces. Here we just recall that each space Lp,1 < p < ‚àû, is a UMD-space. Let
(U(s))s‚ààR be a C0-group with generator iB. Then B is a strip-type operator. Recall the
deÔ¨Ånition of œâst(B) from Section 4.3.4.
THEOREM (Monniaux). Let iB be the generator of a C0-group U on a UMD-space X.
Assume that
œâst(B) < œÄ.
Then there exists a unique sectorial operator A such that Ais = U(s) for all s ‚ààR.
We call A the analytic generator of U.
This theorem is due to Monniaux [Mon99] for the case where œâU < œÄ (the group-
type of U). It was Haase [Haa03b] who observed that the weaker assumption œâst(B) < œÄ
sufÔ¨Åces. Of course, in the situation of the theorem one has B = logA. One may ask more
generally which strip type operators B are of the form logA for some sectorial operator A.
This seems to be unknown. It is known though, that the hypothesis on the Banach space
cannot be omitted in the above theorem (see [Mon99] for an example). More precisely,
on each Banach space X, to each C0-group U one can associate the analytic generator A.
If A is sectorial, then Ais = U(s), s ‚ààR. But if the space X is not a UMD-space, then it may
happen that œÅ(A) = ‚àÖ. In particular, A is not sectorial. The notion of analytic generators
is due to Cioranescu and Zsid√≥ [CZ76] before the notion and properties of UMD-spaces
were known. Their aim was to treat Tomita‚ÄìTakesaki theory for von Neumann algebras.
4.4.7. Bounded analytic generators.
We now describe when the C0-group (Ais)s‚ààR is
the boundary group of a holomorphic semigroup (see Section 2.3 for this notion).
PROPOSITION [Mon99]. Let U be a C0-group of type < œÄ on a UMD-space X. The fol-
lowing assertions are equivalent:
(i) The analytic generator A of U is bounded;
(ii) there exists a holomorphic C0-semigroup (T (z))Rez>0 such that U(t)x =
limr‚Üì0 T (it + r)x for all x ‚ààX.
In that case one has A = T (1).

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
27
4.4.8. The Dore‚ÄìVenni theorem.
Next we establish the famous Dore‚ÄìVenni theo-
rem [DoVe87] on maximal regularity. It gives an answer to the question of closedness
of A + B which arose in Section 4.2. We refer to Section 6.1.3 for the deÔ¨Ånition and
properties of UMD-spaces.
The following version of the Dore‚ÄìVenni theorem is due to Pr√ºss and Sohr [PS90].
THEOREM. Let X be a UMD-space. Let A,B ‚ààBIP such that œïbip(A) + œïbip(B) < œÄ.
Assume that A and B commute. Then A + B is closed. Moreover, A + B ‚ààBIP and
œïbip(A + B) ‚©Ωmaxœïbip(A),œïbip(B).
If one of the operators is invertible, it is possible to deduce this result from Monniaux‚Äô
inverse theorem (Section 4.4.6). We sketch the proof.
PROOF [MON99]. Assume that 0 ‚ààœÅ(B). Then by Section 4.4.7 the group (B‚àíis)s‚ààR is
the boundary of a holomorphic C0-semigroup T and B‚àí1 = T (1). Let W(t) = AitB‚àíit. By
Monniaux‚Äô inverse theorem there exists a sectorial operator C such that Cit = AitB‚àíit. It is
not difÔ¨Åcult to show that C = AB‚àí1 with domain D(C) = {x ‚ààX: B‚àí1x ‚ààD(A)}. In par-
ticular, (AB‚àí1 + I) is invertible. Let y ‚ààX. We have to Ô¨Ånd x ‚ààD(A) + D(B) such that
Ax + Bx = y; i.e., (AB‚àí1 + I)Bx = y. Thus x = B‚àí1(AB‚àí1 + I)‚àí1y is a solution.
‚ñ°
4.4.9. A noncommutative Dore‚ÄìVenni theorem.
The assumption that A and B commute
can be relaxed by imposing a growth condition on the commutator of the resolvent.
THEOREM (Monniaux and Pr√ºss [MP97]). Assume that X is a UMD-space. Let
A, B ‚ààBIP with œïbip(A) + œïbip(B) < œÄ. Assume that 0 ‚ààœÅ(A). Let œàA > œïbip(A),
œàB > œïbip(B) be angles such that œàA + œàB < œÄ. Assume that there exist constants
0 ‚©ΩŒ± < Œ≤ < 1 and c ‚©æ0 such that
AR(Œª,A)

A‚àí1R(Œº,B) ‚àíR(Œº,B)A‚àí1 ‚©Ω
c
(1 + |Œª|1‚àíŒ±)|Œº|1+Œ≤
for all Œª ‚ààŒ£œÄ‚àíœàA and all Œº ‚ààŒ£œÄ‚àíœàB . Then there exists œâ ‚ààR such that A + B + œâ is
closed and sectorial.
This result can be applied to Volterra equations [MP97], to nonautonomous evolu-
tion equations [HM00a,HM00b] and also to prove maximal regularity of the Ornstein‚Äì
Uhlenbeck operator [MPRS00].
4.4.10. Interpolation spaces and BIP.
Let A be an injective sectorial operator. Then
D(AŒ±) is a Banach space for the norm
‚à•x‚à•D(AŒ±) := ‚à•x‚à•+
AŒ±x
,
0 < Œ± < 1.

28
W. Arendt
PROPOSITION ([[Tri95], p. 103], [Yag84], [[MS01], Theorem 11.6.1]). Let A ‚ààBIP. Then
the complex interpolation space [X,D(A)]Œ± is isomorphic to D(AŒ±) for 0 < Œ± < 1.
Now assume in addition that A is invertible. Then Dore [Dor99a] (see also [Dor99b]
for the noninvertible case) showed that the part of A in the real interpolation space
(X,D(A))Œ±,p has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus whenever 0 < Œ± < 1, 1 < p < ‚àû. (See Sec-
tion 4.5 for the deÔ¨Ånition of H ‚àû-calculus.) If X is a Hilbert space, then (X,D(A))Œ±,2 =
[X,D(A)]Œ±. Thus, if X is a Hilbert space, the part of A in [X,D(A)]Œ± has a bounded
H ‚àû-calculus. Observe that the part of A in D(AŒ±) is similar to A. Thus, if D(AŒ±) =
[X,D(A)]Œ±, then A has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus.
We have proved the converse of the above proposition and may formulate the following
characterization on Hilbert spaces.
THEOREM. Let A be a sectorial, invertible operator on a Hilbert space and let 0 < Œ± < 1.
The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) A ‚ààBIP;
(ii) D(AŒ±) = [X,D(A)]Œ±;
(iii) the H ‚àû-calculus is bounded.
For further results on Hilbert spaces we refer to Section 5 and to the paper by Auscher,
McIntosh and Nahmrod [AMN97].
This interesting relation between BIP and interpolation spaces seemed to be the mo-
tivation of much research on operators with bounded imaginary powers in the seventies
(see, e.g., Seeley‚Äôs paper [See67]). Long time after this, the Dore‚ÄìVenni theorem lead to a
different direction, namely regularity theory.
4.5. Bounded H ‚àû-calculus for sectorial operators
Let A be an injective sectorial operator on a Banach space X and let œÄ ‚©æœï > œïsec(A).
Then for f ‚ààH ‚àû(Œ£œï) the closed operator f (A) was deÔ¨Åned in Section 4.3.
DEFINITION. We say that A has a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£œï)-calculus if
f (A) ‚ààL(X)
for all f ‚ààH ‚àû(Œ£œï).
(4.27)
In that case, the mapping
f ‚Üíf (A)
is a continuous algebra homomorphism from H ‚àû(Œ£œï) into L(X).
We note the following: Let œïsec(A) < œï1 < œï2 ‚©ΩœÄ. If A has a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£œï1)-cal-
culus then also the H ‚àû(Œ£œï2)-calculus is bounded. Thus, the weakest property in this con-
text is to have a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£œÄ)-calculus for the cut plane Œ£œÄ = C \ {x ‚ààR: x < 0}.

4.5.2. Unbounded H ‚àû-calculus.

4.6. Perturbation
Let A be a sectorial operator on a Banach space X. We consider perturbations A+B where
B :D(A) ‚ÜíX is linear. We say that B is A-bounded if B is continuous with respect to the
graph norm on D(A); i.e., if there exist constants a ‚©æ0, b ‚©æ0 such that
‚à•Bx‚à•‚©Ωa‚à•Ax‚à•+ b‚à•x‚à•,
x ‚ààD(A).
(4.36)
The inÔ¨Åmum over all a > 0 such that there exists b > 0 such that (4.36) holds is called
the A-bound of B. A small perturbation of A is a linear mapping B :D(A) ‚ÜíX with
A-bound 0. This is equivalent to limŒª‚Üí‚àû‚à•BR(Œª,A)‚à•= 0 as is easy to see. Here we
consider the following two stronger conditions.
BR(Œª,A)
 ‚©Ωc
ŒªŒ≤ ,
Œª ‚©æ1;
(4.37)
R(Œª,A)Bx
 ‚©Ωc
ŒªŒ≤ ‚à•x‚à•,
Œª ‚©æ1,x ‚ààD(A).
(4.38)
THEOREM. Assume that B :D(A) ‚ÜíX is linear such that (4.37) or (4.38) is satisÔ¨Åed
for some Œ≤ > 0, c ‚©æ0. Assume that A and A + B are invertible and sectorial. Then the
following holds:
(a) A ‚ààH ‚àû‚áíA + B ‚ààH ‚àû;
(b) A ‚ààBIP ‚áíA + B ‚ààBIP.
We refer to [AHS94] or [ABH01] for the proof. Given a sectorial operator A there exists
a constant ŒµA > 0 such that A + B + œâ is sectorial for some œâ ‚ààR whenever B has an
A-bound smaller than ŒµA. However, the properties H ‚àûand BIP are not preserved.
COUNTEREXAMPLE [MY90]. There exists an invertible operator A ‚ààH ‚àûon a Hilbert
space X such that, for each Œµ > 0, there exists an operator BŒµ :D(A) ‚ÜíX with A-bound
less than Œµ > 0 such that A + BŒµ + œâ /‚ààBIP for any œâ ‚ààR.
In view of the counterexample one would not expect that the properties H ‚àûor BIP are
preserved under small perturbations. This seems to be unknown, though.
4.7. Groups and positive contraction semigroups
In this section we give two classes of examples of operators with bounded H ‚àû-calculus.
4.7.1. Groups.
Generators of bounded C0-groups and their squares yield an interesting
class of examples.
THEOREM [HP98]. Let B be the generator of a bounded C0-group on a UMD-space X.
Then

W. Arendt
(a) B has a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£œï)-calculus for each œï > œÄ/2;
(b) ‚àíB2 has a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£œï)-calculus for each œï > 0.
We give an example.

4.7.3. Positive contraction semigroups on Lp.
Next we consider positive semigroups.
The following result is due to Duong [Duo89] after a more special result was proved by
Cowling [Cow83]. Vector-valued versions are given in [HP98].
THEOREM. Let ‚àíA be the generator of a positive, contractive C0-semigroup on Lp(Œ©),
1 <p <‚àû, where (Œ©,Œ£,Œº) is a measure space. Then A has a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£œï)-calculus
for each œï > œÄ/2.
This result can be extended to semigroups on Lp which are dominated by a positive
contraction semigroup. The proof can be reduced to the group case (Section 4.7.1) by an
interesting dilation theorem due to Fendler extending the Akcoglu dilation theorem for
single operators to semigroups. We give more details.
4.7.4. r-contractive semigroups on Lp.
Let S be an operator on Lp(Œ©), 1 ‚©Ωp ‚©Ω‚àû.
We say that S is regular, if S is a linear combination of positive operators; or equivalently,
if S is dominated by a positive operator T on Lp(Œ©), i.e.,
|Sf | ‚©ΩT |f |,
f ‚ààLp(Œ©),
where |f |(x) = |f (x)|, x ‚ààŒ©. In that case there exists a smallest positive operator |S|
which dominates S. We call ‚à•S‚à•r := ‚à•|S|‚à•the r-norm of S. If p = 1 or ‚àû, then every
bounded operator S on Lp(Œ©) is regular and ‚à•S‚à•= ‚à•S‚à•r, but if 1 < p < ‚àûthis is false
(if Lp(Œ©) has inÔ¨Ånite dimension). We refer to [[Sch74], Chapter IV].
THEOREM. Let 1 < p < ‚àû. Let T be a C0-semigroup on Lp(Œ©) such that ‚à•T (t)‚à•r ‚©Ω1
for all t ‚©æ0. Denote by ‚àíA the generator of T . Then A has a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£œï)-calculus
for each œï > œÄ/2.

5. Form methods and functional calculus
On Hilbert space generators of contraction C0-semigroups are characterized by m-accreti-
vity. This most convenient criterion also implies boundedness of the H ‚àû-calculus, as an
easy consequence of the Spectral Theorem after a dilation to a unitary group. If the semi-
group is holomorphic, then conversely, a bounded H ‚àû-calculus also implies m-accretivity
after rescaling and changing the scalar product. In addition, the generator is associated
with a closed form. The interesting interplay of forms, m-accretivity and H ‚àû-calculus on
Hilbert space, this is the subject of the present section.
5.1. Bounded H ‚àû-calculus on Hilbert space
Things are much simpler on Hilbert space than on general Banach spaces. The BIP property
is equivalent to bounded H ‚àû-calculus and all angles can be chosen optimal as was shown
in Section 4.4.10, (4.26) and (4.34). We reformulate this more formally.
THEOREM (McIntosh). Let A be an injective, sectorial operator on a Hilbert space. The
following are equivalent:
(i) A ‚ààBIP;
(ii) for all œï > œïsec(A), the H ‚àû(Œ£œï)-calculus is bounded;
(iii) the H ‚àû(Œ£œÄ)-calculus is bounded.
In that case œïbip(A) = œïsec(A).
This optimal situation in Hilbert space contrasts the Lp-case, p Ã∏= 2, where we had
seen that property BIP does not imply boundedness of the H ‚àû(Œ£œÄ)-calculus (see Sec-
tion 4.5.3). Also had we seen that it can happen that œïsec(A) < œÄ < œïbip(A) on Lp, p Ã∏= 2.

36
W. Arendt
Also the Dore‚ÄìVenni theorem needs fewer hypotheses on Hilbert space.
THEOREM (Dore‚ÄìVenni on Hilbert space [DoVe87]). Let A and B be two commuting
injective, sectorial operators on a Hilbert space such that œïsec(A) + œïsec(B) < œÄ. Assume
that A ‚ààBIP. Then A + B is closed.
We mention that this result does not hold on Lp for p Ã∏= 2 ([Lan98], Theorem 2.3).
5.2. m-accretive operators on Hilbert space
The simplest unbounded operators are multiplication operators. Let (Œ©,Œ£,Œº) be a mea-
sure space and let m:Œ© ‚ÜíR be a measurable function. DeÔ¨Åne Am on L2(Œ©) by
Amu = mu with domain
D(Am) =

u ‚ààL2(Œ©): m ¬∑ u ‚ààL2(Œ©)

.
For the operator Am one has the best possible spectral calculus. For each f ‚ààL‚àû(R),
we may deÔ¨Åne f (A) = Af ‚ó¶m ‚ààL(L2(Œ©)). It is not difÔ¨Åcult to see that this deÔ¨Ånition is
consistent with our previous one whenever f ‚ààH ‚àû(Œ£œï) for some œï > œÄ/2.
5.2.1. The Spectral theorem.
The spectral theorem says that each self-adjoint operator is
unitarily equivalent to a multiplication operator.
SPECTRAL THEOREM. Let A be a self-adjoint operator on H . Then there exists a
measure space (Œ©,Œ£,Œº), a measurable function m:Œ© ‚ÜíR and a unitary operator
U :H ‚ÜíL2(Œ©) such that
(a) UD(A) = D(Am);
(b) AmUx = UAx, x ‚ààD(A).
Thus, multiplication operators and self-adjoint operators are just the same thing.
Now recall that an operator A generates a unitary group (i.e., a C0-group of unitary
operators) if and only if iA is self-adjoint. Thus iA is equivalent to a multiplication opera-
tor. This shows in particular that each generator A of a unitary group on H has a bounded
H ‚àû(Œ£œï)-calculus for all œï > œÄ/2. In fact, it is easy to show that for f ‚ààH ‚àû(Œ£œï) one has
f (A) = U‚àí1Af ‚ó¶mU.
5.2.2. Bounded H ‚àû-calculus for m-accretive operators.
Recall that an operator A on
a Hilbert space H is called m-accretive if
(a) Re(Ax|x) ‚©æ0 for all x ‚ààD(A);
(b) I + A is surjective.
The Lumer‚ÄìPhillips theorem asserts that an operator A is m-accretive if and only if
‚àíA generates a contractive C0-semigroup. In particular, if A is m-accretive, then A is
sectorial and œïsec(A) ‚©ΩœÄ
2 .

5.2.3. Equivalence of bounded H ‚àû-calculus and m-accretivity.
Let (¬∑|¬∑)1 be an equiva-

for all u ‚ààH . Of course, having a bounded H ‚àû-calculus is independent of the equivalent
norm on H we choose. Thus, if A is a sectorial operator on H which is m-accretive with
respect to some equivalent scalar product, then A ‚ààH ‚àû. This describes already the class
of all operators A with bounded H ‚àû-calculus.
THEOREM (Le Merdy [LeM98a]). Let A be an injective, sectorial operator on H such
that œïsec(A) < œÄ/2. The following are equivalent:
(i) A ‚ààH ‚àû,
(ii) there exists an equivalent scalar product (¬∑|¬∑)1 on H such that Re(Au|u)1 ‚©æ0 for
all u ‚ààD(A);

The proof of Le Merdy [LeM98a] uses the theory of completely bounded operators and

is given by Haase [Haa02].
The theorem gives a very satisfying characterization of the boundedness of the
H ‚àû-calculus; see also Section 5.3 for a description by forms. However, it is restricted
to sectorial operators of sectorial type smaller than œÄ/2:
5.2.4. Counterexample.
There exists an invertible, sectorial operator A on a Hilbert
space H such that ‚àíA generates a bounded C0-semigroup T on H . Moreover, A has
a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£œï)-calculus for any œï > œÄ/2. But for all œâ > 0, A + œâ is not accretive
with respect to any equivalent scalar product.
The counterexample is due to Le Merdy [LeM98a] (based on a famous example of Pisier
solving the Halmos problem) with an additional argument by Haase [Haa02] (taking care
of the case where œâ > 0).
5.3. Form methods
A most efÔ¨Åcient way to deÔ¨Åne generators of holomorphic semigroups on a Hilbert space
H is the form method (sometimes it is also called ‚Äúvariational method‚Äù).
Let H be a Hilbert space. If V is another Hilbert space we write V ‚ÜíH if V is a sub-
space of H such that the embedding is continuous. We write V ‚Üíd H if in addition V is
dense in H .
DEFINITION. A closed form on H is a sesquilinear form a :V √ó V ‚ÜíC which is contin-
uous, i.e.,

for some œâ ‚ààR, Œ± > 0. The space V is called the domain of a.

5.3.1. The operator associated with a closed form.
Let a be a closed form on H with
dense domain V . Then we associate an operator A with a, given by
D(A) = u ‚ààV : ‚àÉv ‚ààH such that a(u,œï) = (v|œï)H for all œï ‚ààV ,
Au = v.
Note that v is well deÔ¨Åned since V is dense in H . We call A the operator associated
with a. It is not difÔ¨Åcult to see that A + œâ is sectorial with angle œïsec(A + œâ) < œÄ/2.
Moreover, A + œâ is m-accretive (where œâ is the constant occurring in (5.2)). Thus we
obtain the following.
THEOREM. Let A be an operator associated with a closed form. Then there exists œâ ‚ààR
such that A + œâ ‚ààH ‚àû.
5.3.2. Example: self-adjoint operators.
Let a be a densely deÔ¨Åned closed form on H
with domain V . Assume that a is symmetric; i.e., a(u,v) = a(v,u) for all u,v ‚ààV . Let
A be the operator associated with a. Then A is bounded below (i.e., (Au|u) ‚©æ‚àíœâ‚à•u‚à•2
H
for all u ‚ààD(A) and some œâ ‚ààR) and self-adjoint. Conversely, let A be a self-adjoint
operator which is bounded below. Then A is associated with a densely deÔ¨Åned symmetric
closed form.
We give a classical concrete example right now. Later we will study elliptic operators in
more detail.

5.3.4. Characterization of operators deÔ¨Åned by forms.
Let A be an operator on H .
We say that A is induced by a form, if there exists a densely deÔ¨Åned closed form a on H
such that A is associated with a. It is easy to describe such operators by an accretivity-
condition.
THEOREM [[Kat66]]. Let A be an operator on H . The following are equivalent:
(i) A is induced by a form;
(ii) there exist œâ ‚ààR and 0 < Œ∏ < œÄ

(a) (œâ + A)D(A) = H ;
(b) e¬±iŒ∏(œâ + A) is accretive.
(iii) ‚àíA generates a holomorphic C0-semigroup T of angle Œ∏ ‚àà(0, œÄ
2 ) such that for
some œâ ‚ààR,

(iv) the numerical range W(A) := {(Ax|x): x ‚ààD(A),‚à•x‚à•= 1} is contained in
Œ£Œ∏ + œâ for some Œ∏ ‚àà(0,œÄ/2), œâ ‚ààR and (‚àí‚àû,œâ) ‚à©œÅ(A) Ã∏= ‚àÖ.
Property (ii) is sometimes formulated by saying that A is strongly quasi-m-accretive
(and strongly m-accretive if œâ = 0).
5.3.5. Changing scalar products.
Let a :V √ó V ‚ÜíC be a closed densely deÔ¨Åned form
on H . The deÔ¨Ånition of the associated operator A depends on the scalar product on H .
Let (¬∑|¬∑)1 be another equivalent scalar product on H . Then there exists a self-adjoint oper-
ator Q ‚ààL(H) such that

for all u,v ‚ààH,

some Œµ > 0. Let u ‚ààD(A). Then u ‚ààV and a(u,œï) = (Au|œï) = (QAu|œï)1 for all œï ‚ààV .
This shows that the operator A1 associated with a on (H,(¬∑|¬∑)1) is given by A1 = QA. With
the help of Le Merdy‚Äôs theorem in Section 5.2.3 one obtains the following characterization
of the class H ‚àû.
THEOREM [ABH01]. Let A be an operator on H . The following are equivalent:

(ii) there exists an equivalent scalar product (¬∑|¬∑)1 on H such that A is induced by
a form on (H,(¬∑|¬∑)1);
(iii) there exists a strictly form-positive self-adjoint operator Q ‚ààL(H) such that QA
is induced by a form.
We remark that the rescaling A + œâ is needed to obtain a sectorial operator. From Sec-
tion 4.6 we know that for an invertible sectorial operator A and œâ > 0 one has
A ‚ààH ‚àû
if and only if
A + œâ ‚ààH ‚àû.
5.3.6. More on equivalent scalar products.
In the Section 5.3.5 we characterized those
operators A which come from a form on (H,(¬∑|¬∑)1) for some equivalent scalar product.
What happens if we replace ‚Äúsome‚Äù by ‚Äúall ‚Äù?
THEOREM (Matolcsi [Mat03]). Let A be an operator on H . The following are equivalent:
(i) A is bounded;
(ii) for each equivalent scalar product (¬∑|¬∑)1 on H , the operator A is induced by a form
on (H,(¬∑|¬∑)1).
5.4. Form sums and Trotter‚Äôs product formula
There is a natural way to deÔ¨Åne the sum of closed forms leading to a closed form again.
Here we want to allow also nondense form domains. Let H be a Hilbert space.

We deÔ¨Åne closed forms on H as before but

5.5. The square root property
Let H be a Hilbert space. During this section we consider a continuous sesquilinear form
a :V √ó V ‚ÜíC which is coercive with respect to H , i.e.,
Rea(u,u) ‚©æŒΩ‚à•u‚à•2
V ,
u ‚ààV,
where V ‚Üíd H and ŒΩ > 0. This means that the ellipticity condition (5.2) is satisÔ¨Åed
for œâ = 0. We consider the operator A on H which is associated with a. Thus A is a sec-
torial operator and 0 ‚ààœÅ(A).
5.5.1. The square root property.
We say that the operator A (or the form a) has the square
root property if V = D(A1/2). It is easy to see that this is the case if a is symmetric (see the
Example below). But an example of McIntosh [McI82] shows that the square root property
does not hold for all closed, coercive forms. Here is an easy characterization of the square
root property.
PROPOSITION. The following are equivalent:
(i) D(A1/2) = V ,
(ii) D(A‚àó1/2) = V ,
(iii) D(A1/2) = D(A‚àó1/2).
In that case the three norms ‚à•¬∑ ‚à•V , ‚à•A1/2x‚à•and ‚à•A‚àó1/2x‚à•are equivalent. This is an im-
mediate consequence of the Closed Graph theorem since all three spaces are continuously
embedded into H . Of course one may also ask whether (iii) is valid for other powers Œ±
than Œ± = 1
2. Surprisingly, by a result of Kato [[Kat66]] one always has
D

AŒ±	
= D

A‚àóŒ±	
for all 0 < Œ± < 1
2 for each m-accretive operator. Thus Œ± = 1
2 is the critical power for which
things may go wrong.
5.5.2. Induced operators on V and V ‚Ä≤.
Since V ‚Üíd H , we may identify H with a sub-
space of V ‚Ä≤. Indeed, given x ‚ààH , we deÔ¨Åne jx ‚ààV ‚Ä≤ by jx(y) = (x|y)H. Then j :H ‚ÜíV ‚Ä≤,
x ‚Üíjx is linear, continuous and has dense image. We will identify x and jx so that
V ‚Üí
d H ‚Üí
d V ‚Ä≤.
By the Lax‚ÄìMilgram theorem, there is an isomorphism AV ‚Ä≤ :V ‚ÜíV ‚Ä≤ given by ‚ü®AV ‚Ä≤u,v‚ü©=
a(u,v), u,v ‚ààV . Here V ‚Ä≤ denotes the space of all continuous, anti-linear forms on V
(i.e., V ‚Ä≤ = { ¬Øœï: œï ‚ààV ‚àó}, V ‚àóthe dual space of V ). The operator ‚àíAV ‚Ä≤ generates a
bounded holomorphic C0-semigroup TV ‚Ä≤ on V ‚Ä≤ (see [[Tan79], Section 3.5]). Moreover,
TV ‚Ä≤(t)|H = T (t), the semigroup generated by ‚àíA on H and, clearly, A is the part of AV ‚Ä≤
in H . Finally, the part of AV ‚Ä≤ in V , i.e., the operator AV given by AV u = Au with do-
main D(AV ) = {u ‚ààD(A): Au ‚ààV } is similar to AV ‚Ä≤ and ‚àíAV generates a holomorphic

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
45
C0-semigroup TV which is the restriction of T to V . Thus, AV and AV ‚Ä≤ are always similar;
but AV and A are not, unless A has the square root property:
THEOREM. The following are equivalent:
(i) D(A1/2) = V ;
(ii) AV ‚ààH ‚àû;
(iii) AV ‚Ä≤ ‚ààH ‚àû;
(iv) AV and A are similar.
Thus, one can describe the square root property by the boundedness of the H ‚àû-calculus
of AV (or AV ‚Ä≤).
Before giving a proof of the Theorem we determine the diverse notions in the case of
self-adjoint operators.
EXAMPLE (Self-adjoint operators). Assume that the form a deÔ¨Åned at the beginning of the
section is symmetric. Then the associated operator A is self-adjoint. Thus, by the spectral
theorem, we may assume that H = L2(Œ©,Œ£,Œº) and Au = m ¬∑ u, D(A) = {u ‚ààL2(Œ©):
mu ‚ààL2(Œ©)}, where m:Œ© ‚Üí[ŒΩ,‚àû) is measurable. Then V = L2(Œ©,mdŒº) and
a(u,v) =

and AV is given by AV u = mu with domain D(AV ) = {u ‚ààV : mu ‚ààV } = L2(Œ©,m3 dŒº).
Now, A‚àíŒ± is a bounded operator on H given by A‚àíŒ±u = m‚àíŒ±u. Thus D(AŒ±) =

0 < Œ± < 1.
REMARK (DeÔ¨Ånition of the complex interpolation space). Let V ‚Üíd H . It is possible

where [H,V ]Œ± denotes the complex interpolation space.

(i) ‚áí(iv). Since A ‚ààH ‚àû, (iv) implies (ii). And (ii) implies (iii) since AV and AV ‚Ä≤
are always similar. Finally we show that (iii) implies (i). From the previous remark it
is clear that H = [V ‚Ä≤,V ]1/2. Now if AV ‚Ä≤ ‚ààH ‚àû, then, by Section 4.4.10, D(A1/2

5.6. Groups and cosine functions
In the preceding sections we have characterized those sectorial operators A on a Hilbert
space with sectorial angle œïsec(A) < œÄ/2 which have a bounded H ‚àû-calculus. This is

46
W. Arendt
equivalent to saying that A is deÔ¨Åned by a closed form on (H,(¬∑|¬∑)1) for some equiva-
lent scalar product (¬∑|¬∑)1. Now we will see that squares of group generators are always of
this form.
5.6.1. Groups on Hilbert spaces.
Let U be a bounded C0-group on a Hilbert space H .
Then, by a classical result of Sz.-Nagy, there exists an equivalent scalar product (¬∑|¬∑)1 on H
such that the group is unitary in (H(¬∑|¬∑)1). Concerning arbitrary C0-groups the following
holds (see, e.g., [Haa03a]).
PROPOSITION. Let B be the generator of a C0-group on H . Then there exists a bounded
operator C on H such that B + C generates a bounded C0-group.
Thus, on Hilbert space, up to equivalent scalar product, each generator of a C0-group
B is of the form
B = iB0 + C,
where B0 is self-adjoint and C bounded.
5.6.2. Squares of generators of C0-groups.
Let B be the generator of a C0-group. Then
B2 generates a holomorphic C0-semigroup of angle œÄ/2. Thus, for each 0 < Œ∏ < œÄ/2,
there exists œâ ‚ààR such that ‚àíB2 + œâI is sectorial and œïsec(‚àíB2 + œâI) < Œ∏.
THEOREM (Haase [Haa03a]). Let A = ‚àíB2, where B generates a C0-group on a Hilbert
space. Then there exists œâ ‚ààR such that A + œâ ‚ààH ‚àû.
Operators of the form B2 ‚àíœâ with B a group generator are the same as generators
of cosine functions. This holds in Hilbert spaces, and more generally on UMD-spaces.
We describe these facts, starting on arbitrary Banach spaces Ô¨Årst and concluding with the
square root property.
5.6.3. Cosine functions.
Let X be a Banach space. A cosine function on X is a strongly
continuous function C :R ‚ÜíL(X) satisfying
2C(t)C(s) = C(t + s) + C(t ‚àís),
s,t ‚ààR,
C(0) = I.
In that case there exist M ‚©æ1, œâ ‚ààR such that

 ‚©ΩMeœât,

Moreover, there is a unique operator A such that (œâ,‚àû) ‚äÇœÅ(A) and

for all x ‚ààX, Œª > œâ. We call A the generator of C. The cosine function C generated by A

THEOREM [[ABHN01], Section 3.14.11]. Let A be an operator on a Banach space X.
The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) A generates a cosine function;
(ii) there exists a Banach space W such that D(A) ‚äÇW ‚ÜíX, and the operator

with domain D(A) √ó W generates a C0-semigroup on W √ó X.
In that case the Banach space W is uniquely determined by property (ii). We call
W √ó X the phase space of problem (5.7). The phase space is important to produce classical
solutions:
PROPOSITION [[ABHN01], Section 3.14.12]. Let A be the generator of a cosine function,
with phase space W √ó X. Then, for each x ‚ààD(A), y ‚ààW, there exists a unique solution
u ‚ààC2(R,X) ‚à©C(R,D(A)) of (5.7).
So far we have described well-posedness of the second-order Cauchy problem (5.7) in
arbitrary Banach spaces. Now we come back to the initial subject of this section.
5.6.4. Squares of group generators and cosine functions.
On UMD-spaces one has the
following characterization.
THEOREM (Fattorini [[ABHN01], Section 3.16.8]). Let A be an operator on a UMD-spa-
ce X. The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) A generates a cosine function;

48
W. Arendt
(ii) there exist a generator B of a C0-group on X and œâ ‚©æ0 such that
A = B2 + œâI.
In that case, the phase space is D(B) √ó X, where D(B) carries the graph norm.
This theorem explains why Lp-spaces for p Ã∏= 2 are not so good as functional frame-
work for hyperbolic problems: There are not many groups operating on Lp for p Ã∏= 2. For
example, the Laplacian  generates a cosine function on Lp(Rn) if and only if p = 2
or n = 1. On the other hand, on Hilbert spaces there are many C0-groups since there are
many self-adjoint operators. This explains from an abstract point of view why many exam-
ples of well-posed second-order problems exist on Hilbert space (see Section 8.9). In view
of the results mentioned so far, they all are related to self-adjoint operators.
5.6.5. Forms and cosine functions.
Let H be a Hilbert space. If ‚àíA generates a co-
sine function, then it follows from Sections 5.6.4 and 5.6.2 that A + œâ ‚ààH ‚àûfor œâ large
enough. Thus, after changing the scalar product on H , the operator A is associated with
a closed form. Now let us assume that A is associated with a coercive, continuous form
a :V √ó V ‚ÜíC, where V ‚Üíd H . Assume in addition that ‚àíA generates a cosine function.
Then by Fattorini‚Äôs theorem [[ABHN01], Section 3.16.7] B = iA1/2 generates a C0-group.
Thus, the phase space is D(A1/2)√óH . Now it becomes apparent why the square root prop-
erty is interesting in this context. The given known space is V (for example in applications,
V may be a Sobolev space). One would like to know whether V √ó H is the phase space of
the second-order Cauchy problem.
5.6.6. Numerical range in a parabola.
If A is an operator on a Hilbert space, then
A comes from a form if and only if the numerical range of A
W(A) =

(Ax|x)H: x ‚ààD(A),‚à•x‚à•= 1

is contained in a sector Œ£Œ∏ + œâ for some œâ ‚ààR, Œ∏ ‚àà[0,œÄ/2) and (‚àí‚àû,œâ) ‚à©œÅ(A) Ã∏= ‚àÖ
(see Section 5.3.4). Now assume that ‚àíA is the generator of a cosine function. Then the
spectrum œÉ(A) is contained in a parabola
Pœâ =

Œæ + iŒ∑ ‚ààC: Œæ ‚©Ωœâ2 ‚àíŒ∑2/4œâ2
for some œâ ‚ààR [[ABHN01], Section 3.14.18]. Recall that œÉ(A) ‚äÇW(A) by [[Kat66],
Section V.3.2].
THEOREM (McIntosh [McI82], Theorems A and C). Let a be a closed densely deÔ¨Åned
form on H with associated operator A. Assume that the numerical range W(A) of A is
contained in a parabola Pœâ for some œâ ‚ààR. Then A has the square root property.
Generators of cosine functions can be characterized by a real condition on the resolvent
[[ABHN01], Section 3.15.3] which is however of little practical use. Much more interesting
is the following most remarkable new criterion:

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
49
THEOREM (Crouzeix [Cro03]). Let a :V √ó V ‚ÜíC be a closed densely deÔ¨Åned form on
a Hilbert space H such that
a(u,u) ‚ààPœâ,
u ‚ààV,‚à•u‚à•H = 1,
for some œâ ‚ààR. Then the associated operator generates a cosine function.
Haase [Haa03a], Corollary 5.18, proved that also the converse implication holds: If
A generates a cosine function on a Hilbert space, then there exist an equivalent scalar
product (¬∑|¬∑)1 on H , a closed form a : V √ó V ‚ÜíC on H with V ‚Üíd H such that ‚àíA is
associated with the form a on (H,(¬∑|¬∑)1) and
a(u,u) ‚ààPœâ,
u ‚ààV,‚à•u‚à•H = 1,
for some œâ ‚ààR. Thus, in view of Section 5.3.4 we can formulate the following beautiful
characterization.
COROLLARY. Let A be an operator on a Hilbert space H . The following assertions are
equivalent:
(i) A generates a cosine function;
(ii) there exists an equivalent scalar product (¬∑|¬∑)1 on H and œâ ‚ààR such that
‚àí(Au|u)1 ‚ààPœâ,
u ‚ààD(A),‚à•u‚à•H = 1,
and œÅ(‚àíA) ‚à©Pœâ Ã∏= ‚àÖ.
6. Fourier multipliers and maximal regularity
The Fourier transform is a classical tool to treat differential equations. In order to apply
it to partial differential equations, vector-valued functions have to be considered. Prob-
lems of regularity, but also of asymptotic behavior, can frequently be reformulated as the
question whether a certain operator is an Lp-Fourier multiplier. Michlin‚Äôs theorem gives
a most convenient criterion for this. It was Weis [Wei00a] (after previous work by Cl√©ment
et al. [CPSW00]) who discovered the right formulation of Michlin‚Äôs theorem in the vector-
valued case.
We describe the situation in the periodic case which is technically easier, and ideas
become more transparent in this case. Still, the periodic case leads to the main application,
namely characterization of maximal regularity for the nonhomogeneous Cauchy problem.
6.1. Vector-valued Fourier series and periodic multipliers
It was the study of the heat equation which lead Fourier to the introduction of one of the
most fundamental concepts of Analysis. In the same spirit, vector-valued Fourier series
help us to understand arbitrary abstract evolution equations.

50
W. Arendt

6.1.1. Multipliers on Hilbert spaces.
If H is a Hilbert space, then the Fourier transform
f ‚ÜíÀÜf is an isometric isomorphism of L2
2œÄ(H) onto ‚Ñì2(H) (the space of all sequences
(xk)k‚ààZ in ‚Ñì2(H) such that 
k‚ààZ ‚à•xk‚à•2 < ‚àû). This follows easily from the scalar case by
considering an orthonormal basis of H . As a consequence, if H is a Hilbert space, then a
sequence (Mk)k‚ààZ ‚äÇL(H) is an L2
2œÄ-multiplier if and only if it is bounded. If 1 < p < ‚àû
and p Ã∏= 2, then multipliers can no longer be characterized in a satisfying way, even in

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
51
the scalar case. An important subject of harmonic analysis is to Ô¨Ånd sufÔ¨Åcient conditions.
In the scalar case the following is a special case of Marcinkiewicz‚Äô multiplier theorem.
We state it on Hilbert space (where it is a special case of the Theorem in Section 6.1.5).
THEOREM. Let H be a Hilbert space and let (Mk)k‚ààZ ‚äÇL(H) be a bounded sequence
satisfying
sup

 < ‚àû.
(M1)
Then (Mk)k‚ààZ is an Lp
2œÄ-multiplier for 1 < p < ‚àû.
6.1.2. Characterization of Hilbert spaces.
Even if p = 2, the Theorem in Section 6.1.1
does no longer hold for Banach spaces other than Hilbert space.
THEOREM. Let X be a Banach space and let 1 < p < ‚àû. Assume that each bounded
sequence (Mk)k‚ààZ ‚äÇL(X) satisfying (M1) is an Lp
2œÄ-multiplier. Then X is isomorphic to
Hilbert space.
An explicit proof of this theorem is given in [ArBu03b], Proposition 1.17. It is based on
a deep characterization of Hilbert spaces due to Kwapien. It was Pisier (unpublished) who
had discovered that certain classical operator-valued multiplier theorems hold merely on
Hilbert spaces.
6.1.3. UMD-spaces and the Riesz-projection.
In order to obtain an operator-valued mul-
tiplier result one has to replace boundedness in operator norm in (M1) by a stronger as-
sumption (R-boundedness), and a restricted class of Banach spaces has to be considered.
DEFINITION. Let X be a Banach space. For k ‚ààZ, let
Mk =
I
if k ‚©æ0,
0
if k < 0.
(6.3)
We say that X is a UMD-space if the sequence (Mk)k‚ààZ is an Lp
2œÄ(X)-multiplier for all
(equivalently one) p ‚àà(1,‚àû). The associated operator R is called the Riesz-projection.
Note that the sequence (6.3) satisÔ¨Åes condition (M1) of Section 6.1.1.
The letters UMD stay for ‚Äúunconditional martingale differences‚Äù and refer to an equiv-
alent property introduced and studied by Burkholder [Bur83]. Here we will not be con-
fronted with martingales and use the term UMD just for saying that the Riesz-projection is
bounded.
EXAMPLES. (a) The space Lq(Y) is a UMD-space if 1 < q < ‚àûfor any œÉ-Ô¨Ånite measure
space (Y,Œ£,Œº).
(b) Every closed subspace of a UMD-space is a UMD-space.

W. Arendt
(c) Each UMD-space is reÔ¨Çexive (even superreÔ¨Çexive).
(d) It follows from (a)‚Äì(c) that, for any nonempty open subset Œ© of Rn, the Sobolev
space W k,p(Œ©) is a UMD-space if and only if 1 < p < ‚àû, where k ‚ààN0.
(e) If Œ© ‚äÇRn is a nonempty open bounded set, then C( 
Œ©) is not a UMD-space.
6.1.4. R-boundedness.
In order to formulate an operator-valued version of Marcinkie-
wicz‚Äôs theorem we need a new notion of boundedness for sets of operators. Recall that
a series ‚àû
k=1 xk in a Banach space is called unconditionally convergent if the series
‚àû
k=1 Œµkxk converges for any choice of signs (Œµk)k‚ààN ‚àà{‚àí1,1}N. This implies conver-
gences of ‚àû
k=1 Œ±kxk for each Œ± = (Œ±k)k‚ààN ‚àà‚Ñì‚àû. But in general, this does not imply that
‚àû
k=1 ‚à•xk‚à•< ‚àû, unless X is Ô¨Ånite dimensional. We introduce the means over all signs
(x1,...,xn)


DEFINITION. Let X,Y be Banach spaces. A subset T of L(X,Y) is called R-bounded if
there exists a constant c ‚©æ0 such that
(T1x1,...,Tnxn)

for all T1,...,Tn ‚ààT , x1,...,xn ‚ààX, n ‚ààN. The least constant c such that (6.5) is satis-

The notion of R-boundedness was introduced by Berkson and Gillespie [BG94], where
the ‚ÄúR‚Äù stands for ‚ÄòRiesz‚Äô. Since the mean
(x1,...,xn)

R
can be expressed in terms of Rademacher functions some pronounce it ‚ÄúRademacher

sort of unconditional boundedness.
R-boundedness clearly implies boundedness. But if X = Y, the notion of R-bounded-
ness is strictly stronger than boundedness unless the underlying space is a Hilbert space
[ArBu02], Proposition 1.17.
6.1.5. The operator-valued Marcinkiewicz theorem.
On an arbitrary Banach space, in
general it is a difÔ¨Åcult task to verify R-boundedness (we will come back to this point
later). Nevertheless, for multipliers it is the right notion as the following two results show.
First of all, we state that it is a necessary condition.
PROPOSITION ([ArBu02], [CP01]). Let (Mk)k‚ààZ ‚äÇL(X) be an Lp
2œÄ-multiplier for some
1 < p < ‚àû. Then the set {Mk: k ‚ààZ} is R-bounded.

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
53
If in Marcinkiewicz‚Äôs theorem we replace boundedness by R-boundedness, the theorem
remains true on UMD-spaces (see [ArBu02], Theorem 1.3).
THEOREM (The operator-valued Marcinkiewicz theorem). Let X be a UMD-space. Let
(Mk)k‚ààZ ‚äÇL(X) be R-bounded. Assume that

k(Mk+1 ‚àíMk): k ‚ààZ

is R-bounded. Then (Mk)k‚ààZ is an Lp
2œÄ-multiplier whenever 1 < p < ‚àû.
We remark that a set of scalar operators (i.e., operators of the form c ¬∑ I, where c ‚ààC)
is bounded if and only if it is R-bounded. In that case, the Theorem had been proved by
Cl√©ment, de Pagter, Sukochev and Witvliet [CPSW00]. It was Weis [Wei00a] who proved
the Ô¨Årst operator-valued multiplier theorem on UMD-spaces, namely the operator-valued
version of Michlin‚Äôs theorem on the real line.
6.1.6. The variational Marcinkiewicz‚Äô condition.
Finally we state the original, more gen-
eral version of Marcinkiewicz‚Äôs theorem. It holds in Hilbert spaces as was shown by
Schwartz [Schw61].
THEOREM. Let X be a Hilbert space and let (Mk)k‚ààZ ‚äÇL(X) be a bounded sequence
satisfying
sup
n‚ààN

2n‚àí1‚©Ω|k|<2n
‚à•Mk+1 ‚àíMk‚à•< ‚àû.
(MV)
Then (Mk)k‚ààZ is an Lp
2œÄ-multiplier for 1 < p < ‚àû.
We call (MV) the variational Marcinkiewicz condition. There is a version on UMD-spa-
ces due to Strkalj and Weis [SW00]. But the ‚ÄúR-version‚Äù of being of uniform bounded
variation on dyadic intervals is more complicated to formulate.
Finally we mention a remarkable difference between the variational Marcinkiewicz con-
dition and the stronger condition (M1) of Section 6.1.1. In the scalar case, if (M1) is sat-
isÔ¨Åed the associated operator is of weak type (1,1). This does not hold, if merely the more
general condition (MV ) is satisÔ¨Åed (see Fournier‚Äôs example [[EG77], Section 7.5]).
6.2. Maximal regularity via periodic multipliers

6.2.1. Mild and strong Lp-solutions.
Recall the notion of mild solution of Px(f )
given in Section 1.5. We now deÔ¨Åne a stronger notion of solution. Let 1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû.

u‚Ä≤ ‚ààLp((0,œÑ);X) such that
u(t) = u(0) +
 t
0

t ‚àà[0,œÑ].
(6.6)
Then u‚Ä≤(t) is the derivative of u a.e. Let f ‚ààLp((0,œÑ);X). A strong Lp-solution u
of Px(f ) is a function u ‚ààW 1,p((0,œÑ);X) ‚à©Lp((0,œÑ);D(A)) such that u(0) = x and
u‚Ä≤(t) = Au(t) + f (t) a.e. on (0,œÑ). Each strong solution is also a mild solution. Con-
versely, since A is closed, a mild solution u of Px(f ) is a strong Lp-solution if and only
if u ‚ààW 1,p((0,œÑ);X). Now assume that A is the generator of a C0-semigroup T . Then,
by Section 1.5, u = T (¬∑)x + T ‚àóf is the unique mild solution of Px(f ). Thus, we are lead
to investigate under which conditions T (¬∑)x ‚ààW 1,p((0,œÑ);X). We start to consider the
case f = 0.

6.2.3. Strong solutions of periodic problems.
Let A be a closed operator on a Banach
space X. For f ‚ààLp((0,2œÄ);X), we consider the periodic problem
Pper(f )
u‚Ä≤(t) = Au(t) + f (t),
t ‚àà[0,2œÄ],
u(0) = u(2œÄ).
A strong Lp-solution of Pper(f ) is a function u ‚ààW 1,p((0,œÑ);X) ‚à©Lp((0,œÑ);D(A))
such that (Pper) is satisÔ¨Åed t-a.e. We may identify Lp((0,2œÄ);X) and Lp
2œÄ(R,X). Then it
is not difÔ¨Åcult to see the following.
PROPOSITION. Let 1 < p < ‚àû. The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) For each f ‚ààLp((0,2œÄ);X), there exists a unique strong Lp-solution of Pper(f );
(ii) iZ ‚äÇœÅ(A) and (kR(ik,A))k‚ààZ is an Lp-multiplier.

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
55
Let us consider a Hilbert space H . Then we obtain the following theorem.
THEOREM. Let 1 < p < ‚àû. Let A be a closed operator on a Hilbert space H . The fol-
lowing are equivalent:
(i) iZ ‚äÇœÅ(A) and supk‚ààZ ‚à•kR(ik,A)‚à•< ‚àû;
(ii) for all f ‚ààLp, there exists a unique strong Lp-solution of Pper(f ).
For the implication (i) ‚áí(ii) one considers Mk = kR(ik,A). The resolvent identity
implies that (k(Mk+1‚àíMk))k‚ààZ is bounded. Thus assertion (ii) follows from Section 6.1.1.
Similarly, one obtains from Section 6.1.5 the following characterization on UMD-spaces.
THEOREM [ArBu02]. Let A be a closed operator on a UMD-space X and let 1 < p < ‚àû.
The following are equivalent:
(i) iZ ‚äÇœÅ(A) and {kR(ik,A): k ‚ààZ} is R-bounded;
(ii) for all f ‚ààLp((0,2œÄ);X), there exists a unique strong Lp-solution of (Pper).
Two things are remarkable:
1. Condition (ii), i.e., well-posedness of the periodic problem in the sense of strong
Lp-solutions, is p-independent for 1 < p < ‚àû.
2. Whereas no characterization of Lp-multipliers seems possible in general (if 1 <
p < ‚àû, p Ã∏= 2), in the context of resolvents, it is.
Finally, we remark that A satisÔ¨Åes the equivalent conditions of the theorem if and only
if ‚àíA does so. In particular, A need not be the generator of a C0-semigroup.
6.2.4. Maximal regularity on Hilbert space.
Let X be a Banach space. Assume that
A generates a holomorphic semigroup T . Then, for f ‚ààL1((0,œÑ);X), x ‚ààX,
u = T (¬∑)x + T ‚àóf
is the unique mild solution of Px(f ). We want to investigate when the solution is strong.
If f ‚â°0, this is done in Section 6.2.2. Thus we may consider x = 0, i.e., we want to
investigate P0(f ).
THEOREM. Let A be the generator of a holomorphic C0-semigroup T on a Hilbert
space H . Then
T ‚àóf ‚ààW 1,p
(0,œÑ);X
	
for all f ‚ààLp
(0,œÑ);X

(6.8)
PROOF. Let œÑ = 2œÄ. Replacing A by A ‚àíœâ we may assume that Œª ‚ààœÅ(A) when-
ever ReŒª ‚©æ0 and ‚à•ŒªR(Œª,A)‚à•‚©ΩM. Let f ‚ààLp((0,œÑ);H). Then by the Ô¨Årst the-
