‚ñ°

56
W. Arendt
Property (6.8) is frequently called maximal regularity, or (MR) for short. Thus, on
Hilbert space, every generator of a holomorphic C0-semigroup does enjoy this prop-
erty (MR). It is also known that (MR) implies holomorphy of the semigroup (see Sec-
tion 6.2.6).
6.2.5. Characterization of Hilbert space.
For a long time it has been an open problem
whether the preceding theorem holds more generally on UMD-spaces. However, the an-
swer is negative.
THEOREM (Kalton and Lancien [KL00]). Let X be a Banach space possessing an uncon-
ditional basis. Let 1 < p < ‚àû. If X is not isomorphic to a Hilbert space, then there exist
a holomorphic C0-semigroup T and f ‚ààLp((0,œÑ);X) such that T ‚àóf /‚ààW 1,p((0,œÑ);X).
The semigroup T is not constructed directly, the existence of such semigroup T is proved
implicitly using several deep results of geometry of Banach spaces. However one can say
that the generator A of T is a block-diagonal operator with respect to some conditional
basis in X.
It is an open problem whether the Theorem does also hold in Banach spaces with condi-
tional bases. Also, so far no explicit counterexample, and in particular, no model is known
for which (MR) fails.
6.2.6. Maximal regularity on UMD-spaces.
On UMD-spaces, with the same proof as in
Section 6.2.4 based on the periodic operator-valued multiplier theorem of Section 6.1.5
one obtains the following characterization.
THEOREM (Weis). Assume that X is a UMD-space. Let A be a closed operator, œÑ > 0,
1 < p < ‚àû. The following are equivalent:
(i) for all f ‚ààLp((0,œÑ);X), there exists a unique u ‚ààW 1,p((0,œÑ);X) ‚à©Lp((0,œÑ);
D(A)) such that
u‚Ä≤(t) = Au(t) + f (t)
a.e.,
u(0) = 0;
(ii) there exist œâ ‚ààR such that Œª ‚ààœÅ(A) whenever ReŒª > œâ and the set {ŒªR(Œª,A):
ReŒª > œâ} is R-bounded.
It was Weis [Wei00a] who proved that (ii) implies (i), Cl√©ment and Pr√ºss [CP01] showed
necessity of the condition. Weis gave a different proof (than we indicated here), based on
his operator-valued Michlin‚Äôs theorem on the real line.
DEFINITION. We say that an operator A satisÔ¨Åes condition (MR) (for maximal regularity)
if condition (i) is satisÔ¨Åed.
It can be seen from the Theorem that property (MR) is independent of p ‚àà(1,‚àû) and
of œÑ > 0. Moreover, (MR) implies that A generates a holomorphic semigroup T . Thus, the

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
57
solution u of (i) is given by u = T ‚àóf . If A satisÔ¨Åes (MR) then the existence of strong
Lp-solutions on the entire half-line (0,‚àû) is merely a question of the asymptotic behavior
of T as the following result shows. See Section 1.3 for the deÔ¨Ånition of œâ(T ).
THEOREM. Let A be the generator of a holomorphic C0-semigroup T on a Banach
space X. The following assertions are equivalent:
(i) A satisÔ¨Åes (MR) and œâ(T ) < 0;
(ii) T ‚àóf ‚ààW 1,p((0,‚àû),X) ‚à©Lp((0,‚àû);D(A)) for all f ‚ààLp((0,‚àû);X).
PROOF. (ii) ‚áí(i) follows from Datko‚Äôs theorem [[ABHN01], p. 336]. For (ii) ‚áí(i),
see [Dor00], Theorem 5.2.
‚ñ°
Finally, we mention that the restriction to p ‚àà(1,‚àû) is essential. If A generates
a C0-semigroup T on a reÔ¨Çexive space X such that T ‚àóf ‚ààW 1,1((0,1);X) for all
f ‚ààL1((0,1);X), then A is bounded (see [Gue95]).
6.2.7. Perturbation of (MR).
In general it is not at all easy to prove R-boundedness.
However, it is not difÔ¨Åcult to see that condition (ii) of the preceding theorem is stable
under small perturbation (see [KuWe01], [ArBu02]).
THEOREM. Let A be an operator satisfying (MR) on a UMD-space X. Then there exists
Œµ > 0 such that, for each linear B :D(A) ‚ÜíX,
‚à•Bx‚à•‚©ΩŒµ‚à•Ax‚à•+ b‚à•x‚à•,
x ‚ààD(A),
for some b ‚©æ0, also A + B satisÔ¨Åes (MR).
6.2.8. BIP and maximal regularity.
An important criterion for maximal regularity is
property BIP. The following theorem is due to Dore and Venni [DoVe87].
THEOREM. Let A ‚ààBIP on a UMD-space X such that œïbip(A) < œÄ/2. Then ‚àíA has
property (MR).
We sketch two different proofs.
FIRST PROOF. One can show directly that BIP implies that for œïbip < œï < œÄ/2 one has
œÉ(A) ‚äÇŒ£œï and that the set {ŒªR(Œª,A): Œª ‚ààC\Œ£œï} is R-bounded, [DHP01], Theorem 4.5.
Thus the Ô¨Årst theorem of Section 6.2.6 can be applied.
‚ñ°
SECOND PROOF [DOVE87]. The space Y = Lp((0,œÑ);X) has the UMD-property and
the operator A on Lp((0,œÑ);X) given by (Au)(t) = Au(t) with domain D(A) =
Lp((0,œÑ);D(A)) obviously inherits BIP from A with angle œïbip(A) ‚©Ωœïbip(A). On the
other hand, the operator B on Lp((0,œÑ);X) given by D(B) = W 1,p
0
((0,œÑ);X),Bu = u‚Ä≤,
has BIP with angle œïbip(B) = œÄ/2 (see [HP97] or [DoVe87]). Assuming that 0 ‚ààœÅ(A), it
follows from the Dore‚ÄìVenni theorem (Section 4.4.8) that A + B is closed. The Theorem
of Section 4.2 shows that A + B is invertible. This is exactly property (MR).

6.2.9. Maximal regularity for positive contraction semigroups on Lp(Œ©).
The character-
ization of maximal regularity by R-sectoriality 6.2.11 (and Section 4.7.5) has the following
interesting consequence [Wei00b].
THEOREM (Lamberton and Weis). Let 1 < p < ‚àû. Let ‚àíA be the generator of a positive
contractive C0-semigroup T on Lp(Œ©). If T is holomorphic, then A has (MR).
This result had been Ô¨Årst proved by Lamberton [Lam87] in the case where T is also
contractive for the L‚àû- and L1-norm.
6.2.10. Maximal regularity and quasi-linear problems.
The property of maximal regu-
larity is most important in order to solve quasi-linear problems. Here we give a result on
local existence.
Let X be a UMD-space and let D be a Banach space such that D ‚Üíd X. Let 1 < p < ‚àû
and Y = (X,D)1/p‚àó,p, where 1/p + 1/p‚àó= 1. Let A:Y ‚ÜíL(D,X) be Lipschitz contin-
uous on each bounded subset of Y. Let u0 ‚ààY and assume that the operator ‚àíA(u0) on X
with domain D(A(u0)) = D has property (MR). Then the following result holds.
THEOREM (Cl√©ment and Li [CL94]). For each f ‚ààLp
loc((0,‚àû);X), there exist œÑ > 0 and

6.2.11. R-sectorial operators.
As we mentioned before, on Hilbert space (and only
on Hilbert space), boundedness and R-boundedness are the same. On the other hand,
it turns out that many results known for Hilbert spaces can be carried over to Lp-spaces,
1 < p < ‚àû, if boundedness is replaced by R-boundedness. The operator-valued
Marcinkiewicz of Section 6.1.5 and the Michlin multiplier theorem [Wei00a] are of this
kind. We mention some further results. We say that an operator A is R-sectorial if there

Semigroups and evolution equations: Functional calculus, regularity and kernel estimates
59
exists 0 < œï < œÄ such that œÉ(A) ‚äÇŒ£œï and such that the set {ŒªR(Œª,A): Œª ‚ààC \ Œ£œï} is
R-bounded. In that case let œïR sec(A) be the inÔ¨Åmum of all angles with these properties.
On a UMD-space an operator A has property (MR) if and only if A + œâ is R-sectorial
for some œâ ‚ààR.
In analogy to Section 5.1 one has the following results. Assume that X = Lp(Œ©),
1 < p < ‚àû.
If A has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus, then A is R-sectorial and œïH ‚àû(A) = œïR sec(A).
Moreover, if B is a second R-sectorial operator commuting with A such that œïH ‚àû(A) +
œïR sec(B) < œÄ, then A + B is closed.
For this and many other interesting properties we refer to [Wei00a], [Wei00b]
and [KW01].
7. Gaussian estimates and ultracontractivity
Frequently it is easy to deÔ¨Åne a semigroup on L2(Œ©) with the help of form methods for ex-
ample. In this section we discuss under which conditions such a semigroup can be extended
to Lp(Œ©). An important item is to investigate whether semigroup properties (as holo-
morphy, maximal regularity, H ‚àû-calculus) extrapolate to Lp. Integral representations by
Gaussian kernels play a big role.
7.1. The Beurling‚ÄìDeny criteria
For simplicity we consider real spaces in this section. Let H be a real Hilbert space. Let
V ‚Üíd H be another Hilbert space and a :V √ó V ‚ÜíR a continuous bilinear form which is
H -elliptic, i.e.,
a(u,u) + œâ‚à•u‚à•2
H ‚©æŒ±‚à•u‚à•2
V ,
u ‚ààV,
for some œâ ‚ààR, Œ± > 0. Recall that this is the same as saying that a is a closed form with
form domain D(a) = V . Denote by A the operator associated with a (see Section 5.3.1).
Then ‚àíA generates a C0-semigroup T on H which has a holomorphic extension to HC,
the complexiÔ¨Åcation of H . In the following we assume that H = L2(Œ©) for some measure
space (Œ©,Œ£,Œº) so that HC = L2(Œ©,C). We let V+ = V ‚à©L2(Œ©)+.
7.1.1. Theorem (First Beurling‚ÄìDeny criterion).
The semigroup T is positive if and only
if u ‚ààV implies u+ ‚ààV and

Here, for u ‚ààL2(Œ©), we let u+(x) = max{u(x),0}, u‚àí= (‚àíu)+. The next condition
characterizes L‚àû-contractivity. An operator S on L2(Œ©) is called submarkovian if S ‚©æ0
and ‚à•Sf ‚à•‚àû‚©Ω‚à•f ‚à•‚àûfor all f ‚ààL2(Œ©) ‚à©L‚àû(Œ©). A semigroup T on L2(Œ©) is called
submarkovian if each T (t) is submarkovian.
7.1.2. Theorem (Second Beurling‚ÄìDeny criterion).
Assume that the semigroup T is pos-
itive. Then T is submarkovian if and only if u ‚àß1 ‚ààV for each u ‚ààV+ and

We refer to [Ouh92], [[Ouh04]] for a proof of these criteria. Note that T ‚àóis associated with
a‚àó:V √ó V ‚ÜíR given by a‚àó(u,v) = a(v,u). If T and T ‚àóare submarkovian, then

p ‚àà(1,‚àû). The form a is called a Dirichlet form if the two criteria of Beurling‚ÄìDeny are
satisÔ¨Åed. If in addition the form a is symmetric (i.e., a = a‚àó), then the semigroup T consists
of self-adjoint operators satisfying (7.1). Each C0-semigroup of symmetric submarkov-
ian operators is associated with a symmetric Dirichlet form. The monographs [[FOT94]],
[[MR86]], [[BH91]] are devoted to the theory of Dirichlet forms and their important and
interesting interplay with stochastic processes. Here we are merely interested in analyti-
cal properties.
7.1.3. Domination [Ouh96].
Let a and b be two closed forms on L2(Œ©) with associ-
ated semigroups S and T , respectively. Assume that S and T are positive. The following
assertions are equivalent:
(i) S(t) ‚©ΩT (t), t ‚©æ0;
(ii) (a) D(a) ‚äÇD(b) and for u ‚ààD(b), if 0 ‚©Ωu ‚©Ωv ‚ààD(a), then u ‚ààD(a) (ideal
property), and
(b) a(u,v) ‚©Ωb(u,v) for all 0 ‚©Ωu, v ‚ààD(a) (monotonicity).
We mention two prototype examples.

7.2.3. Proofs and comments.
We comment on the diverse properties. The Ô¨Årst three
(a)‚Äì(c) concern regularity of the semigroup.
(a) Let 1 < p < 2, 1
p = Œ∏
1 + 1‚àíŒ∏
2 . Then by the Riesz‚ÄìThorin theorem ‚à•Tp(t) ‚àíI‚à•‚©Ω
‚à•T1(t) ‚àíI‚à•Œ∏‚à•T2(t) ‚àíI‚à•1‚àíŒ∏ ‚Üí0 as t ‚Üì0. This implies that Ap is bounded.
(b) This is a consequence of Stein‚Äôs interpolation theorem (cf. [[Dav90], Theo-
rem 1.4.2]). But a similar proof as for (a) can be given for contraction semigroups
using the following result (see [[Paz83], p. 68]).
THEOREM (Kato‚ÄìNeuberger‚ÄìPazy). Let 1 < p < ‚àûand let T be a C0-semigroup
on Lp(Œ©) such that ‚à•T (t)‚à•‚©Ω1, t ‚©æ0. Then T is holomorphic if and only if
limt‚Üì0‚à•T (t) ‚àíI‚à•< 2.
Now the argument of (a) also gives a proof of (b).
(c) The argument of (a) also gives a proof of (c).
(d) This is [[Dav90], Theorem 1.6.1 and Corollary 1.6.2]. Properties (f ) and (g) are
trivial. Here a semigroup is called positive, if it leaves the real space invariant and
its restriction to the real space is positive.
(i) Example 4.5.3 provides a counterexample where the semigroups extrapolate to
Lp merely for 1 < p < ‚àû, the operator A2 has H ‚àû-calculus, but Ap has not
H ‚àû-calculus for p Ã∏= 2. We do not know such an example where the semigroups
extrapolate to Lp for 1 ‚©Ωp ‚©Ω‚àû.
Next we give some interesting examples showing, in particular, that the positive results
in (b), (c) or (d) cannot be extended to p = 1.

on Lp(R,e‚àíx2 dx) with maximal domain. Then Ap generates a C0-semigroup Tp on

for 1 < p < ‚àû, but T1 is not norm continuous on [t0,‚àû) for any t0 > 0. Ap has

œÉ(A1) = {Œª ‚ààC: ReŒª ‚©æ0}. Thus A1 has not a compact resolvent.

7.2.6. Symmetric submarkovian semigroups, optimal angles and the Neumann Laplacian
on horn domains.
Let A2 be the generator of a symmetric submarkovian semigroup T2
on L2(Œ©) and denote by Tp the C0-semigroup on Lp(Œ©) with generator Ap extrapolat-
ing T2, 1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû. Then Liskevich and Perelmuter [LP95] showed that the angle ob-
tained by the Stein interpolation theorem can be improved. In fact, Tp has a holomorphic,
contractive extension to the sector Œ£Œ∏p, where 0 ‚©ΩŒ∏p < œÄ
2 such that cosŒ∏p = |1 ‚àí2/p|.
In particular, the spectrum of Ap is contained in the sector

It was Voigt [Voi96] who Ô¨Årst showed that this sector is optimal. In fact, modifying Ex-
ample 7.2.5 he constructed a degenerate elliptic operator Ap on Lp(0,‚àû)2 such that the
spectrum of Ap is equal to Sp.
Another interesting example in this context is the symmetric Ornstein‚ÄìUhlenbeck op-
erator Ap on Lp(Rn,Œº), where Œº is the invariant measure. It generates a symmetric sub-
markovian semigroup Tp on Lp(Rn,Œº). Metafune, Pallara and Priola [MPP02] computed
explicitly the spectrum and showed that it is independent of p ‚àà[1,‚àû). In particular,
the spectrum of Ap is real for all p ‚àà[1,‚àû). However, Chill, Fa≈°angov√°, Metafune and
Pallara [CFMP03] showed that Œ£Œ∏p is the sector of holomorphy of Tp, i.e., the worst case
is realized for the symmetric Ornstein‚ÄìUhlenstein semigroup.
Kunstmann [Kun02] constructed an open unbounded domain Œ© in Rn (which is com-
posed by inÔ¨Ånitely many ‚Äúhorn domains‚Äù) such that the Neumann Laplacian has bad in-
terpolation properties. In particular, for a domain Œ© composed by inÔ¨Ånitely many horn
domains the spectrum of the Neumann Laplacian N
Œ©,p in Lp(Œ©) depends on p. Moreover,
the semigroup (etN
Œ©,1)t‚©æ0 is not holomorphic in L1(Œ©). In fact, it is not even eventually
norm continuous since the spectrum of N
Œ©,1 is the left-half plane.
Concerning the functional calculus, one can say the following: given a symmetric sub-
markovian semigroup T2 with extension semigroups Tp on Lp(Œ©), by Section 4.7.5 the
negative generator Ap of Tp has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus and
œïR sec(Ap) = œïH ‚àû(Ap),

[KS03] showed that œïH ‚àû(Ap) < œïs(Ap) for 1 < p < ‚àû, p Ã∏= 2. Still, it seems to be open
whether always œïH ‚àû(Ap) = Œ∏p.
7.3. Ultracontractivity, kernels and Sobolev embedding
In this section we consider a semigroup T on L2(Œ©) which is regularizing in the Lp-sense:
We will ask that T (t)L2(Œ©) ‚äÇLq(Œ©) for some q > 2. This property implies in particular
that T (t) is an integral operator. Throughout this section (Œ©,Œ£,Œº) is a measure space.

If the generator A of T is associated with a closed form with form domain V ‚ÜíL2(Œ©)
such that V ‚à©L1(Œ©) is dense in L1(Œ©) and if n > 2, then these four conditions are also
equivalent to
(v) V ‚ÜíL2n/(n‚àí2)(Œ©).
We call a semigroup ultracontractive if the equivalent conditions (i) and (ii) are satisÔ¨Åed.
The number dim(T ) = inf{n > 0: (i) is valid} is called the semigroup dimension. Note
that n is not entire, in general. It was Varopoulos who startet a systematic investigation
of the dimension of a semigroup, mainly in the framework of symmetric submarkovian
semigroups. We refer to [[VSC93]], [[Sal02]], [[Dav90]] for the historical references and
further results.

7.3.6. The extension property.
An open set Œ© ‚äÇRn has the extension property if the re-
striction mapping R :W 1,2(Rn) ‚ÜíW 1,2(Œ©) is surjective. Then R0 :(kerR)‚ä•‚ÜíW 1,2(Œ©)

7.3.7. The Neumann Laplacian.

7.4. Gaussian estimates
Let Œ© ‚äÇRn be an open set and let T be a C0-semigroup on L2(Œ©) (the L2-space of
complex-valued functions). We identify L2(Œ©) with a subspace of L2(Rn) extending func-
tions on Œ© by 0 on RN \ Œ©. Consider the Gaussian semigroup G on L2(Rn).
DEFINITION. The semigroup T admits a Gaussian estimate if there exist constants c > 0,
b > 0 such that
T (t)f
 ‚©ΩcG(bt)|f |,
0 < t ‚©Ω1,
(7.15)

70
W. Arendt
for all f ‚ààL2(Œ©).
Note that (7.15) is an inequality between measurable functions in the almost everywhere
sense. It is not difÔ¨Åcult to show that it implies an estimate of the form
T (t)f
 ‚©ΩMeœâtG(bt)|f |
(7.16)
for all t > 0, f ‚ààL2(Œ©). By the Dunford‚ÄìPettis criterion this is equivalent to saying that
T (t) = SKt , where Kt ‚ààL‚àû(Œ© √ó Œ©), is a kernel satisfying
Kt(x,y)
 ‚©Ωconst ¬∑ eœâtt‚àín/2e‚àí|x‚àíy|2/4bt,
(x,y)-a.e.
(7.17)
for all t > 0. If T admits a Gaussian estimate then by Section 7.2 (and in particular, Sec-
tion 7.2.1(d)) there exist consistent extrapolation semigroups Tp on Lp(Œ©), 1 ‚©Ωp ‚©Ω‚àû,
such that T2 = T . For 1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû, Tp is a C0-semigroup, T‚àûis w‚àó-continuous. By Ap we
denote the generator of Tp. These notations will be used in the following without further
notice. Our aim is to establish consequences of Gaussian estimates for Tp which allow us
in particular to replace some of the negative answers in the heritage list of Section 7.2.2 by
positive assertions. Later we will see that a large class of elliptic operators generate semi-
groups which satisfy Gaussian estimates. But before that we give two prototype examples.

7.4.2. Remark (Proper domination).
There is a signiÔ¨Åcant difference between the two
examples: For the Dirichlet Laplacian we have proper domination; i.e., the constant c
in (7.15) is equal to 1. But this is the only realization of the Laplacian with this property:
Let Œ© ‚äÇRn be open. We assume that Œ© is stable (see Section 5.4.5). Let S be a positive,
symmetric C0-semigroup on L2(Œ©) such that S(t) ‚©ΩG2(t), 0 < t ‚©Ω1. Assume that the
generator A of S satisÔ¨Åes D(Œ©) ‚äÇD(A) and Au = u for all u ‚ààD(Œ©). Then A = D
Œ©.
PROOF. (a) We consider L2(Œ©) as a subspace of L2(Rn), extending functions by 0. Then
S(t) = (1Œ©S(t/n))n ‚©Ω(1Œ©G2(t/n))n for all n ‚ààN. Since limn‚Üí‚àû(1Œ©G(t/n))n = etD
Œ©
strongly by Section 5.4.5, we conclude that S(t) ‚©ΩetD
Œ©, 0 < t < ‚àû.
(b) Denote by a :V √ó V ‚ÜíR the symmetric closed form associated with ‚àíA. It fol-
lows from (a) and Section 7.1.3 that V ‚äÇH 1
0 (Œ©). For u, v ‚ààD(Œ©), we have a(u,v) =
‚àí(Au|v)L2 =

‚àáu‚àáv dx. Note that ‚à•u‚à•2
L2 + a(u,u) deÔ¨Ånes an equivalent norm on V .

‚ñ°
The fact that the constant c in (7.15) might be larger than 1 makes it difÔ¨Åcult to prove
Gaussian estimates, and no such simple criteria as in Section 7.1.3 are available. We com-
ment on techniques to prove Gaussian estimates in Section 8.7. Now we establish heritage
properties made possible by Gaussian estimates.
7.4.3. Gaussian estimates and extrapolation of holomorphy.
Let T be a C0-semigroup
on L2(Œ©) which admits a Gaussian estimate. Assume that T is holomorphic of angle
Œ∏ ‚àà(0,œÄ/2]. Then also the extrapolation semigroups Tp are holomorphic of the same
angle Œ∏ for each p ‚àà[1,‚àû].
This result due to Ouhabaz [Ouh95] (see [AtE97], Theorem 5.4, in the nonsymmetric
case) contrasts the examples in Sections 7.2.4 and 7.2.6, where, in absence of Gaussian
estimates, the angle depends on p and where T1 is not holomorphic.
7.4.4. Gaussian estimates and maximal regularity.
Let T be a C0-semigroup on L2(Œ©)
which has Gaussian estimates. If T is holomorphic, then Tp has property (MR) for
1 < p < ‚àû.
This result is most important for applications to nonlinear equations. We refer to Sec-
tion 6.2.6 for the deÔ¨Ånition of (MR) and to [HP97], [CP01], [CD00], [Wei00b] and
[ArBu03a], Corollary 4.5, for proofs of this result.
Recall that holomorphy is a necessary condition for (MR). It may happen that a
semigroup T on L2(Œ©) has Gaussian estimates without being holomorphic. In fact,
Voigt showed that the operator  + ix on L2(R) with suitable domain generates a
C0-semigroup S such that |S(t)f | ‚©ΩG(t)|f |, but S is not holomorphic,cf. [LM97], p. 303.
However, so far no example of a nonholomorphic positive semigroup with Gaussian esti-
mates is known.
7.4.5. Gaussian estimates and H ‚àû-calculus.
Let ‚àíA be the generator of a holomor-
phic C0-semigroup on L2(Œ©) admitting a Gaussian estimate. Assume that (A + œâ) has

72
W. Arendt
a bounded H ‚àû-calculus for some œâ ‚ààR. Then also (Ap +œâ) has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus
for some œâ ‚ààR, for all 1 < p < ‚àû.
This result is due to Duong and Robinson [DR96]. The restriction on Œ© (doubling prop-
erty) made there was removed later by Duong and McIntosh [DM99]. We do not try to op-
timize the rescaling constant œâ in our formulation, but rather refer to [DR96] and [AtE97],
pp. 118 and 122, for this.
We recall that on Hilbert space it sufÔ¨Åces that the semigroup T be quasicontractive to
insure (A + œâ) to have a bounded H ‚àû-calculus for some œâ.
7.4.6. Gaussian estimates and p-independence of the spectrum.
Let T be a C0-semi-
group on Lp(Œ©) admitting a Gaussian estimate. Denote by Tp the extrapolation
C0-semigroup on Lp(Œ©) and by Ap its generator. Then œÉ(Ap) = œÉ(A2), 1 ‚©Ωp ‚©Ω‚àû.
In [Are94] it was proved that the connected component of œÅ(Ap) is p-independent,
the general result was obtained by Kunstmann [Kun99]. An example of special interest
are Schr√∂dinger operators for which the result had been obtained before by Hempel and
Voigt [HV86].
8. Elliptic operators
In this section we apply the results obtained before to semigroups generated by elliptic op-
erators of second order. If the coefÔ¨Åcients and the domain in Rn are smooth, then classical
estimates of Agmon‚ÄìDouglis‚ÄìNirenberg give precise information on the domain. Here we
consider merely measurable coefÔ¨Åcients. Then the domain can no longer be determined.
Under some mild conditions, however, Gaussian estimates can still be proved and lead to
a variety of semigroup and spectral properties. At the end of this chapter we mention also
some results for higher order operators and systems.
Let Œ© ‚äÇRn be an open set. Let aij, bi, ci, a0 ‚ààL‚àû(Œ©), i,j = 1,...,n, be complex-
valued coefÔ¨Åcients. We assume the ellipticity condition

we describe in the following section.

8.5. Gaussian estimates: real coefÔ¨Åcients
Assume that all coefÔ¨Åcients are real valued. Let V be one of the three spaces considered
in Section 8.1. In the case of Neumann or mixed boundary conditions assume that Œ© has
the extension property (in the weak sense of Section 7.3.6). Then TV admits Gaussian
estimates; see [AtE97], [Dan00], [Ouh03]. In particular, we have the following conse-
quences: Denote by Tp the extrapolation semigroup of TV in Lp(Œ©) and by ‚àíAp its gen-
erator. Then
(a) Tp is a holomorphic C0-semigroup, 1 ‚©Ωp < ‚àû.
(b) The operator Ap satisÔ¨Åes (MR), 1 < p < ‚àû.
(c) The operator (Ap + œâ) has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus for œâ large enough and
œïH ‚àû(Ap + œâ) < œÄ/2, where 1 < p < ‚àû.
(d) The spectrum œÉ(Ap) is independent on p ‚àà[1,‚àû].

(e) Asymptotic behavior: Assume that Œ© is connected and bounded. Then there exist u,

This follows from Sections 7.4.3 for (a), 7.4.4 for (b), 7.4.5 for (c), 7.4.6 for (d) and

assertion (c) can already be deduced from (8.4) by Section 4.7.5.
8.6. Complex second-order coefÔ¨Åcients
If the coefÔ¨Åcients aij are complex-valued, the situation is more complicated. For Œ© = Rn,
there are always Gaussian estimates if the aij are uniformly continuous [Aus96] or if
n ‚©Ω2; but otherwise there are counterexamples (see Auscher, Coulhon and Tchamitchian
[ACT96] and Davies [Dav97]). If Œ© is a Lipschitz domain and V = W 1,2
0
(Œ©) or W 1,2(Œ©),
then the existence of Gaussian estimates depends on the Lipschitz constant even for con-
stant complex aij : For small Lipschitz constant Gaussian estimates are valid in that case
[AT01a], but a counterexample based on [MNP85] is given for large Lipschitz constant.
However, if the imaginary parts of the aij are symmetric then Gaussian estimates are valid:
THEOREM ([Ouh03], Theorem 5.5). Assume that the imaginary parts of the coefÔ¨Å-
cients satisfy
Imaij ‚ààW 1,‚àû,
Im(aij + aji) = 0.
Let V = W 1,2
0
(Œ©) or W 1,2(Œ©) assuming the extension property in the latter case. Then
TV admits Gaussian estimates.
8.7. Further comments on Gaussian estimates
Gaussian estimates were Ô¨Årst proved by Aronson [Aro67] for real nonsymmetric ellip-
tic operators on Rn with measurable coefÔ¨Åcients. He used Moser‚Äôs parabolic Harnack in-
equality [Mos64]. New impetus to the subject came from Davies [Dav87] who introduced
a perturbation method (‚ÄúDavies‚Äô trick‚Äù) which provides an efÔ¨Åcient tool to prove Gaussian
estimates via ultracontractivity.One of Davies‚Äô motivations was to Ô¨Ånd optimal constants in
the estimates, and the results are presented for symmetric operators in his book [[Dav90]].

76
W. Arendt
Here we do not explain how the Gaussian estimates are proved but refer to the correspond-
ing articles mentioned above and to [[Fri64]], [AER94], [AMT98], [DHZ94]. Some of
the semigroup properties put together here carry over to estimates valid for higher-order
equations, see, for example, [Are97], [Hie96], [HP97], [tER98].
8.8. The square root property
Assume that Œ© ‚äÇRn is open, bounded with Lipschitz boundary. Consider the operator AV
with
V = W 1,2
0
(Œ©)
or
V = W 1,2(Œ©),
i.e., Dirichlet or Neumann boundary conditions are imposed. Let œâ ‚ààR be large so that
AV + œâ is sectorial. Then
D

(AV + œâ)1/2	
= V.
This is an extremely deep result. For Rn, it is the famous Kato‚Äôs conjecture which was
solved recently by Auscher, Hofmann, Lacey, McIntosh and Tchamitchian [AHLMT02].
The result for the boundary conditions mentioned here is proved in [AT01a]. We refer to
these articles as well as [[AT98]] for the sophisticated techniques from harmonic analysis
leading to this result and also for various connections of these results with other areas.
We mention that Kato‚Äôs square root problem has also been solved for higher order elliptic
operators in Rn [AHMT01]. Finally, we mention an elegant short proof of the square root
property by ter Elst and Robinson [tER96b] (after previous work by McIntosh [McI85]) in
the special case where the second-order coefÔ¨Åcients are H√∂lder continuous.
8.9. The hyperbolic equation
We keep the notations and assumptions made in the beginning of this section, but we as-
sume in addition that
aij = aji,
i,j = 1,...,n.
Then the following holds.
THEOREM. The operator ‚àíAV generates a cosine function on L2(Œ©) with phase space
V √ó L2(Œ©).
The proof [[ABHN01], Theorem 7.1] given for V = W 1,2
0
(Œ©) carries over to arbitrary
closed subspaces V of W 1,2(Œ©) containing W 1,2
0
(Œ©). The assertion of the Theorem im-
plies in particular the square root property D((AV + œâ)1/2) = V (for œâ large). However,
here AV is a certain perturbation of a self-adjoint operator [[ABHN01], Corollary 3.14.12]
for which the square root property is easy in comparison with the general result mentioned
in Section 8.8.

8.10. Nondivergence form
Let aij ‚ààC(Rn) such that
Re

aij(x)ŒæiŒæj ‚©æŒ±|Œæ|2
for all x ‚ààRn, Œæ ‚ààRn and some Œ± > 0. Consider the operator A on L2(Rn) given by
Af =
n

i,j=1
aijDiDju
with domain D(A) = H 2(Rn). If the coefÔ¨Åcients aij are H√∂lder continuous, then A gen-
erates a holomorphic C0-semigroup on L2(Rn) admitting Gaussian estimates [[Fri64],
Theorem 9.4.2]. However, there are no Gaussian estimates in general, if the coefÔ¨Åcients
are merely uniformly continuous and bounded, even if they are real [Bau84]. However,
by other methods (viz. the T 1 Theorem) Duong and Simonett [DS97] show that the
Lp-realization of the above operator is sectorial and has a bounded H ‚àû-calculus. Fur-
ther generalizations to VMO-coefÔ¨Åcients are given by Duong and Yan [DY01] by wavelet
methods and by Heck and Hieber [HH03] via weighted estimates.
8.11. Elliptic operators with Banach space-valued coefÔ¨Åcients
Elliptic operators with coefÔ¨Åcients in a Banach space and the associated parabolic equa-
tions were introduced and investigated by Amann [Ama01]. Further regularity results were
obtained by Denk, Hieber and Pr√ºss [DHP01] where a comprehensive presentation of the
subject is given. A basic result is the following.
THEOREM ([DHP01], Section 5.5). Let X be a UMD-space, n, m ‚ààN, 1 < p < ‚àû,
aŒ± ‚ààL(X) for multiindices Œ± of order |Œ±| = m. Assume the ellipticity condition

A(Œæ)

for all Œæ ‚ààRn such that |Œæ| = 1, and some Œ∏ ‚àà[0,œÄ/2), where we set

|Œ±|=m

Then A has a bounded H ‚àû(Œ£Œ∏)-calculus. In particular, A is R-sectorial.

W. Arendt
This result can be extended to elliptic operators on Lp(Œ©,X) with diverse boundary
conditions. It is remarkable that it is possible to characterize precisely those boundary con-
ditions for which maximal regularity (MR) is valid; viz. by the Lopatinskii‚ÄìShapiro con-
dition; see [DDHPV04].

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
89
1. Introduction
A scalar conservation law in one space dimension is a Ô¨Årst-order partial differential equa-
tion of the form
ut + f (u)x = 0.
(1.1)
Here u is called the conserved quantity while f is the Ô¨Çux. Equations of this type often
describe transport phenomena. Integrating (1.1) over a given interval [a,b] one obtains
d
dt
 b
a
u(t,x)dx =
 b
a
ut(t,x)dx
= ‚àí
 b
a
f

u(t,x)
	
x dx
= f

u(t,a)
	
‚àíf

u(t,b)
	
= [inÔ¨Çow at a] ‚àí[outÔ¨Çow at b].
In other words, the quantity u is neither created nor destroyed: the total amount of u con-
tained inside any given interval [a,b] can change only due to the Ô¨Çow of u across boundary
points (see Figure 1). By the knowledge of the Ô¨Çux function f (u), one should thus be able
to determine the evolution of u in future times.
Throughout the following, we shall be concerned with an n √ó n system of conservation
laws
‚éß
‚é™‚é®
‚é™‚é©
‚àÇ
‚àÇt u1 + ‚àÇ
‚àÇx f1(u1,...,un) = 0,
...
‚àÇ
‚àÇt un + ‚àÇ
‚àÇx fn(u1,...,un) = 0.
For simplicity, this will still be written in the form (1.1), but keeping in mind that now
u = (u1,...,un) is a vector in Rn and that f = (f1,...,fn) is a map from Rn into itself.
The components u1,...,un are now called the conserved quantities, while f1,...,fn are
the Ô¨Çuxes.
Systems of this form are often used in order to express the fundamental balance laws
of continuum physics, assuming that small viscosity or dissipation effects are neglected.
A primary example is provided by the Euler equations describing the evolution of a com-
pressible, nonviscous Ô¨Çuid:
‚éß
‚é™‚é®
‚é™‚é©
œÅt + (œÅv)x = 0
(conservation of mass),
(œÅv)t +

œÅv2 + p
	
x = 0
(conservation of momentum),
(œÅE)t + (œÅEv + pv)x = 0
(conservation of energy).
Here œÅ is the mass density, v is the velocity while œÅE = œÅe + œÅv2/2 is the energy density,
obtained as the sum of an internal energy œÅe and the kinetic energy œÅv2/2. The system is

90
A. Bressan
Fig. 1. Solution to a conservation law.
closed by a constitutive relation of the form p = p(œÅ,e), giving the pressure as a function
of the density and of the internal energy. The particular choice of p depends on the gas
under consideration.
Using the chain rule, the system (1.1) can be written in the quasilinear form
ut + A(u)ux = 0,
(1.2)
where A(u) .= Df (u) is the Jacobian matrix of Ô¨Årst-order partial derivatives of f . For
smooth solutions, the two equations (1.1) and (1.2) are entirely equivalent. However, if
u has a jump at a point Œæ (see Figure 1), the left-hand side of (1.2) will contain a product
of the discontinuous function A(u) with the distributional derivative ux, which in this case
contains a Dirac mass at the point Œæ. In general, such a product is not well deÔ¨Åned. Hence,
(1.2) is meaningful only within a class of continuous functions. On the other hand, the sys-
tem (1.1) is in divergence form and can be always interpreted in distributional sense. More
precisely, a locally integrable function u = u(t,x) is a weak solution of (1.1) provided that
  uœÜt + f (u)œÜx
dx dt = 0
(1.3)
for every differentiable function with compact support œÜ ‚ààC1
c .
We say that the above system is strictly hyperbolic if every matrix A(u) has n real,
distinct eigenvalues, say Œª1(u) < ¬∑¬∑¬∑ < Œªn(u). In this case, by a standard result of lin-
ear algebra one can Ô¨Ånd dual bases of left and right eigenvectors of A(u), denoted by
l1(u),...,ln(u) and r1(u),...,rn(u), normalized according to
ri(u)
 = 1,
li(u) ¬∑ rj(u) =

1
if i = j,
0
if i Ã∏= j.
(1.4)
To appreciate the consequences of the nonlinearity of the equations, consider Ô¨Årst the
case of a linear system with constant coefÔ¨Åcients:
ut + Aux = 0.
(1.5)

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
91
As before, we call Œª1 < ¬∑¬∑¬∑ < Œªn the eigenvalues of the matrix A and let {l1,...,ln},
{r1,...,rn} be dual bases of left and right eigenvectors, as in (1.4). One can then write
the general solution of (1.5) as a superposition of independent linear waves:
u(t,x) =

i
œÜi(x ‚àíŒªit)ri.
(1.6)
The functions œÜi can here be determined by decomposing the initial data u(0,¬∑) with re-
spect to the given basis of eigenvectors:
u(0,y) =

i
œÜi(y)ri,
œÜi(y) .= li ¬∑ u(0,y).
Notice that the solution (1.6) is completely decoupled along the eigenspaces of A. Each
component travels with constant speed, given by the corresponding eigenvalue of A.
In the nonlinear case (1.2) where the matrix A is not constant but depends on the state u,
new features will appear.
(i) The eigenvalues Œªi now depend on u. Since these eigenvalues determine the speeds
of propagation of the wave fronts, as a result the shape of the various components
in the solution will vary in time. In particular, rarefaction waves will decay, and
compression waves will become steeper, possibly leading to shock formation in
Ô¨Ånite time (see Figure 2).
(ii) The eigenvectors ri also depend on u. These vectors determine the basis along which
the solution is decomposed. As a result, the various components are no longer inde-
pendent, and nontrivial interactions between waves of different families will occur.
In particular, the strength of the interacting waves may change and new waves can
be created, as the result of an interaction.
Of all these features, the most important for the mathematical theory is the possible loss
of regularity in the solutions, related to the formation of shocks [J]. This happens also be-
cause in our model equations we neglect small second-order terms that could provide a
smoothing effect. The strong nonlinearity of the equations, together with this lack of regu-
larity in the solutions, is responsible for many of the difÔ¨Åculties encountered in a rigorous
mathematical analysis. Indeed, most of the well established, powerful techniques of func-
tional analysis do not apply in this context. The theory of hyperbolic conservation laws has
thus progressed mainly by developing ad hoc methods.
Fig. 2. Shock formation in a nonlinear wave.

92
A. Bressan
Toward the construction as well as the analysis of solutions, a basic building block is the
so called Riemann problem, where the initial data is piecewise constant:
u(0,x) =

u‚àí
if x < 0,
u+
if x > 0.
(1.8)
This particular initial value problem was Ô¨Årst introduced in 1860 in a fundamental paper
of Riemann [Rm], who studied its solution in the context of isentropic gas dynamics. The
case of more general n √ó n systems was considered by Lax [Lx] nearly a century later. The
solution is assumed to be self-similar, having the form
u(t,x) = U(x/t).
The central position taken by the Riemann problem is related to a symmetry of the equa-
tions (1.1). If u = u(t,x) is any solution, then, for each Œ∏ > 0, the rescaled function
uŒ∏(t,x) .= u(Œ∏t,Œ∏x)
provides another solution. The special solutions which are invariant under the above
stretching of coordinates are precisely the ones which solve a Riemann problem.
For the Cauchy problem with general initial data
u(0,x) .= ¬Øu(x),
(1.7)
the Ô¨Årst global existence theorem was proved in a fundamental paper by Glimm [G]. Ap-
proximate solutions are constructed by solving a family of Riemann problems, one for
each node of a Ô¨Åxed grid in the t‚Äìx plane. The convergence of a sequence of approxi-
mations is guaranteed by a compactness argument, based on a priori bounds on the total
variation. A key idea in Glimm‚Äôs approach, which remained fundamental in nearly all sub-
sequent developments, is to control the total variation by means of a quadratic interaction
functional. Roughly speaking, this functional measures the amount of possible future inter-
actions among waves in a given solution. It is monotonically decreasing in time, provided
that the total variation is small enough. For this reason Glimm‚Äôs result, as well as most of
the present theory for n √ó n conservation laws, is restricted to the case of small BV data.
An alternative method for constructing approximate solutions to the general Cauchy
problem is by front tracking. This method was Ô¨Årst proposed by Dafermos [D1] to study
scalar conservation laws, then adapted by DiPerna to the case of 2 √ó 2 systems. More
recently, it has been reÔ¨Åned and extended to n √ó n systems in [B2,Ri,BaJ,AM2].
The underlying idea is quite simple. We seek approximate solutions which are piecewise
constant, having jumps along a Ô¨Ånite number of straight lines in the t‚Äìx plane. For this
purpose, at time t = 0 we start with an initial data which is piecewise constant. At each
point of jump, we construct a piecewise constant approximate solution of the corresponding
Riemann problem. Piecing together these local solutions, we obtain a solution u = u(t,x)
which is well deÔ¨Åned until the Ô¨Årst time t1, where two lines of discontinuity interact. In this
case, the solution can be further prolonged in time by solving the new Riemann problem

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
93
determined by the interaction. This yields an approximation valid up to the next time t2 > t1
where two more fronts interact. Once again we solve the corresponding Riemann problem,
thus extending the solution further in time, etc.
This approach shares many features in common with the Glimm scheme. The Riemann
solutions remain the basic building blocks, and the control of the total variation relies on
exactly the same wave interaction functional introduced in [G]. However, there are some
distinct advantages:
‚Ä¢ In the Glimm scheme, at each time step tj .= jt one has to replace the constructed
solution u(tj‚àí,¬∑) with a piecewise constant function u(tj,¬∑), having jumps exactly
at the nodes of a Ô¨Åxed grid. This is achieved by a random sampling procedure. As a
consequence, the approximate solution t ‚Üíu(t,¬∑) is not continuous as a map with
values in L1
loc. Moreover, the sum of all the errors

j‚©æ1
u(tj) ‚àíu(tj‚àí)

L1
remains uniformly large as the mesh size t tends to zero. The convergence to an
exact solution stems from the fact that the differences u(tj) ‚àíu(tj‚àí) are somehow
‚Äúrandom‚Äù: in the long run they tend to cancel each other out, according to the law of
large numbers. However, the analysis of the convergence rate is not an easy task.
The front tracking algorithm, on the other hand, constructs approximate solutions
u(t,¬∑) whose jumps move with constant speed. Therefore, the map t ‚Üíu(t,¬∑) is now
Lipschitz continuous with respect to the L1 distance. This makes it much easier to
derive error estimates and properties of the limit solution.
‚Ä¢ For the Glimm scheme, the dependence of the approximate solution on the initial data
is not continuous, and extremely difÔ¨Åcult to study. On the other hand, for a solution
u constructed by front tracking there is a natural class of perturbations which can
be analyzed in detail. Namely, one can slightly shift the locations of the jumps in
the initial data u(0,¬∑) and estimate at a later time the corresponding shifts of the
wave fronts in u(t,¬∑). This approach yields a basic understanding of the Lipschitz
continuous dependence of solutions on their initial data, in the L1 norm. In the 2 √ó 2
case, a rigorous proof along these lines was worked out in [BC1].
‚Ä¢ A very effective tool in the analysis of smooth solutions to hyperbolic systems is the
method of characteristics. For a Ô¨Åxed i ‚àà{1,...,n}, one looks at the curves x = xi(t)
in the t‚Äìx plane which satisfy the ordinary differential equation (ODE)
Àôx(t) = Œªi
ut,x(t)		.
This method works perfectly well also for solutions constructed by front tracking.
In this case, the analysis is particularly simple because the characteristic curves are
polygonals.
‚Ä¢ For a front tracking solution, to each front one can assign a generation order, count-
ing the number of interactions needed to produce it. Fronts originating at time t = 0
are the ‚Äúprimal ancestors‚Äù, and have order 1. When these interact, to the new fronts
emerging from the interaction we assign order 2, etc. This provides an additional,
useful tool for the analysis of solutions.

94
A. Bressan
Fig. 3. InÔ¨Ånitely many wave fronts.
‚Ä¢ Front tracking approximations have an elementary structure, being piecewise constant
in the t‚Äìx plane, with exactly 2 incoming wave fronts at each interaction point. Hence,
all of the relevant estimates can be obtained by the careful analysis of one single
building block: the Riemann problem generated by the interaction of two wave fronts.
By proving suitable estimates on front tracking approximations and passing to the
limit, relying on a general uniqueness theorem one can now obtain detailed results on
the existence, stability, local and global structure, and asymptotic behavior of weak
solutions.
On the negative side, one must mention one technical problem that has slowed down the
development of the front tracking method for several years. If the algorithm is implemented
in a straightforward way, it may well produce a solution with inÔ¨Ånitely many wave fronts
within Ô¨Ånite time (see Figure 3). When this happens, the whole construction breaks down.
This unpleasant situation does not occur for scalar conservation laws, and can be easily
avoided in the 2 √ó 2 case. But for general n √ó n systems it represents a real difÔ¨Åculty. To
prevent the number of wave fronts from blowing up, some new technical provision must be
inserted. As shown in [B2,BaJ], this can be achieved by occasionally solving a Riemann
problem in a simpliÔ¨Åed way, which is not very accurate but involves a minimum number of
outgoing fronts. In the end, this modiÔ¨Åcation of the algorithm is a purely technical device,
which does not affect in any way the results which can be obtained by the method. Yet, it
lengthens a bit every proof, requiring one more case to consider before the punch line. For
this reason, we feel it somewhat detracts from the elegance of the whole approach.
2. Weak solutions
2.1. Basic deÔ¨Ånitions
A basic feature of nonlinear hyperbolic systems is the possible loss of regularity: solutions
which are initially smooth may become discontinuous within Ô¨Ånite time. In order to con-
struct solutions globally in time, we are thus forced to work in a space of discontinuous
functions, and interpret the conservation equations in a distributional sense.

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
95
DEFINITION 2.1. Let f :Rn ‚ÜíRn be a smooth vector Ô¨Åeld. A measurable function u =
u(t,x) from an open set Œ© ‚äÜR √ó R into Rn is a distributional solution of the system of
conservation laws
ut + f (u)x = 0
(2.1)
if, for every C1 function œÜ :Œ© ‚ÜíRn with compact support, one has

(2.2)

locally integrable in Œ©. Notice also that weak solutions are deÔ¨Åned up to L1 equivalence.
A solution is not affected by changing its values on a set of measure zero in the t‚Äìx plane.
An easy consequence of the above deÔ¨Ånition is the closure of the set of solutions with
respect to convergence in L1
loc.

2.3. Admissibility conditions
To motivate the following discussion, we Ô¨Årst observe that the concept of weak solution is
usually not stringent enough to achieve uniqueness for a Cauchy problem. In some cases,
inÔ¨Ånitely many weak solutions can be found.
EXAMPLE 2.2. For Burgers‚Äô equation
ut +

u2/2
	
x = 0,
(2.11)
consider the Cauchy problem with initial data
u(0,x) =

1
if x ‚©æ0,
0
if x < 0.
For every Œ± ‚àà]0,1[, a weak solution is
uŒ±(t,x) =
‚éß
‚é™‚é®
‚é™‚é©
0
if x < Œ±t/2,

Indeed, the piecewise constant function uŒ± trivially satisÔ¨Åes the equation outside the jumps.
Moreover, the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot conditions hold along the two lines of discontinuity {x =
Œ±t/2} and {x = (1 + Œ±)t/2}.
From the previous example it is clear that, in order to achieve the uniqueness and con-
tinuous dependence on the initial data, the notion of weak solution must be supplemented
with further ‚Äúadmissibility conditions‚Äù along shocks, possibly motivated by physical con-
siderations. A standard way to impose additional conditions is through the use of convex
entropies.
DEFINITION 2.4. A continuously differentiable function Œ∑ :Rn ‚ÜíR is called an entropy
for the system of conservation laws (2.1), with entropy Ô¨Çux q :Rn ‚ÜíR, if for all u ‚ààRn
there holds
DŒ∑(u) ¬∑ Df (u) = Dq(u).
(2.12)
An immediate consequence of (2.12) is that, if u = u(t,x) is a C1 solution of (2.1), then
Œ∑(u)t + q(u)x = 0.
(2.13)

100
A. Bressan
Indeed,
DŒ∑(u)ut + Dq(u)ux = DŒ∑(u)

‚àíDf (u)ux
	
+ Dq(u)ux = 0.
In other words, for a smooth solution u, not only the quantities u1,...,un are conserved
but the additional conservation law (2.13) holds as well. However, one should be aware
that, when u is discontinuous, the quantity Œ∑(u) may not be conserved.
A standard admissibility condition for weak solutions of (1.1) can now be formulated as
follows.
DEFINITION 2.5. Let Œ∑ be a convex entropy for the system (2.1), with entropy Ô¨Çux q.
A weak solution u is entropy-admissible if
Œ∑(u)t + q(u)x ‚©Ω0
(2.14)
in distribution sense, i.e.,
  
Œ∑(u)œït + q(u)œïx

dx dt ‚©æ0
(2.15)
for every function œï ‚©æ0 continuously differentiable with compact support.
For a bounded solution, we now show that the entropy admissibility condition (2.14)
poses additional restrictions every point of approximate jump.
THEOREM 2.2. Let u = u(t,x) be a bounded, entropy admissible solution of the system
of conservation laws (2.1). Let Œ∑ be a convex entropy with Ô¨Çux q. Assume that u has an
approximate jump at the point (œÑ,Œæ), so that (2.10) holds. Then the left and right states
u‚àí,u+ and the speed Œª satisfy
ŒªŒ∑u+	 ‚àíŒ∑(u‚àí) ‚©æqu+	 ‚àíq(u‚àí).
(2.16)
PROOF. By the same rescaling argument used in the proof of Theorem 2.3, we conclude
that the function U in (2.5) is itself an entropy admissible solution. Given any nonnegative
function œï ‚ààC1
c , using the divergence theorem we Ô¨Ånd
0 ‚©Ω
 
Œ∑(U)œït + q(U)œïx dx dt
=
 ŒªŒ∑u+	 ‚àíŒ∑(u‚àí) ‚àíqu+	 + q(u‚àí)œï(t,Œªt)dt.
Therefore (2.16) must hold.
‚ñ°
Of course, the entropy admissibility condition can be useful only if some nontrivial
convex entropy for the system (2.1) is known. Observe that (2.12) represents a Ô¨Årst-order
system of n partial differential equations for the two scalar variables Œ∑, q. For n ‚©æ3, this

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
101
system is overdetermined. In general, one should thus expect to Ô¨Ånd solutions only in the
case n ‚©Ω2. In mathematical physics, however, one encounters several special cases of
systems where a nontrivial convex entropy exists.
An alternative admissibility condition, due to Lax [Lx], is particularly useful because it
can be applied to any system and has a simple geometrical interpretation. We recall that a
function u has an approximate jump at a point (œÑ,Œæ) if (2.10) holds, for some U deÔ¨Åned as
in (2.5). In this case, by Theorem 2.3 the right and left states u‚àí,u+ and the speed Œª of the
jump satisfy the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot equations. In particular, Œª must be an eigenvalue of the
averaged matrix A(u‚àí,u+) deÔ¨Åned at (2.8), i.e., Œª = Œªi(u‚àí,u+) for some i ‚àà{1,...,n}.
DEFINITION 2.6. A solution u = u(t,x) of (2.1) satisÔ¨Åes the Lax admissibility condition
if, at each point (œÑ,Œæ) of approximate jump, the left and right states u‚àí,u+ and the speed
Œª = Œªi(u‚àí,u+) of the jump satisfy
Œªi(u‚àí) ‚©æŒª ‚©æŒªi
u+	.
(2.17)
To appreciate the geometric meaning of this condition, consider a piecewise smooth
solution, having a discontinuity along the line x = Œ≥ (t), where the solution jumps from a
left state u‚àíto a right state u+. According to (2.9), this discontinuity must travel with a
speed Œª .= ÀôŒ≥ = Œªi(u‚àí,u+) equal to an eigenvalue of the averaged matrix A(u‚àí,u+). If we
now look at the i-characteristics, i.e., at the solutions of the ODE
Àôx = Œªi

u(t,x)
	
,
we see that the Lax condition requires that these lines run into the shock, from both sides.
3. The Riemann problem
In this section we construct the solution to the Riemann problem, consisting of the system
of conservation laws
ut + f (u)x = 0
(3.1)
with the simple, piecewise constant initial data
u(0,x) = ¬Øu(x) .=

u‚àí
if x < 0,
u+
if x > 0.
(3.2)
This will provide the basic building block toward the solution of the Cauchy problem with
more general initial data. Throughout our analysis, we shall adopt the following standard
assumption, introduced by Lax [Lx].
(H) For each i = 1,...,n, the ith Ô¨Åeld is either genuinely nonlinear, so that DŒªi(u) ¬∑
ri(u) > 0 for all u, or linearly degenerate, with DŒªi(u) ¬∑ ri(u) = 0 for all u.

102
A. Bressan
Notice that, in the genuinely nonlinear case, the ith eigenvalue Œªi is strictly increasing
along each integral curve of the corresponding Ô¨Åeld of eigenvectors ri. In the linearly de-
generate case, on the other hand, the eigenvalue Œªi is constant along each such curve. With
the above assumption we are ruling out the possibility that, along some integral curve of an
eigenvector ri, the corresponding eigenvalue Œªi may partly increase and partly decrease,
having several local maxima and minima.
EXAMPLE 3.1. Denote by œÅ the density of a gas, by v = œÅ‚àí1 its speciÔ¨Åc volume and by
u its velocity. A simple model for isentropic gas dynamics is then provided by the system

vt ‚àíux = 0,
ut + p(v)x = 0.
Here p = p(v) is a function which determines the pressure in terms of the speciÔ¨Åc volume.
An appropriate choice is p(v) = kv‚àíŒ≥ , with 1 ‚©ΩŒ≥ ‚©Ω3. In the region where v > 0, the
Jacobian matrix of the system is
A .= Df =

0
‚àí1
p‚Ä≤(v)
0

.
The eigenvalues and eigenvectors are found to be
Œª1 = ‚àí


Œª2 =

‚àíp‚Ä≤(v),
r1 =



‚àíp‚Ä≤(v)
	T ,
r2 =

‚àí1,

‚àíp‚Ä≤(v)
	T .
It is now clear that the system is strictly hyperbolic provided that p‚Ä≤(v) < 0 for all v > 0.
Moreover, observing that
DŒª1 ¬∑ r1 =
p‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(v)
2

‚àíp‚Ä≤(v)
= DŒª2 ¬∑ r2,
we conclude that both characteristic Ô¨Åelds are genuinely nonlinear if p‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(v) > 0 for all
v > 0.
As we shall see in the sequel, if the assumption (H) holds, then the solution of the
Riemann problem has a simple structure consisting of the superposition of n elementary
waves: shocks, rarefactions or contact discontinuities. This considerably simpliÔ¨Åes all fur-
ther analysis. On the other hand, for strictly hyperbolic systems that do not satisfy the
condition (H), basic existence and stability results can still be obtained but at the price of
heavier technicalities. See [L4] for an approach based on the Glimm scheme, or the recent
paper [BiB] for the vanishing viscosity approach.

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
103
3.1. Shock and rarefaction waves
Fix a state u0 ‚ààRn and an index i ‚àà{1,...,n}. As before, let ri(u) be an i-eigenvector of
the Jacobian matrix A(u) = Df (u). The integral curve of the vector Ô¨Åeld ri through the
point u0 is called the i-rarefaction curve through u0. It is obtained by solving the Cauchy
problem in state space:
du
dœÉ = ri(u),
u(0) = u0.
(3.3)
We shall denote this curve as
œÉ ‚ÜíRi(œÉ)(u0).
(3.4)
Clearly, the parametrization depends on the choice of the eigenvectors ri. In particular, if
we impose the normalization |ri(u)| ‚â°1, then the rarefaction curve (3.4) will be parame-
trized by arc-length.
Next, for a Ô¨Åxed u0 ‚ààRn and i ‚àà{1,...,n}, we consider the curve of states u which can
be connected to the right of u0 by an i-shock, satisfying the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot equations
Œª(u ‚àíu0) = f (u) ‚àíf (u0).
(3.5)
As in (2.9), we can write these equations in the form
A(u,u0)(u ‚àíu0) = Œª(u ‚àíu0),
(3.6)
showing that u ‚àíu0 must be a right i-eigenvector of the averaged matrix
A(u,u0) .=
 1
0
A

su + (1 ‚àís)u0
	
ds.
By a theorem of linear algebra, this holds if and only if u ‚àíu0 is orthogonal to every
left j-eigenvector of A(u,u0), with j Ã∏= i. The Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot conditions can thus be
written in the equivalent form
lj(u,u0) ¬∑ (u ‚àíu0) = 0
for all j Ã∏= i,
(3.7)
together with Œª = Œªi(u,u0). Notice that (3.7) is a system of n ‚àí1 scalar equations in
n variables (the n components of the vector u). Linearizing at the point u = u0 one obtains
the linear system
lj(u0) ¬∑ (w ‚àíu0) = 0,
j Ã∏= i,
whose solutions are all the points w = u0 + cri(u0), c ‚ààR. Since the vectors lj(u0) are
linearly independent, we can apply the implicit function theorem and conclude that the set

Fig. 5. Shock and rarefaction curves.
of solutions of (3.7) is a smooth curve, tangent to the vector ri at the point u0. This will be
called the i-shock curve through the point u0 and denoted as
œÉ ‚ÜíSi(œÉ)(u0).
(3.8)
Using a suitable parametrization (say, by arc-length), one can show that the two curves
Ri,Si have a second-order contact at the point u0 (see Figure 5). More precisely, the fol-
lowing estimates hold.

3.3. General solution of the Riemann problem
Relying on the previous analysis, the solution of the general Riemann problem
(3.1) and (3.2) can be obtained by Ô¨Ånding intermediate states œâ0 = u‚àí,œâ1,...,œân = u+
such that each pair of adjacent states œâi‚àí1,œâi can be connected by an elementary wave,

œâi = Œ®i(œÉi)(œâi‚àí1),
i = 1,...,n.

implicit function theorem provides the existence of unique wave strengths œÉ1,...,œÉn, such

3.4. Some estimates
We conclude this section by proving two types of estimates, which will play a key role in
the analysis of front tracking approximations.

small.

4. Front tracking approximations
4.1. Global existence of entropy weak solutions
In this section we describe in detail the construction of front tracking approximations and
give the main application of this technique, proving the global existence of weak solutions.
Consider the Cauchy problem
ut + f (u)x = 0,
(4.1)
u(0,x) = ¬Øu(x),
(4.2)
where the Ô¨Çux function f is smooth, deÔ¨Åned on a neighborhood of the origin. We always
assume that the system is strictly hyperbolic, and the assumption (H) holds, so that each

112
A. Bressan
characteristic Ô¨Åeld is either genuinely nonlinear or linearly degenerate. The following basic
theorem provides the global existence of an entropy weak solution, for all initial data with
suitably small total variation.
THEOREM 4.1. There exists a constant Œ¥0 > 0 such that, for every initial condition ¬Øu ‚àà
L‚àû(R;Rn) with
Tot.Var(¬Øu) ‚©ΩŒ¥0,
‚à•¬Øu‚à•L‚àû‚©ΩŒ¥0,
(4.3)
the Cauchy problem (4.1) and (4.2) has a weak solution u = u(t,x) deÔ¨Åned for all t ‚©æ0. If
Œ∑ is a convex entropy with entropy Ô¨Çux q, one can construct a solution which also satisÔ¨Åes
Œ∑(u)t + q(u)x ‚©Ω0.
(4.4)
The above theorem was Ô¨Årst proved in the fundamental paper of Glimm [G], where
approximate solutions are constructed by piecing together Riemann solutions on the nodes
of a Ô¨Åxed grid. Here we shall describe an alternative construction, based on wave-front
tracking.
Roughly speaking, a front tracking Œµ-approximate solution (see Figure 9) is a piece-
wise constant function u = u(t,x) whose jumps are located along Ô¨Ånitely many segments
x = xŒ±(t) in the t‚Äìx plane. At any given time t > 0, all these jumps should approximately
satisfy the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot conditions, namely


ÀôxŒ±


‚àí

f

‚àíf

u(t,xŒ±‚àí)
	 = O(1) ¬∑ Œµ.
Moreover, if Œ∑ is a convex entropy with Ô¨Çux q, at each time t > 0 in view of (2.16) we also
Fig. 9. Front tracking approximation.

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
113
require the approximate admissibility conditions

Œ±
qu(t,xŒ±+)	 ‚àíqu(t,xŒ±‚àí)	 ‚àíÀôxŒ±

‚©ΩO(1) ¬∑ Œµ.
For didactical purposes, the proof of Theorem 4.1 will be given in two steps. In the Ô¨Årst
part of the proof we describe a naive front tracking algorithm and derive uniform bounds on
the total variation of the approximate solutions. Relying on Helly‚Äôs compactness theorem,
we also prove that a suitable subsequence of front tracking approximations converges to an
entropy weak solution. This Ô¨Årst step thus contains all the ‚Äúheart of the matter‚Äù. It would
provide a complete proof, except for one gap: we are not considering here the possibility
that inÔ¨Ånitely many wave-fronts appear within Ô¨Ånite time (see Figure 3). If this happens,
the naive front tracking algorithm breaks down, and solutions cannot be further prolonged
in time.
The only purpose of the second part of the proof is to Ô¨Åx this technical problem. We
show that a suitable modiÔ¨Åed front tracking algorithm will always produce approximate
solutions having a Ô¨Ånite number of wave-fronts for all times t ‚©æ0. This will achieve a
completely rigorous proof of Theorem 4.1.
4.2. A naive front tracking algorithm
Let the initial condition ¬Øu be given and Ô¨Åx Œµ > 0. We now describe an algorithm which pro-
duces a piecewise constant approximate solution to the Cauchy problem (4.1) and (4.2).
The construction (see Figure 9) starts at time t = 0 by taking a piecewise constant approx-
imation u(0,¬∑) of ¬Øu, such that

by piecewise constant rarefaction fans, inserting additional states œâi,j as follows (see Fig-
ure 10).
If the ith characteristic Ô¨Åeld is genuinely nonlinear and œÉi > 0, we divide the centered
i-rarefaction into a number pi of smaller i-waves, each with strength œÉi/pi. Since we want

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
115
Fig. 12. Approximate solution to a Riemann problem.
We observe that the difference between this function v and the exact solution is only
due to the fact that every centered i-rarefaction wave is here divided into equal parts and
replaced by a rarefaction fan containing pi wave-fronts. Because of (4.8), the strength of
each one of these fronts is less than Œµ.
We now resume the construction of a front tracking solution to the original Cauchy prob-
lem (4.1) and (4.2). Having solved all the Riemann problems at time t = 0, the approximate
solution u can be prolonged until a Ô¨Årst time t1 is reached, when two wave-fronts inter-
act (see Figure 9). Since u(t1,¬∑) is still a piecewise constant function, the corresponding
Riemann problems can again be approximately solved within the class of piecewise con-
stant functions. The solution u is then continued up to a time t2 where a second interaction
takes place, etc. We remark that, by an arbitrary small change in the speed of one of the
wave fronts, it is not restrictive to assume that at most two incoming fronts collide, at each
given time t > 0. This will considerably simplify all subsequent analysis, since we do not
need to consider the case where three or more incoming fronts meet together.
4.3. Bounds on the total variation
In this section we derive bounds on the total variation of a front tracking approximation
u(t,¬∑), uniformly valid for all t ‚©æ0. These estimates will be obtained from Lemma 3.2,
using an interaction functional.
We begin by introducing some notation. At a Ô¨Åxed time t let xŒ±, Œ± = 1,...,N, be the
locations of the fronts in u(t,¬∑). Moreover, let |œÉŒ±| be the strength of the wave-front at xŒ±,
say of the family kŒ± ‚àà{1,...,n}. Consider the two functionals
V (t) .= V

DEFINITION 4.1. Two fronts, located at points xŒ± < xŒ≤ and belonging to the characteristic
families kŒ±,kŒ≤ ‚àà{1,...,n}, respectively, are approaching if kŒ± > kŒ≤ or else if kŒ± = kŒ≤ and
at least one of the wave-fronts is a shock of a genuinely nonlinear family.
Roughly speaking, two fronts are approaching if the one behind has the larger speed
(and hence it can collide with the other, at a future time).
Now consider the approximate solution u = u(t,x) constructed by the front tracking
algorithm. It is clear that the quantities V (u(t)), Q(u(t)) remain constant except at times
where an interaction occurs. At a time œÑ where two fronts of strength |œÉ ‚Ä≤|,|œÉ ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤| collide, the

can approach all the other fronts not involved in the interaction (which have total strength
‚©ΩV (œÑ‚àí)).

4.4. A modiÔ¨Åed front tracking algorithm
For general n √ó n systems, the analysis given in the previous sections does not provide a
complete proof of Theorem 4.1, because the naive front tracking algorithm can generate in
Ô¨Ånite time an inÔ¨Ånite number of wave-fronts, in which case the whole construction breaks
down.
We thus need to modify the algorithm, to ensure that the total number of fronts
remains uniformly bounded. Following [B2], we shall use two different procedures for

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
121
(a)
(b)
Fig. 15. Different Riemann solvers.
(a)
(b)
Fig. 16. Reducing the number of wave-fronts.
solving a Riemann problem within the class of piecewise constant functions: the Accurate
Riemann Solver (see Figure 15(a)), which introduces several new wave-fronts, and a Sim-
pliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver (see Figure 15(b)), which involves a minimum number of outgoing
fronts. In this second case, all new waves are lumped together in a single nonphysical front,
traveling with a Ô¨Åxed speed ÀÜŒª strictly larger than all characteristic speeds. The main feature
of this algorithm is illustrated in Figures 16(a) and (b). If all Riemann problems are solved
accurately, the number of wave-fronts becomes inÔ¨Ånite (see Figure 16(a)). On the other
hand, if at a certain point we use the SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver, the total number of fronts
remains bounded for all times (see Figure 16(b)).
The Accurate Riemann Solver was described at (4.12). Next, we introduce a simpliÔ¨Åed
way of solving a Riemann problem, with ‚©Ω3 outgoing fronts. Throughout the following,
ÀÜŒª will denote a Ô¨Åxed constant, strictly larger than all characteristic speeds Œªj(u).

122
A. Bressan
SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver
Consider again the Riemann problem (4.6) at a point (¬Øt, ¬Øx), say generated by the interaction
of two incoming fronts, of strength œÉ,œÉ ‚Ä≤. We distinguish two cases.
Case 1.

constructed as in (4.12). Because of (4.35), the piecewise constant function Àúv contains
exactly two wave-fronts of sizes œÉ ‚Ä≤,œÉ if j > j‚Ä≤, or a single wave-front of size œÉ + œÉ ‚Ä≤
if j = j‚Ä≤. It is important to observe that Àúur Ã∏= ur, in general. We let the jump (Àúur, ur)
travel with the Ô¨Åxed speed ÀÜŒª, strictly bigger than all characteristic speeds. In a forward

(4.36)
Notice that this SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver introduces a new nonphysical wave-front,
joining the states Àúur,ur and traveling with constant speed ÀÜŒª. In turn, this front may interact
with other wave-fronts. One more case of interaction thus needs to be considered.
Case 2.
A nonphysical front hits from the left a wave front of the ithe family (see Fig-
ure 17(c)), for some i ‚àà{1,...,n}.
Let ul,um,ur be the left, middle and right state before the interaction. If
ur = Œ®i(œÉ)(um),
(4.37)
deÔ¨Åne the auxiliary right state
Àúur = Œ®i(œÉ)(ul).
(4.38)
Call Àúv the solution to the Riemann problem with data ul, Àúur, constructed as in (4.12).
Because of (4.38), Àúv will contain a single i-wave with size œÉ. Since Àúur Ã∏= ur in general, we

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
123
(a)
(b)
(c)
Fig. 17. Interactions involving two nonphysical wave-fronts.
let the jump (Àúur,ur) travel with the Ô¨Åxed speed ÀÜŒª. In a forward neighborhood of the point
(¬Øt, ¬Øx), the approximate solution u is then deÔ¨Åned again according to (4.36).
By construction, all nonphysical fronts travel with the same speed ÀÜŒª, hence they never
interact with each other. The above cases therefore cover all possible interactions between
two wave-fronts.
To complete the description of the algorithm, it remains to specify which Riemann
Solver is used at any given interaction. For this purpose, to each wave-front we attach
a generation order, counting how many interactions were needed to produce it.
DEFINITION 4.2. The generation order of a front is inductively deÔ¨Åned as follows (see
Figure 18).
‚Ä¢ All fronts generated by the Riemann problems at the initial time t = 0 are the ‚Äúprimary
ancestors‚Äù and have generation order k = 1.
‚Ä¢ Let two incoming fronts interact, say of the families i,i‚Ä≤ ‚àà{1,...,n}, with generation
orders k,k‚Ä≤. The orders of the outgoing fronts are then deÔ¨Åned as follows.
Case 1: i Ã∏= i‚Ä≤.
Then
‚Äì the outgoing i-wave and i‚Ä≤-wave have the same orders k,k‚Ä≤ as the incoming ones;
‚Äì the outgoing fronts of every other family j Ã∏= i,i‚Ä≤ have order max{k,k‚Ä≤} + 1.
Case 2: i = i‚Ä≤.
Then
‚Äì the outgoing front of the ith family has order min{k,k‚Ä≤};
‚Äì the outgoing fronts of every family j Ã∏= i have order max{k,k‚Ä≤} + 1.
In the above, we tacitly assumed that at most two incoming wave-fronts interact at any
given time. This can always be achieved by an arbitrarily small change in the speed of the
fronts. We shall also adopt the following important provision:
(P) In every Riemann Solver, rarefaction waves of the same family as one of the incom-
ing fronts are never partitioned.

124
A. Bressan
Fig. 18. Generation orders of various wave-fronts.
In other words, if one of the incoming fronts belongs to the ith family, we set pi = 1 re-
gardless of the strength of the ith outgoing front. This guarantees that every wave-front can
be uniquely continued forward in time, unless it gets completely canceled by interacting
with other fronts of the same family and opposite sign.
To complete the description of the algorithm, given an integer ŒΩ ‚©æ1, at each point of
interaction we choose:
‚Ä¢ The Accurate Riemann Solver, if the two incoming fronts both have generation order
less than ŒΩ.
‚Ä¢ The SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver, if one of the incoming fronts has generation order
greater than or equal to ŒΩ, or if it is a nonphysical front.
In the remainder of this section we will show that, with the above modiÔ¨Åcations, the
front tracking algorithm yields a completely rigorous proof of Theorem 4.1. The proof is
given in several steps.
(1) Bounds on the number of wave-fronts.
Let N0 be the number of jumps in the initial
condition u(0,¬∑). At every point where the Accurate Riemann Solver is used, we clearly
have an upper bound on the number of outgoing fronts, say less than or equal to M. By the
provision (P), after its birth no front is ever partitioned any further. Therefore,
[total number of fronts of Ô¨Årst generation] ‚©ΩMN0.
Fronts of second generation can appear only because of an interaction among two fronts of
the Ô¨Årst generation. Hence,
[number of fronts of second generation] ‚©ΩM(MN0)2.
By induction, we Ô¨Ånd
[# of fronts of generation k + 1]
‚©ΩM[# of fronts of generation k] ¬∑ [# of fronts of generation ‚©Ωk].

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
125
Hence, for each k = 1,...,ŒΩ + 1, there can be at most Ô¨Ånitely many fronts of generation k.
We now observe that all physical fronts must have generation ‚©ΩŒΩ, while the fronts of
generation ŒΩ + 1 are precisely the nonphysical ones. Moreover, when a nonphysical front
interacts with a physical one, no additional front is generated (see Figure 17(c)). We thus
conclude that the total number of all wave-fronts is bounded.
(2) Bounds on the total variation.
The uniform estimates on the total variation are
obtained as in Section 4.2, with only minor changes that we describe here. The func-
tional (4.13), measuring the total strength of waves, must now include also the nonphysical
fronts. The strength of such fronts is simply deÔ¨Åned as the size of the jump, i.e.,
|œÉŒ±| .=
u(xŒ±+) ‚àíu(xŒ±‚àí)
.
The wave interaction potential (4.14) now takes into account also the nonphysical fronts.
For this purpose, our DeÔ¨Ånition 4.1 of approaching waves is supplemented by
‚Ä¢ A nonphysical front located at a point xŒ± approaches all other physical wave-fronts
(shocks, rarefactions or contact discontinuities) located at points xŒ≤ > xŒ±.
Observe that all nonphysical fronts travel with exactly the same speed ÀÜŒª. Hence (by
deÔ¨Ånition), they do not approach each other.
To establish the inequalities (4.15)‚Äì(4.19) in this more general case, the interaction es-
timates given in Lemma 3.2 must be supplemented with two additional estimates, holding
when the SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver is used.

and ur be the left, middle and right states before interaction, so that (4.34)
holds. Introducing the auxiliary right state Àúur as in (4.35), one has (see Fig-
ures 17(a) and (b))

‚ñ°
Using the above estimates at every point where the SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver is used,
we can repeat exactly the same arguments in Section 4.2 and deduce the uniform bound
(4.19) on the total variation. In turn, this again implies the estimate (4.21) on the uniform
Lipschitz continuity with respect to time.
(3) Strength of each rarefaction front is small.
Whenever a new rarefaction front is intro-
duced, its strength is always less than Œµ. Because of the provision (P), this front is never
again partitioned, even if, as a result of subsequent interactions, its size becomes greater
than Œµ. The following analysis will show that, if the total strength of waves remains small,
the size of each rarefaction front never grows bigger than 2Œµ.
By construction, at a time t0 where a new rarefaction front is introduced by the Accurate
Riemann Solver, its size is œÉŒ±(t0) ‚àà]0,Œµ]. We now examine how its strength can change
at times t > t0. Clearly, our front will never interact with rarefaction fronts of the same
family. When it hits a shock of the same family, its size will decrease due to a cancellation.
When it crosses a nonphysical wave, by construction its size remains unchanged. On the

other hand, by subsequent interactions with fronts of other families, our rarefaction front
may increase its initial strength. To keep track of its size œÉŒ±(t) at any time t > t0, consider

(4) Total strength of all nonphysical fronts is small.
Let u be a front tracking approxi-
mation constructed by using the SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver whenever one of the incoming
fronts has generation greater than or equal to ŒΩ. Observing that an interaction involving an
incoming nonphysical front does not produce any new front, is becomes clear that:
‚Ä¢ Physical fronts are precisely those of generation less than or equal to ŒΩ.
‚Ä¢ Nonphysical fronts have generation order ŒΩ + 1.
‚Ä¢ No front of generation order greater than or equal to n + 2 is ever created.

(5) Convergence to an entropy weak solution.
The remainder of the proof again follows
closely the arguments given in Section 4.4. Fix any sequence ŒµŒΩ ‚Üí0+. For every ŒΩ ‚©æ1,
we apply the modiÔ¨Åed front tracking algorithm and construct an approximate solution uŒΩ,
dividing all new rarefactions into fronts of size < ŒµŒΩ and using the SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann
Solver whenever one of the incoming fronts has generation order ‚©æŒΩ. By the previous
analysis, the total variation of uŒΩ(t,¬∑) remains bounded, uniformly for all t ‚©æ0 and ŒΩ ‚©æ1.
Moreover, by (4.21) the maps t ‚ÜíuŒΩ(t,¬∑) are uniformly Lipschitz continuous with re-
spect to the L1 distance. We can thus apply Theorem A.1 in the Appendix and extract a
subsequence which converges to some limit function u in L1
loc, satisfying (4.20).
To show that u is actually an entropy weak solution, we Ô¨Årst need to supplement
Lemma 3.2 with new error estimates concerning nonphysical fronts. Consider any such

Notes
The Ô¨Årst proof of global existence for weak solutions with small total variation appeared in
the fundamental paper of Glimm [G]. The striking new ideas introduced in this work have
been deeply inÔ¨Çuential, providing the foundation for much of the subsequent literature
on the subject. The original proof in [G] was based on the construction of approximate
solutions generated by Riemann problems along the nodes of a Ô¨Åxed grid, with a restarting

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
131
procedure deÔ¨Åned through a random sampling. The convergence of a deterministic version
of this algorithm was later proved by Liu [L1]. An excellent presentation of the Glimm
scheme can be found in the book of Smoller [Sm].
The front tracking method for scalar conservation laws was introduced by Dafermos
[D1]. The technique was extended to 2 √ó 2 systems by DiPerna [DP1]. In this case, a naive
form of the algorithm already sufÔ¨Åces, since it produces only Ô¨Ånitely many wave-fronts.
For general n √ó n systems, some technical adjustment in order to prevent the blow up of
the number of fronts becomes necessary. The use of a SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver, and the
deÔ¨Ånition of generation number of a wave-front were introduced in [B2]. Several variants
of this technique are found in the literature.
In [Sc2], Schochet chooses the speed of nonphysical fronts to be ÀÜŒª = +‚àû. In other
words, when the SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver is used at a point P (see Figure 19), the non-
physical front is immediately sent to +‚àû, by solving a sequence of Riemann problems at
all points P1,P2,... to the right of P . This has the advantage of eliminating nonphysical
fronts altogether. The price to pay is that now the solutions have no longer Ô¨Ånite propaga-
tion speed, while the map t ‚Üíu(t,¬∑) is no longer continuous with values in L1
loc.
In [BaJ], Baiti and Jenssen show that, instead counting the generation number, the choice
between Accurate and SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver can be based solely on the strengths
œÉ,œÉ ‚Ä≤ of the two incoming waves. Given a small threshold value œÅ > 0, one can use the
Accurate Solver if |œÉœÉ ‚Ä≤| ‚©æœÅ and the SimpliÔ¨Åed Solver if |œÉœÉ ‚Ä≤| < œÅ.
Yet another possibility, considered in [Ri,HR], is to deÔ¨Åne a SimpliÔ¨Åed Riemann Solver
by attaching all new waves to one of the two main fronts involved in the interaction (see
Figure 20). This method appears to be numerically efÔ¨Åcient, because it completely avoids
the introduction of nonphysical wave-fronts, and all the computations connected with them.
A rigorous analysis of this algorithm requires interaction estimates slightly more general
than Lemma 3.2. Indeed, one must keep in mind that each front can now contain waves of
several different families.
Early applications of the front tracking algorithm to special systems are found in the
papers of Alber [Al], Lin [Ln] and Wendroff [W].
The above global existence result has been generalized by Liu [L4] to general n √ó n
systems, without the hypothesis (H) of genuine nonlinearity or linear degeneracy, using
the Glimm scheme. A front tracking algorithm for these more general systems was recently
developed in [AM2].
Fig. 19. Alternative front tracking algorithms.
Fig. 20. See Figure 19.

132
A. Bressan
The smallness assumption on the total variation is essential. For large initial data, a local
existence theorem was proved by Schochet [Sc1]. A counterexample to global existence,
showing that the L‚àûnorm of solutions can blow up in Ô¨Ånite time, was constructed by
Jenssen [Je].
5. Uniqueness and stability
In the previous section, the existence of a global weak solution was proved by a compact-
ness argument, which did not provide any information on the uniqueness of the limit. Our
next goal is to show that front tracking approximations converge to a unique limit solution,
continuously depending on the initial data.
5.1. A Lyapunov functional
In order to estimate the distance between two front tracking solutions, we introduce a func-
tional Œ¶ = Œ¶(u,v), uniformly equivalent to the L1 distance, which is ‚Äúalmost decreasing‚Äù
along pairs of solutions. Throughout the following, it will be convenient to use an alterna-
tive parametrization of shock and rarefaction curves, in terms of the characteristic speeds.
‚Ä¢ If the ith Ô¨Åeld is genuinely nonlinear, the i-shock and i-rarefaction curve through a
point u0 are parametrized so that
Œªi

‚Ä¢ For a linearly degenerate Ô¨Åeld, the shock and rarefaction curves are always parame-
trized by arc-length.

form

In the following, by an Œµ-approximate front tracking solution of the system (4.1) we

‚Ä¢ Every shock front satisÔ¨Åes the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot equations exactly, and is entropy

‚Ä¢ Every rarefaction front has strength œÉŒ± ‚àà]0,Œµ] and travels with speed ÀôxŒ± =
Œªi(u(xŒ±‚àí)), i.e., with the characteristic speed of its left state.
‚Ä¢ All nonphysical front travel with the Ô¨Åxed speed ÀÜŒª. The total strength of all nonphys-
ical fronts in u(t,¬∑) is always lees than or equal to Œµ.
The existence of Œµ-approximate solutions was discussed in the previous section. One
should mention that, to prevent three or more fronts interacting at a same point, we may
need to slightly change the speed of one of the incoming fronts. To avoid pointless techni-
calities, in all future estimates we neglect this additional error term, since it clearly can be
made arbitrarily small. Recalling the deÔ¨Ånition Œ• (u) .= V (u) + C0Q(u), the basic L1 sta-
bility estimate for front tracking approximations can now be stated as follows.

Next, if the kth Ô¨Åeld is genuinely nonlinear, according to (5.23) the functional Œ¶(u,v)
also contains a term of the form (see Figure 25)
Œ¶Œ±,k .= Œ∫1|œÉŒ±|[area of the region between
the graphs of uk and vk, to the right of xŒ±].
Notice that, because of genuine nonlinearity, the points on the graphs of uk and vk move
with different speeds. As a consequence, the shape of these graphs changes in time. In
particular, while the area enclosed by the two graphs may remain constant, the portion
of this area located to the right of a given front œÉŒ± will decrease. In Figure 25, the two
points P,Q lie initially on the same vertical line. At a later time this is no longer true.
The area of the shaded region, enclosed by the graphs of uk and vk and by a vertical line
through P , has decreased by an amount roughly equal to the area of the triangular region
with vertices P,P ‚Ä≤,Q.
Recalling the parametrization (5.1), the difference between the speed ÀôxŒ± of the jump œÉŒ±
at P and the average speed ŒªŒ±‚àí
k
of points between P and Q is estimated by

5.2. Proofs of the main estimates

computations refer to a Ô¨Åxed jump Œ± ‚ààJ (v), we shall often drop the superscript ‚ÄúŒ±‚Äù and

5.3. A semigroup of solutions
Recalling the deÔ¨Ånitions (4.13) and (4.14), consider a domain of the form
D = cl

u ‚ààL1
R;Rn	
; u is piecewise constant,
Œ• (u) .= V (u) + C0 ¬∑ Q(u) < Œ¥0
,
(5.71)
where cl denotes closure in L1. For a suitable choice of the constants C0 and Œ¥0 > 0, within
the proof of Theorem 4.1 we showed that, for every ¬Øu ‚ààD, one can construct a convergent

Front tracking method for systems of conservation laws
151
sequence of front tracking approximationstaking values inside D. Relying on Theorem 5.1,
we now show that the limit of these approximate solutions is unique and depends Lipschitz
continuously on the initial data.
THEOREM 5.2. Fix ¬Øu ‚ààD and consider a sequence ŒµŒΩ ‚Üí0. Then every sequence of
ŒµŒΩ-approximate solutions uŒΩ :[0,‚àû[ ‚ÜíD of the Cauchy problem (4.1) and (4.2) con-
verges to a unique limit solution u:[0,‚àû[ ‚ÜíD. The map (¬Øu,t) ‚Üíu(t,¬∑) .= St ¬Øu is a
uniformly Lipschitz semigroup, satisfying
S0 ¬Øu = ¬Øu,
Ss(St ¬Øu) = Ss+t ¬Øu,
(5.72)
‚à•St ¬Øu ‚àíSs ¬Øv‚à•L1 ‚©ΩL‚à•¬Øu ‚àí¬Øv‚à•L1 + L‚Ä≤|t ‚àís|
for all ¬Øu, ¬Øv ‚ààD, s,t ‚©æ0.
(5.73)
PROOF. Let ¬Øu ‚ààD be given. Consider any sequence {uŒΩ}ŒΩ‚©æ1, such that each uŒΩ is a front
tracking ŒµŒΩ-approximate solution of (4.1), with ŒµŒΩ ‚Üí0 and

(5.74)
Since the right-hand side of (5.74) approaches zero as Œº,ŒΩ ‚Üí‚àû, the sequence is Cauchy
and converges to a unique limit.
The semigroup property (5.72) is an immediate consequence of uniqueness. To prove
the continuous dependence on the initial data, let ¬Øu, ¬Øv ‚ààD be given. For each ŒΩ ‚©æ1, let
uŒΩ,vŒΩ be front tracking ŒµŒΩ-approximate solutions of (4.1) with

u(t) ‚àív(t)
