The numerical tests we present now have been performed with g = 2.
Figure 1 gives the computed Riemann decomposition for initial values u = 0, hleft = 2,
hright = 0.5 at time t = 0.18 with 100 grid points. We use a CFL number of 0.95. We draw
the height of water h (left) and the water velocity u (right). The continuous line represents
the exact solution and the crosses the computed solution. Here we have used the piecewise
constant equilibrium œáC(w) in the Ô¨Çuxes formulae. Kaniel‚Äôs choice leads to very close
results œáK(w).
Figures 2 and 3 give the computed Riemann decomposition for initial values u = 0,
hleft = 2, hright = 0.000005. This right state is equivalent to vacuum and shows the ability

468
B. Perthame
Fig. 1. A standard Riemann decomposition. A kinetic scheme based on piecewise constant equilibrium œáC. Left:
height of water, right: water velocity. Continuous line ‚Äì exact solution, crosses ‚Äì computed solution.
Fig. 2. Riemann decomposition including a vacuum state (dry soil). A kinetic scheme based on piece-
wise constant equilibrium œáC. Left: height of water, right: water velocity. Continuous line ‚Äì exact solution,
crosses ‚Äì computed solution.
Fig. 3. The same Riemann decomposition and output as in Figure 2. Kinetic scheme based on Kaniel‚Äôs
equilibrium œáK.

Kinetic formulations of parabolic and hyperbolic PDEs: From theory to numerics
469
of the schemes to handle smoothly the case h = 0 at time t = 0.12 with 100 grid points.
We use again a CFL number of 0.95. In Figure 2 we have used œáC(w). In Figure 3 we have
used œáK(w).
Both schemes give a usual Ô¨Årst-order accurate result. The main difference is that the
results obtained with œáK exhibit a slight jump at the sonic point for the particularly sharp
Riemann problem with vacuum.
6. Conclusion
The kinetic approach to macroscopic conservation laws relies Ô¨Årstly on the physical de-
scription of a gas at the kinetic level thanks to Boltzmann‚Äôs formalism. However, it goes
much beyond in two directions.
The Ô¨Årst direction is that of kinetic formulations, restricted to systems with many en-
tropies, which systematically provides a way to handle full families of entropies by single
equations. For scalar hyperbolic‚Äìparabolic equations it is a way to prove strong (and op-
timal) regularizing effects using the method of kinetic averaging lemmas which use the
Fourier transform (it may be applied here because the kinetic formulation is a linear equa-
tion on nonlinear quantities).
The second direction is that of kinetic representations, which only uses one entropy,
is much less demanding than the kinetic formulation. It allows to represent a hyperbolic
system by integrating the underlying kinetic equation and maybe uses, for instance, to
produce Ô¨Ånite volumes solvers.

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 550
Abstract
We consider various scalar conservation laws with dissipation. The Cauchy problem gener-
ates a (nonlinear) semigroup that satisÔ¨Åes a maximum principle, a contraction property with
respect to the L1-distance, and preserves the total mass (hence the word ‚Äúconservation law‚Äù).
A crucial role is played by traveling waves, also called shock proÔ¨Åles, that tend to distinct
constants as x ¬∑ ŒΩ ‚Üí¬±‚àû(ŒΩ ‚ààSd‚àí1 a direction of propagation). In particular, their stability is
a good criterion for the relevance of the underlying inviscid shock waves. The precise question
that we address in this article is their asymptotic stability with respect to the L1-distance. This
topology turns out to be the most natural one in the context of conservation laws because of
the properties mentioned above. A related question concerns steady solutions of the IBVP,
usually called ‚Äúboundary layers‚Äù.
In one space dimension, the stability of shock proÔ¨Åles is, up to some extent, a matter of
dynamical systems theory. However, a complete picture needs the more analytical proof that
constants are also asymptotically stable, with respect to zero-mass initial disturbances. The
latter may or may not hold, depending on the strength of the dissipation involved by a given
model. For instance, it does not in the inviscid case. The multidimensional stability of shock
waves is signiÔ¨Åcantly more involved, and is still widely open.
Numerical approximation by conservative and monotone Ô¨Ånite difference schemes pro-
vides another kind of dissipative process. We investigate the existence and stability of discrete
shock proÔ¨Åles. We Ô¨Åll a gap in Jennings‚Äô proof of existence and prove that tails are exponen-
tially small.
Throughout this text, we present nine Open Problems that have their own interest.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
475
Notations
Spaces Lp(Rd) are deÔ¨Åned with respect to the Lebesgue measure. Their norms are de-
noted ‚à•¬∑ ‚à•p. The conjugate exponent of p ‚àà[1,‚àû] is given by
1
p‚Ä≤ = 1 ‚àí1
p.
Sometimes, it may be useful to remember the equality p‚Ä≤ = p/(p ‚àí1). Partial derivatives
with respect to t or xŒ± are denoted ‚àÇt and ‚àÇŒ± (‚àÇx in one space dimension). The space of
C‚àû-functions with compact support in Œ© is D(Œ©). If E is a functional space, E+ denotes
the cone of nonnegative elements of E; for instance, D+(Œ©) is the set of nonnegative
test functions. The space of functions with bounded variations is designated by BV; the
total variation of a function a is TV(a). The sign function is deÔ¨Åned on real numbers by
s ‚Üísgn(s) = s/|s| is s Ã∏= 0 and sgn(0) = 0. The positive part s+ of a real number s is
max(s,0). Its negative part is s‚àí:= min(s,0).
Introduction
Scalar conservation laws with dissipation
We are interested in scalar conservation laws of the form
‚àÇtu +
d

Œ±=1
‚àÇŒ±f Œ±(u) = Lu.
(1)
The unknown u(x,t) depends on time t > 0 and a space variable x = (x1,...,xd) ‚ààRd.
In most of this chapter, we focus on the case of a single space variable (d = 1). The Ô¨Çuxes
f Œ± are given smooth (at least C2) functions. They represent the nonlinear convection of
some physical problem governed by (1). The linear operator L models the dissipation
process present in the physics. It is the inÔ¨Ånitesimal generator of a Markov semigroup
etL on L‚àû(Rd). The Markov property satisÔ¨Åed by any operator of the from T = etL is
summarized by the following list:
Comparison.
If a,b ‚ààL‚àûare such that a ‚©Ωb almost everywhere, then T a ‚©ΩT b holds
almost everywhere.
Contraction.
If a,b ‚ààL‚àûare such that b ‚àía ‚ààL1, then T b ‚àíT a ‚ààL1 and
‚à•T b ‚àíT a‚à•1 ‚©Ω‚à•b ‚àía‚à•1.

476
D. Serre
Conservation.
If a,b ‚ààL‚àûare such that b ‚àía ‚ààL1, then T b ‚àíT a ‚ààL1 and

Rd(T b ‚àíT a)dx =

Rd(b ‚àía)dx.
In addition, since the Ô¨Çux f does not explicitly depend on x and thus commutes with
translations, we shall ask that L (or T as well) share this property. In particular:
Constants.
If a is a constant, then T a ‚â°a.
The four properties described above, whose names (Comparison, Contraction, Conser-
vation, Constant) begin with ‚ÄúCo‚Äù, will be referred to as the Co-properties in the sequel.
Such linear semigroups have long been identiÔ¨Åed, see, for instance, [50]. Their generator
have the general form
Lu =

Œ±,Œ≤
aŒ±Œ≤‚àÇŒ±‚àÇŒ≤u +

Œ±
bŒ±‚àÇŒ±u + K ‚àóu ‚àíŒºu,
where the differential part is a weakly elliptic second-order operator with constant
coefÔ¨Åcients:
0d ‚©ΩA = (aŒ±Œ≤)1‚©ΩŒ±Œ≤‚©Ωd,
and the second part is a convolution by a nonnegative integrable kernel K, while the last
term is a multiplication by the constant
Œº :=

Rd K(y)dy.
The Ô¨Årst-order derivatives may be incorporated in the convective term, and thus will be
ignored: b = 0.
An important aspect of a Markov semigroup is its decay, or dispersion, property. For
instance, if L is the Laplacian , we have
eta

p ‚©Ωcp
‚à•a‚à•1
td/2p‚Ä≤ .
This decay still holds when we add a convolution term to the Laplacian, but it cannot hold
in the lack of differential terms. As a matter of fact, u ‚ÜíLu = K ‚àóu ‚àíŒºu is a bounded
operator on every Lp and thus generate a group of transformations that are automorphisms
within Lp. In particular, etLa belongs to Lp if and only if a does.
The reason that motivates us in considering the perturbation of the so-called inviscid
conservation law
‚àÇtu +
d

Œ±=1
‚àÇŒ±f Œ±(u) =

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
477
by such dissipation terms is two-fold. First of all, conservation laws in physics have the
general form ‚àÇtu + divq = 0, where the relation between the Ô¨Çux q and the state u may
be rather complex. In a coarse approximation (large scales), the Ô¨Çux may be represented
by a nonlinear local term f (u), but at smaller scales, additional terms must be taken in
account. For instance, gas dynamics is described at large scales by the Euler equations,
while a reÔ¨Åned description needs the Navier‚ÄìStokes system. Secondly, the scalar inviscid
conservation law generates a semigroup (see [39]) which displays the four Co-properties
above. In some instances, these properties are inherent to the physics under consideration,
and should not be destroyed by the addition of the dissipative operator L. Considering
small amplitude data, we see that etL must Ô¨Åll the four Co-properties, hence be a Markov
semigroup.
Other motivations have been given in the physics literature. For instance, the choice
(here d = 1)
K0(x) = 1
2e‚àí|x|,
Œº0 = 1
represents a coupling with an elliptic equation, since then K0 ‚àóu‚àíu = ‚àÇxq, where q is the
solution of ‚àí‚àÇ2
xq + q = ‚àÇxu. Such terms have been considered in radiative gas dynamics;
see [33,34] and the references herein. Of course, the present context of a scalar equation is
not relevant for radiative gas dynamics, but it provides a simpliÔ¨Åed model, in the same spirit
than when the Burgers equation was proposed as a simpliÔ¨Åcation of full gas dynamics.
Rosenau [52] considered the kernel K0 in a regularized version of the Chapman‚ÄìEnskog
expansion in hydrodynamics. The study of the Cauchy problem for (1) with Rosenau‚Äôs
operator began with [56].
A less simple, at a Ô¨Årst glance, modiÔ¨Åcation of (2) for which we still expect that the
four Co-properties hold in a suitable sense, is the relaxation model designed by Jin and
Xin [32]:
‚àÇtu + ‚àÇxv = 0,
(3)
‚àÇtv + Œ±2‚àÇxu = f (u) ‚àív.
(4)
The Ô¨Årst equation is the conservation law, where the Ô¨Çux v is related to u through the evo-
lution equation (4). If we ignore the ‚àÇxu term, the latter looks like an ODE v‚Ä≤ = f (u) ‚àív,
which forces v to relax to the equilibrium value f (u); then at equilibrium, we recover (2).
Actually, for stability reasons, we may not afford to ignore the ‚àÇxu term, where Œ± must be
large enough. This model looks much different from scalar ones. For instance, it requires
two data, one for each unknown. That it shares a lot of properties of scalar equations, due
to a weak decoupling, was Ô¨Årst observed by Hanouzet and Natalini [27].
Given a nonlinear model as above, the proof that the Cauchy problem is well posed
in L‚àûis more or less well known, although it is never a triviality. We reproduce it in
Section 1, emphasizing that the proof of uniqueness depends heavily on which equation
we are dealing with. As a matter of fact, the well-posedness of the convolution model
in L‚àû(if d = 1) and in BV (if d ‚©æ2) are new, and that in L‚àûremains an open question
when d ‚©æ2.

478
D. Serre
We show in the course of the proofs that the semigroups deÔ¨Åned by these Cauchy prob-
lem satisfy the Co-properties. It has long been remarked that the L1-contraction allows to
extend them continuously to the larger space L1 + L‚àû, in a unique way. However, it is
hard to say whether this extension gives weak solutions of the models, since the nonlinear
term divf (u) might not be a distribution if f is super-linear.
Besides the PDEs mentioned above, we also consider the discretization of the inviscid
conservation law by Ô¨Ånite difference schemes. They provide an other kind of dissipation
that, in academic cases like the Lax‚ÄìFriedrichs and Godunov schemes, gives rise to the
Co-properties. The corresponding shock proÔ¨Åles are often named ‚Äúdiscrete shock proÔ¨Åles‚Äù,
a rather inappropriate word since these proÔ¨Åles usually depend on the real variable.
The next step (Section 2) is the characterization of shock waves for each model. In
general, these are unique up to a space translation. Their existence is more or less trivial,
except in two cases. The question remains essentially open for the convolution model,
apart for the kernel K0 studied in [34,44]. The situation was uncomfortable for discrete
shock proÔ¨Åles: Their existence was claimed by Jennings [31], whose proof covered only
the so-called ‚Äúrational case‚Äù. We Ô¨Åx the state of the art in Section 6 by providing a proof
of the irrational case. Our argument may be viewed as a stability analysis of proÔ¨Åles with
respect to various data: The shock parameters as well as the scheme itself. Hence, it can be
used to extend Jennings‚Äô result to schemes that are monotone but not in a strict sense, like
Godunov‚Äôs. In the strictly monotonous situation, with the additional assumption that the
shock is noncharacteristic, we also obtain an exponential decay of the tail of the proÔ¨Åle.
We begin the stability analysis of shock proÔ¨Åles in Section 3. When the values taken by
the initial data lie between the states u‚àíand u+, the L1-stability is proved by arguments
taken form dynamical systems theory: compactness of trajectories, œâ-limit set, Lasalle‚Äôs
invariance principle. Only when exploiting the latter have we to make a case-by-case study.
The general idea is due to Osher and Ralston [51].
The situation is more involved when the data takes values outside the shock interval. We
show that L1-stability may fail in the borderline inviscid case when the shock is character-
istic on at least one side. This result is optimal, since we also prove the stability whenever
the shock is noncharacteristic, that is Lax‚Äô shock inequalities are strict.
For models with L Ã∏= 0, Freist√ºhler and the author found that the L1-stability of shock
proÔ¨Åles is implied by that of constant states under zero-mass disturbance. The latter prop-
erty is analyzed in details in Section 4. In some sense, it is the most technical part since
we really have to work on a case-by-case basis. The stability is induced by the disper-
sion properties of the linear semigroup etL, which may be pretty strong (L = ) or weak
(convolution model, relaxation).
Section 5 is devoted to the multidimensional viscous case. Since the shift of a given
proÔ¨Åle does not belong to the same class modulo L1(Rd) as the proÔ¨Åle itself, the total mass
of the initial disturbance becomes a meaningful invariant of the problem. Its nonvanishing
causes a disturbance of the shock front that can be represented at the leading order by a
solution of the heat equation in Rd‚àí1, which enhanced diffusion. A pretty good result has
been established by Hoff and Zumbrun [29], following a preliminary study by Goodman
and Miller [22]. Remaining at a qualitative level, we construct the approximate solution
to which the actual one is asymptotic. Of course, because of the lack of compactness, the

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
479
stability result is only known under additional restrictions such as smallness in weighted
spaces. Thus a lot of interesting questions remain open.
Our last Section 7 concerns the Initial-boundary value problem. The waves under con-
sideration are the so-called ‚Äúboundary layers‚Äù. Their stability analysis follows more or less
the same guidelines than that of shock proÔ¨Åles. We give a new proof of the stability of
constant in the outgoing case, by using a simple comparison argument with respect to the
characteristic case. This idea actually works in several space dimensions, where the result
seems to be new.
1. The nonlinear semigroup
We are interested in the Cauchy problem for (1), where the initial datum a belongs to L‚àû.
We wish to construct a semigroup for (1), which enjoys the four Co-properties. The situa-
tion may differ a lot when we vary the choice of the operator L.
1.1. The viscous conservation law
We begin with the viscous equation:
‚àÇtu + divf (u) = u.
(5)
The choice of the Laplace operator  is not restrictive at all, since every elliptic operator
of the form

heat equation ‚àÇtu = u. The latter generates a (linear) C0-semigroup (Ht)t‚©æ0 on Lp
(1 ‚©Ωp ‚©Ω‚àû), which satisÔ¨Åes the four Co-properties. This semigroup is nothing but the
convolution by the Heat kernel:

Dispersion property.

1.2. The inviscid conservation law
The inviscid conservation law
‚àÇtu + divf (u) = 0,
(14)

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
483
faces the problems of shock formation and nonuniqueness of distributional solutions.
Shock formation is caused by the blow-up in the solution of the Ricatti equation along
characteristic

‚àÇt + f ‚Ä≤(u)‚àÇx
	
(‚àÇxu) + f ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(u)(‚àÇxu)2 = 0.
This equation, supplemented by the fact that u is constant along characteristics dx/dt =
f ‚Ä≤(u), shows that most of C1-solutions blow up in Ô¨Ånite time.
For this reason, we must consider distributional solutions, which are assumed bounded,
at least locally, in order that all the terms in the equation make sense. Typically, solutions
exhibit discontinuities across hypersurfaces. Piecewise smooth functions satisfy (14) in the
weak sense if and only if they are classical solutions away from their discontinuities, the
latter satisfying the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot condition

f (u+) ‚àíf (u‚àí)
	
¬∑ ŒΩ = s(u+ ‚àíu‚àí).
(15)
Here, u¬± are the limits of u at x(t) from both sides of a discontinuity locus of Œì (t). The
unit normal to this hypersurface is oriented from the minus side towards the plus side, and
is denoted by ŒΩ. Last, s is the normal velocity of Œì (t): it is deÔ¨Åned by
sx(t)	 = ŒΩx(t)	dx
dt ,
x(t) ‚ààŒì (t).
One often writes [g(u)] for an expression g(u+) ‚àíg(u‚àí). For instance, (15) reads

The Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot condition (15) does not depend on the orientation of Œì . In one
space dimension, we choose the natural orientation ŒΩ = +1, meaning that

As it has been well known since the seminal work by Kruzkhov [39], weak solutions are
far from being unique, and one must select a solution through the entropy criterion. The
rigorous formulation of this criterion is that the solution u satisÔ¨Åes the integral inequalities

R

Rd

|u ‚àík|‚àÇtœÜ + sgn(u ‚àík)


¬∑ ‚àáxœÜ
	
dx dt
+


a(x) ‚àík
œÜ(x,0)dx ‚©æ0
(16)
for every constant k ‚ààR and every nonnegative test function œÜ ‚ààD+(Rd √ó R). Of course,
if we are interested in local-in-time solutions, say on a time interval (0,T ), then the integral
inequalities should be considered for test functions with support in Rd √ó (‚àí‚àû,T ) only.
The solutions satisfying (16) are called entropy solutions.

484
D. Serre
An important remark is that, whenever u is bounded, at least locally in space and time,
then (16) contains the fact that u solves (1) in the distributional sense (take k > ‚à•u‚à•‚àû, and
next k < ‚àí‚à•u‚à•‚àû). But of course, it tells much more. We shall only sketch the proof of the
following well-known result.
THEOREM 1 (Kruzkhov [39]). Let a ‚ààL‚àû(Rd) and T > 0 be given. Then there exists a
unique locally bounded function u in Rd √ó R, satisfying (16) and
u ‚ààC[0,‚àû);L1
loc
Rd		.
In addition, this solution is bounded and the map a ‚ÜíSta := u(t) deÔ¨Ånes a nonlinear
semigroup which satisÔ¨Åes the four Co-properties mentioned in the Introduction.
COMMENTS.
1. The fact that the semigroup is L1-contractive had already been noticed by Volpert [73]
in the context of BV data. This fact motivated Kruzkhov in his study.
2. The L1-contractivity, when an equation exhibits a scaling invariance, is the source of
a BV regularization, as shown by B√©nilan and Crandall [4]. For instance, the Burgers
equation ‚àÇtu + ‚àÇx(u2/2) = 0, in one space dimension, has the property that u(t)2 is
of bounded variation whenever the datum a is integrable, with
TV

u(t)2	
‚©Ω2‚à•a‚à•1
t
.
3. Other selection criteria have been considered for (14) by LeFloch and co-workers
(see [37] and references herein). They may be relevant for speciÔ¨Åc problems, mostly
in systems rather than scalar equations. SigniÔ¨Åcant examples include nonstrictly hy-
perbolic systems and cases where elliptic regions are enclosed in domains of hy-
perbolicity. In the scalar case, such nonclassical solutions may not enjoy the four
Co-properties. Their uniqueness has not been proved yet. In particular, we still ig-
nore whether they deÔ¨Åne a semigroup in any sense. The most important feature for
us is that they are not expected to satisfy the L1-contraction; this is why we shall not
consider them in the sequel.
SKETCH OF PROOF OF THEOREM 1.

1.3. The relaxation model

The technique employed in Section 1.1 (Picard iteration for a contractive map) applies

D. Serre
In order to extend the solution for all times, we need an a priori estimate in the Sup-
norm. This one must be obtained through the maximum principle.2 Following [9], such a
maximum principle must hold simultaneously for the principal part
‚àÇtu + ‚àÇxv = 0,
‚àÇtv + Œ±2‚àÇxu = 0,
and the ODE part
‚àÇtu = 0,
‚àÇtv = f (u) ‚àív.
Let K be a domain in the plane that is positively invariant for both subsystems. The PDE
part imposes (see [9]) that K is a rectangle Iw √ó Iz = [wmin,wmax] √ó [zmin,zmax] in the
characteristic coordinates (w,z). In the latter, the ODE part becomes
‚àÇtw = G(w,z),
‚àÇtz = ‚àíG(w,z).
Hence, the invariance of K amounts to the inequalities
G(wmax,z) ‚©Ω0,
G(wmin,z) ‚©æ0,
z ‚ààIz,
(21)
and
G(w,zmin) ‚©Ω0,
G(w,zmax) ‚©æ0,
w ‚ààIz.
(22)
In particular, G must vanish at upper-left and lower-right corners, meaning that the vertices
(umin,vmin) and (umax,vmax) belong to the equilibrium curve
Œì :=

u,f (u)
	
;u ‚ààR

.
Whenever (21) and (22) hold and the initial datum (a,b) takes its values in the domain K,
the local solution remains in K and is therefore bounded. Since its life time was bounded
by below by a constant T0 depending only on the Sup-norm of (a,b), the solution may be
extended for every time t > 0; the solution is global in time.
When dealing with the relaxation model, which is not exactly what we think immediately
about when we speak of scalar conservation laws, we need to interpret the Co-properties
in terms of solutions with data in a box K as above only. Moreover, the order relation
in (L‚àû)2 and the L1 structure have to be understood in the following sense, introduced by
Hanouzet and Natalini [27]:
Comparison.
We say that a pair (a,b) of bounded functions is smaller than an other
one (A,B) if w(a,b) ‚©Ωw(A,B) and z(a,b) ‚©Ωz(A,B) almost everywhere. Let us write
(a,b) ‚â∫(A,B). In that case, the comparison property for the relaxation model is
(a,b),(A,B):R ‚ÜíK and (a,b) ‚â∫(A,B)
-‚áí
(u,v) ‚â∫(U,V ),
(23)
2We are not aware of such estimates, obtained by other means.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
489
where (u,v) and (U,V ) are the corresponding solutions.
In terms of w and z, which satisfy transport equations coupled by nonlinear source
terms, this amounts to saying that, within the box K, G is nondecreasing with respect to z,
while nonincreasing with respect to w. This exactly require the so-called subcharacteristic
condition, which limits by below the choice of the parameter Œ±:
Œ± ‚©æsupf ‚Ä≤(u)
;u ‚àà[umin,umax].
(24)
Because borderline cases often rise major difÔ¨Åculties or pathologies, we usually assume the
strict subcharacteristic condition, where the inequality is strict. Then the equilibrium curve
can be written, within K, as the graph {z = Œ∏(w)} of a smooth function such that Œ∏‚Ä≤ > 0.
That relation can be rewritten in the similar form {w = Œ∏‚àí1(z)}. Since G increases along
horizontal lines (in variables (w,z)) and decreases along vertical ones, we obtain that G is
positive on the lower-left side of Œì and is negative on the upper-right side. Hence, the in-
equalities (21) and (22) may be viewed as consequences of the subcharacteristic condition.
Contraction.
The integral form of the nonhomogeneous linear problem show immedi-
ately that if a, b, g and h are integrable, then u(t) and z(t) are so, with

Notice the important fact that the conserved integral is a Lipschitz map with unit Lipschitz

Constants.
The only constants preserved by the relaxation model are the equilibrium
constants (a,b), that is those belonging to Œì .
Well-posedness.
As mentioned above, an initial datum taking values in a rectangle K
yields a global-in-time solution that remains in K. The fact that the solution is unique in
the class L‚àû
loc(R+;L‚àû) comes from the L1-contraction property. The only point that is
not obvious is the following fact: given two bounded solutions (w,z) and (W,Z) of the
Cauchy problem, such that W(0)‚àíw(0) and Z(0)‚àíz(0) are integrable, then W(t)‚àíw(t)
and Z(t) ‚àíz(t) remain integrable forever. To do so, we remark that
 X
‚àíX
W(x,t) ‚àíw(x,t)
 +
Z(x,t) ‚àíz(x,t)
	dx
is bounded by
 X+Œ±t
‚àíX‚àíŒ±t
W(x,0) ‚àíw(x,0)
 +

and therefore by
W(0) ‚àíw(0)

Z(0) ‚àíz(0)

Passing to the limit as X goes to inÔ¨Ånity, we obtain the desired result. In particular, we
justify the contraction property.
To prove the conservation property, we play the same game, knowing from above that
W(t) ‚àíw(t) and Z(t) ‚àíz(t) remain integrable. The difference
 X

equals the sum of the integrals of ¬±(G(W,Z) ‚àíG(w,z)) on the triangles T¬± of vertices

know that the integrals along the horizontal sections of T¬± tend to zero as X ‚Üí+‚àû.
Besides, this section integrals are uniformly bounded. Applying the Dominated conver-
gence theorem, we infer that the integrals over T¬± tend to zero. Hence the conservation.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws

COMMENT. When the equilibrium model is a system of n ‚©æ2 equations, most of the
features of the scalar case drop out. For instance, the comparison and the contraction prop-
erties do not hold anymore. A maximum principle persists in a few speciÔ¨Åc case, mostly
when n = 2. It was studied in details in [9] at the level of systems of viscous conservation
laws. When it holds true, it extends, in a nontrivial way, to the Jin‚ÄìXin relaxation of the
system [63], and allows to extend the solution of the Cauchy problem to all positive times.
A thorough account of the theory of general relaxation models is contained in [49].
1.4. The Rosenau model
We Ô¨Ånish this section by the study of the Cauchy problem for the generalized Rosenau
model
‚àÇtu + divf (u) = K ‚àóu ‚àíu,
(28)
where the nonnegative kernel K has been normalized so that

Rd K(y)dy = 1,
(29)
giving formally the mass conservation3 for L1-solutions.
Loss of smoothness.
In this rather complex model, the diffusion term K ‚àóu ‚àíu does
not prevent from shock formation in Ô¨Ånite time, for general data, though it does for small
and smooth data. We refer to [33,34,41,44,56] for a general study of the Cauchy problem,
including shock formation and existence of shock proÔ¨Åles. To explain what is going on,
we Ô¨Årst remark that L := K ‚àó‚àí1 = (K ‚àíŒ¥)‚àóis a bounded operator on every Lebesgue or
Sobolev space. Therefore, it generates a uniformly continuous (semi)group etL. In some
sense, the diffusion is a lower order term, which cannot inÔ¨Çuence the qualitative feature of
the principal part ‚àÇtu + divf (u).
Let us give a convincing example of blow-up, by choosing d = 1 and the Burgers‚Äô Ô¨Çux
f (u) = u2/2. Let u be a smooth solution of
‚àÇtu + u‚àÇxu = K ‚àóu ‚àíu.
Writing v for ‚àÇxu, and differentiating, we obtain
Dtv + v2 + v = K ‚àóv,
where Dt := ‚àÇt + u‚àÇx is the convective derivative. If a = u(0) is integrable, then
u(t) remains so, as we shall see in a moment, and therefore m(t) := infx v(x,t) ‚©Ω0 ‚©Ω
3We shall see later on that the vanishing of the Ô¨Årst moments must be imposed when dealing with L‚àû-solutions.

492
D. Serre
supx v(x,t) =: S(t). We easily obtain the following differential inequalities for
both m and S:
m‚Ä≤ + m2 + m ‚©ΩS,
S‚Ä≤ + S2 ‚©Ω0.
Let M be the solution of the Ricatti equation M‚Ä≤ + M2 = 0 with data S(0). We have
0 ‚©ΩS ‚©ΩM ‚©ΩS(0). Therefore,
m‚Ä≤ + m2 + m ‚©ΩM
and
(m ‚àíM)‚Ä≤ + (m ‚àíM)2 + (2M + 1)(m ‚àíM) ‚©Ω0.
Since m ‚àíM ‚©Ωm ‚àíS ‚©Ω0, we deduce
(m ‚àíM)‚Ä≤ + (m ‚àíM)2 +

2S(0) + 1
	
(m ‚àíM) ‚©Ω0,
where (m ‚àíM)(0) = m(0) ‚àíS(0). It is well known that if this initial data is less than
the smallest root ‚àí2S(0) ‚àí1 of the polynomial X2 + (2S(0) + 1)X, then m ‚àíM must
blow-up, towards ‚àí‚àû, in Ô¨Ånite time. Hence, if
inf
x ‚àÇxa + sup
x
‚àÇxa < ‚àí1,
the space derivative of u blows-up in Ô¨Ånite time.
Global smooth solutions.
On the contrary, smallness of smooth initial data ensures the
existence of a global and smooth solution, as we show now. The above analysis showed
that the supremum of ‚àÇxu remains bounded above, by 1/t for instance. Anticipating on the
maximum principle, we have ‚à•u‚à•‚àû‚©Ω‚à•a‚à•‚àû. Besides, the estimate

Hence, the space derivative of u remains bounded. Equation (28) shows that the time deriv-
ative is bounded as well. At last, one can prove, as in the diffusionless case, that the bound-
edness of the Ô¨Årst derivatives allows to propagate the smoothness of the initial datum.
Construction of the semigroup.
Because of the possibility of shock formation, a semi-
group cannot be deÔ¨Åned within spaces like H 1(Rd), C1(Rd). Reasonable spaces are those
already considered in the diffusionless case: Lp-spaces or BV(Rd). Because we are inter-
ested in the Co-properties, we shall work within L1, L‚àûand their sum L1 + L‚àû. A spe-
cial interest is given to piecewise smooth solutions, since they encode some of the most
signiÔ¨Åcant features. In particular, discontinuities of the solutions obey exactly the same
Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot condition as those of (2).
Because of the lack of smoothing effect of the Rosenau diffusion, it seems possible
to construct solutions which behave locally in the same way as piecewise smooth so-
lutions of (2). In particular, (28) must admit unphysical solutions whose discontinuities,
though satisfying the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot condition, are not admissible with respect to (2).
Therefore, we restrict the notion of solution in exactly the same way as in the diffusionless
case. We say that a locally bounded measurable function u(x,t) is an admissible (or an
entropy) solution of the Cauchy problem for (28) if it satisÔ¨Åes the integral inequalities

choosing large positive or negative values of k, we obtain that admissible solutions do
satisfy (28) in the distributional sense.

We are now reduced to proving the integrability of v(t)‚àíu(t), when b ‚àía is integrable.
It has not yet been addressed, up to our knowledge. Several authors content themselves
with the construction of a semigroup, extending by continuity the L1-semigroup, thanks to
its contraction property.
A Ô¨Årst important case is that of integrable data, because the vanishing viscosity method
(see below) gives integrable solutions. Therefore, we obtain the uniqueness for integrable
data, but only within the restricted class of entropy solutions that are integrable in space.
This is a bit weaker than expected.

We summarize our analysis in the following statement.
THEOREM 2. Let K be a nonnegative, integrable kernel, with unit mass. The Cauchy
problem for the Rosenau model (28) is well posed in the following spaces:
‚Ä¢ in L1(Rd) ‚à©L‚àû(Rd), in every space dimension;
‚Ä¢ in (L1 + BV) ‚à©L‚àû(Rd) if H is integrable. For instance, a radial K satisfying
K ‚ààL1((1 + |x|)dx) works;
‚Ä¢ in L‚àû(Rd) if d = 1 and K ‚ààL1((1 + |x|)dx).
In the sequel, we denote by (Rt)‚©æ0 the semigroup generated by the Rosenau model.
General data
‚Ä¢ When the data is bounded but does not belong to L1 + BV, the above procedure
does not work. Also, the procedure employed in the diffusionless case is inefÔ¨Åcient

D. Serre
because of the lack of Ô¨Ånite propagation velocity. One way to construct an entropy
solution for general L‚àûdata would be to use DiPerna‚Äôs theory of measure valued
solutions (see [14]), together with the improvement by Szepessy [69] to pass to the
limit in the viscosity method. We leave this question open, with the remark that the
uniqueness is already an unsolved problem.

2. Shocks
In the most general acception of this word, a planar shock is a bounded traveling wave of
the form
u(x,t) = U(x ¬∑ ŒΩ ‚àíst),
having Ô¨Ånite limits on each sides:
U(‚àí‚àû) =: u‚àí,
U(+‚àû) =: u+.
The number s is the normal velocity of the shock while ŒΩ ‚ààSd‚àí1 is its direction of propa-
gation. A standing shock corresponds to s = 0. It is always possible to restrict to standing
shocks by using a moving frame, that is by changing variables as (x,t) ‚Üí(x + stŒΩ,t),
yielding
(‚àÇt,‚àáx) ‚Üí(‚àÇt ‚àísŒΩ ¬∑ ‚àáx,‚àáx).
We shall see later on that every shock must satisfy the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot relations (15).
Therefore, the corresponding function
uinv(x,t) :=
u‚àí,
x ¬∑ ŒΩ < st,
u+,
x ¬∑ ŒΩ > st
is a discontinuous solution of the inviscid model. We call it an inviscid discontinuity and
denote it shortly (u‚àí,u+;sŒΩ).

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
501
The shock proÔ¨Åle U obeys to a functional equation. When the latter is an ordinary differ-
ential equation and is resolved in terms of the highest derivative of U, the proÔ¨Åle is smooth
and provides an internal structure of the inviscid discontinuity.
A common feature of shock proÔ¨Åles for scalar equations satisfying the Co-properties is
the monotony. This monotony must be read at the level of the Riemann invariants w and z
in the relaxation model. The monotony of the proÔ¨Åle is intimately related to the underlying
dissipation structure. In general, the dissipation property is due to the particular way the
model approaches the inviscid equation; for instance, it is present in the viscosity ‚àÇ2
xu, or in
the Rosenau operator K ‚àóu‚àíu. However, in the inviscid case, the dissipation cannot come
from an ‚Äúexternal term‚Äù, and thus must be present in the shock itself, through the Lax shock
inequality. This is why we shall meet counterexamplesto the monotony in the inviscid case.
As we shall see in the next section, such ‚Äúbad‚Äù shocks may have poor stability properties.
2.1. Inviscid shocks
We begin with a characterization of the traveling waves in the inviscid case. Denot-
ing f (v;ŒΩ) := ŒΩ ¬∑ f (v) and g(v) := f (v;ŒΩ) ‚àísv, the proÔ¨Åle is a standing wave of the
one-dimensional conservation law
‚àÇtU + ‚àÇxg(U) = 0.
In particular, g ‚ó¶U is constant (say g ‚ó¶U ‚â°¬Øg) and, since U must satisfy the Kruzkhov
entropy inequalities,
x ‚Üí

¬Øg ‚àíg(k)
	
sgn

U(x) ‚àík
	
is nonincreasing for every real number k. For instance, if a (respectively b) is an essential
value of u at some point x (respectively y), and if b Ã∏= a, we obtain an Oleinik-type infor-
mation: If (b ‚àía)(y ‚àíx) > 0 (respectively < 0), then g ‚©æ¬Øg (respectively g ‚©Ω¬Øg) between
a and b.
Assume now that U takes three distinct essential values a,b,c in this order. If b is not
in the interval between a and c, say b > max(a,c), then g ‚©æ¬Øg on (a,b) while g ‚©Ω¬Øg on
(c,b), hence g ‚â°¬Øg on (max(a,c),b). Therefore, making the generic assumption that g is
not constant on any nontrivial interval, we see that U must be monotonous:
PROPOSITION 1. Assume that f (¬∑;ŒΩ) is not afÔ¨Åne on any nontrivial interval. Then the
proÔ¨Åles of planar shock waves are (not strictly) monotonous. In particular, if u‚àí= u+,
then U is constant.
Assuming without loss of generality that u‚àí‚©Ωu+, the graph of f (¬∑;ŒΩ) lies above the
chord between u‚àíand u+.
REMARKS.
‚Ä¢ The generic assumption on the Ô¨Çux f is reminiscent to various approaches in the study
of scalar conservation laws. In one space dimension, it ensures the strong conver-
gence in the viscosity method, thanks to a compensated-compactness argument (see

502
D. Serre
Tartar [71,72]). Given in a quantitative form, it yields regularity properties through
the well-known kinetic formulation (see Lions et al. [43]).
‚Ä¢ As a matter of fact, the inviscid model is reversible at the level of smooth solutions,
since the change of variables (x,t) ‚Üí(‚àíx,‚àít) preserves the equation. However, it
is crucial to observe that this model becomes irreversible at the level of discontinuous
solutions. If a discontinuity (u‚àí,u+;sŒΩ) and the reverse one (u+,u‚àí;sŒΩ) are admis-
sible, then the Oleinik criterion tells that f (¬∑;ŒΩ) is afÔ¨Åne along the interval between
u‚àíand u+.
‚Ä¢ More generally, if f (¬∑;ŒΩ) is afÔ¨Åne along some interval J, then any measurable func-
tion U valued in J yields a traveling wave. In this rather trivial situation, nothing deep
can be said.
‚Ä¢ On the contrary, if f (¬∑;ŒΩ) is convex between u‚àíand u+, then the discontinuity
(u‚àí,u+;sŒΩ) is a shock if and only if it satisÔ¨Åes both u+ ‚©Ωu‚àíand the Rankine‚Äì
Hugoniot relation.
In generic situations, the monotonicity of U and the constancy of g ‚ó¶U imply that
U is piecewise constant with Ô¨Ånitely many discontinuities. Each discontinuity in U is a
shock by itself, and we could consider only those which take two values only, thus named
u‚àíand u+. Even with this restriction, we may encounter, as soon as f (¬∑;ŒΩ) has inÔ¨Çex-
ion points, degenerate situations where the graph of f (¬∑;ŒΩ) meets the chord somewhere
(say at c) between a and b. In such a situation, the shock must be understood as two
shocks of equal velocities s glued together, the Ô¨Årst one linking a to c, the second one link-
ing c to b. Finally, the only situation where U cannot be decomposed in more elementary
blocks is when U takes only the values u‚àíand u+ and the graph of f (¬∑;ŒΩ) does not meet
the chord. When u+ Ã∏= u‚àí(to avoid triviallity), this is what we shall call a strict shock in
the sequel. Hence we have
U(x) =
u‚àí,
x < x0,
u+,
x > x0,
with the following cases, symmetric to each other:
‚Ä¢ either u‚àí< u+ and the graph of f (¬∑;ŒΩ) in the interval (u‚àí,u+) lies strictly above
the chord,
‚Ä¢ or u‚àí> u+ and the graph of f (¬∑;ŒΩ) in the interval (u‚àí,u+) lies strictly below
the chord.
The Oleinik criterion implies immediately the Lax shock inequalities:
fu(u+;ŒΩ) ‚©Ωs ‚©Ωfu(u‚àí;ŒΩ).
(45)
When these inequalities are strict, one speaks of a noncharacteristic shock, or a Lax shock.
Otherwise, it is characteristic. Many people use the term ‚Äúshock wave‚Äù in the case of
noncharacteristic shocks only. But in the sequel, we shall not need to distinguish the char-
acteristic case from the noncharacteristic one.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
503
2.2. Viscous shocks
The viscous case is extremely simple. With the notations of the previous paragraph, the
proÔ¨Åle must satisfy the nonlinear ODE
U‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ = (g ‚ó¶U)‚Ä≤
in the distributional sense. Integrating once, we obtain
U‚Ä≤ = g ‚ó¶U ‚àícst.
By induction, U is a smooth function, say of class Ck+1 if f is Ck. Since U has limits u¬±
at ¬±‚àû, we deduce that the constant of integration equals both of g(u¬±), hence
g(u+) = g(u‚àí).
This is nothing but the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot relation (15).
Since g ‚àíg(u‚àí) has a constant sign between two consecutive zeroes, and since u¬± are
zeroes of this function, we see that an inviscid planar discontinuity admits a viscous proÔ¨Åle
if, and only if, u‚àíand u+ are consecutive zeroes, and if the sign of g ‚àíg(u‚àí) equals that
of u+ ‚àíu‚àíin the corresponding interval. This is the Oleinik inequality for is a strict shock.
In conclusion, we have the following:
PROPOSITION 2. An inviscid discontinuity admits a viscous proÔ¨Åle if and only if it is a
strict shock.
When it exists, a viscous proÔ¨Åle is monotonous and is unique up to a shift. Its behav-
ior at inÔ¨Ånity depends of the nature of the shock. For a noncharacteristic shock, the pro-
Ô¨Åle U tends exponentially fast to its limits u¬±. But if it is characteristic, for instance at
right (fu(u+;ŒΩ) = s), then the decay of U ‚àíu+ is at best algebraic; it is of order 1/x if
fuu(u+;ŒΩ) Ã∏= 0.
In other words, one may say that, up to the decomposition of a discontinuity in elemen-
tary ones, the admissibility condition for a shock can be interpreted as the requirement that
it be realized as the limit of traveling wave solutions in the viscous approximation
‚àÇtu + divf (u) = Œµu,
As a matter of fact, a shock proÔ¨Åle U yields the following solution
uŒµ(x,t) = U
x ¬∑ ŒΩ ‚àíst
Œµ

which is a good approximation of the inviscid shock. It is clear that uŒµ tends pointwise
to u¬±, according to the sign of x ¬∑ ŒΩ ‚àíst.

504
D. Serre
2.3. Relaxation shocks
In the case of a relaxation model, say the Jin‚ÄìXin model, the proÔ¨Åle consists in a
pair (U,V ), while the space dimension is one. The differential equation that it satisÔ¨Åes is
V ‚Ä≤ = sU‚Ä≤,
Œ±2U‚Ä≤ = sV ‚Ä≤ + f (U) ‚àíV.
Eliminating V , we obtain the same equation than in the viscous case, up to a scaling,


Notice the importance of the subcharacteristic condition (24), which must be fulÔ¨Ålled on
the whole interval [u‚àí,u+] (or [u+,u‚àí] if needed). From the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot condi-
tion, s = f ‚Ä≤(¬Øu) for some ¬Øu between u‚àíand u+. When (24) fails on some interval I, there
exist shocks with u¬± ‚ààI, for which Œ±2 < s2. Such shocks do not admit relaxation proÔ¨Åles,
while the nonadmissible discontinuities (u+,u‚àí;s) do! Notice also the degenerate case

2.4. Radiative shocks
We shall call radiative proÔ¨Åle the proÔ¨Åle U of a discontinuity (u‚àí,u+;s) for the gen-
eralized Rosenau model, because the exact Rosenau model, whose kernel K is given by

K(Œæ) = 1/(1 + |Œæ|2), may serve as a baby model for radiative gases.
There is no general theory for the existence of radiative proÔ¨Åles. Up to our knowledge,
the literature consists in the papers [56] by Schochet and Tadmor, and [34] by Kawashima
and Nishibata. In both papers, the kernel is Rosenau‚Äôs one and the existence is studied
through the differential equation
f (U)‚Ä≤ ‚àísU‚Ä≤ = Q‚Ä≤,
Q‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ ‚àíQ + U‚Ä≤ = 0.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
505
In the Ô¨Årst paper, the Ô¨Çux g is any convex function but the amplitude [u] of the shock is
limited by some threshold. In the second paper, the Ô¨Çux is the simplest one u2/2, but the
amplitude is arbitrary. It is proven that whenever the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot relation and the
Oleinik condition u+ < u‚àíhold, there exists a unique (up to a shift) radiative proÔ¨Åle.
The proÔ¨Åle cannot be of class C‚àû; it is of class Ck where k = k(|[u]|) is a decreasing
function. As a matter of fact, the proÔ¨Åle is discontinuous as [u] is large enough. This is the
origin of the restriction of the shock strength in [56], since Schochet and Tadmor did not
consider discontinuous proÔ¨Åles. The lack of regularity is due to the lack of invertibility of
the map u ‚Üíf (u) ‚àísu between u‚àíand u+.
It must be emphasized that discontinuous proÔ¨Åles are perfectly relevant for this model,
whose well-posedness holds in spaces of discontinuous functions (see Section 1.4.) Such
proÔ¨Åles have at most one discontinuity, which turns out to satisfy the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot
relation and the Oleinik condition. Hence, the discontinuity of a radiative proÔ¨Åle is itself
an inviscid shock! This phenomenon reminds us the case of shock proÔ¨Åles in full gas dy-
namics, in presence of heat conduction but without viscosity; in this situation, Gilbarg [20]
showed that strong shocks admit discontinuous proÔ¨Åles, where the discontinuity is an ad-
missible shock of the isothermal gas dynamics.
Consistency of Rosenau approximation.
The natural way to approach an inviscid scalar
conservation law by a Rosenau model is to take a diffusion operator LŒµ with

(49)
Hence, a necessary condition for the existence of a radiative proÔ¨Åle for every inviscid shock
is that the Ô¨Årst moments of K vanish.
Assuming (48), the Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot relation becomes a necessary condition for the
existence of a radiative proÔ¨Åle, thanks to (49). Similarly, applying the entropy inequali-
ties (30) to a radiative proÔ¨Åle, we obtain

OPEN PROBLEM 1. Assume that the kernel K satisÔ¨Åes (29) and (48). Prove that every
strict inviscid shock (u‚àí,u+;sŒΩ) admits a radiative proÔ¨Åle.
We give here a partial result, generalizing that was observed in the viscous and relaxation
approximations.

PROPOSITION 3. Let K be a nonnegative kernel satisfying (29) and (48). Then
(i) radiative shock proÔ¨Åles are monotonous;
(ii) given an inviscid shock, there exists at most one radiative proÔ¨Åle, up to a shift.
PROOF. We may assume that the space dimension is one, and that the shock is stationary.
Let U be a radiative proÔ¨Åle. For any real number h, the shifted œÑhU is another proÔ¨Åle. Since
both U and œÑhU are admissible stationary solutions of the Rosenau model, (30) gives

which implies that œÑhU ‚àíU has a constant sign. Since its integral equals h[u], we deduce
that h‚àí1(œÑhU ‚àíU) has the sign of [u]. Letting h going to zero, we obtain the monotony.
The same argument can be used for uniqueness. Replacing œÑhU by any proÔ¨Åle V in the
computation above, we see that V ‚àíU has a constant sign. Thus V ‚àíœÑhU has a constant
sign for every h ‚ààR. The uniqueness follows immediately.

3. Shock stability (I)
We now raise the main question of this paper, namely that of L1-stability of the shock
proÔ¨Åles. Let U(x ¬∑ ŒΩ ‚àíst) be a traveling wave of a scalar diffusive models, as consid-
ered above. Given an initial datum a, being an integrable perturbation of U(¬∑ŒΩ), that is,7
a ‚ààU + L1(Rd), we already know that
t ‚Üí
Sta ‚àíU(¬∑ŒΩ ‚àíst)

1
is nonincreasing. This strongly suggests the following stability property, which was
Ô¨Årst considered by Osher and Ralston [51] in the context of one-dimensional viscous
shock fronts:
lim
t‚Üí+‚àû
Sta ‚àíU(¬∑ŒΩ ‚àíst)

1 = 0?
(50)
7This assumption must interpreted in terms of the model under consideration. For instance, in the Rosenau
model with d ‚©æ2, TV(a) should also be Ô¨Ånite.

508
D. Serre
We shall give a complete answer to this question in the one-dimensional case, the multi-
dimensional problem being essentially open.
Warning.
In the sequel, we try to remain at a general level as long as possible, without
distinguishing the model under consideration. It must be understood that in the Shi‚ÄìJin
relaxation model, whose unknown is a pair (u,v), the L1-norm is deÔ¨Åned in terms of the
Riemann invariants (w,z), since the corresponding distance is that which is contracted
along the evolution. Similarly, a relaxation proÔ¨Åle is a pair (U,V ), and when we speak
of ‚Äúthe mass‚Äù of the initial disturbance (a ‚àíU,b ‚àíV ), we mean the integral of a ‚àíU,
since that is the conserved quantity along the evolution. At last, the comparison principle,
denoted above by ‚â∫, does not concern (u,v), but (w,z).
Other stability results.
Our goal is not to treat stability in other functional spaces, like
Hilbert ones (L2 or other Sobolev spaces), with or without weights. As mentioned in the
Introduction, we are motivated by the important physical signiÔ¨Åcance of the L1-norm and
the fact that it is the norm for which the semigroup of the equation is nonexpansive. On an
abstract level, Bruck and Baillon have long been studying nonexpansive semigroups and
mappings in Banach spaces (see [2,3] for instance), establishing numerous deep theorems.
But their results more or less assume that the norm has some kind of uniform convexity,
a fact that is not true at all in L1. On a more explicit side, one would not underestimate
the voluminous literature where shock stability is obtained in Hilbert spaces through en-
ergy estimates and/or spectral analysis. One may date its beginning with the famous paper
by Sattinger [55]. This method always assumes some kind of smallness of the initial dis-
turbance, some decay rate of the data as x ‚Üí¬±‚àû, and often a special structure of the
nonlinear Ô¨Çux f . This Ô¨Çaw is a cheap price to pay for much more precise results, includ-
ing accurate decay rates as time go to inÔ¨Ånity. Also, the method has enough versatility to
be applied in multidimensional situations, for which our approach remains inefÔ¨Åcient (see
Section 5 for a convincing example). Let us mention that signiÔ¨Åcant difÔ¨Åculties arise when
one considers systems of conservation laws instead of a scalar equation. Some of them may
be observed at the level of the linearized operator L around the shock proÔ¨Åle U. Even in the
simplest case considered by Sattinger (strict Lax shock, exponentially decaying data), it is
not any more possible to shift the essential spectrum of L strictly to the left of the imaginary
axis. As a by-product, the null eigenvalue Œª = 0 associated to the equation LdU/dx = 0
remains embedded in the continuous spectrum, meaning that the translational invariance
cannot be decoupled from the dynamics. This fact reÔ¨Çects at the level of the mass trans-
port: the excess mass

R(a ‚àíU)dx cannot be absorbed any more by a shift of the proÔ¨Åle.
Therefore, it becomes necessary to take in account diffusion waves associated to the char-
acteristics that emerge from the shock. Liu [45] gave a neat description of the expected
asymptotics, which was rigorously proved under less and less restrictive assumptions by
himself, Goodman and Xin [23] and Szepessy and Xin [70]. A reÔ¨Åned analysis was per-
formed by Kreiss and Kreiss [38] when the excess mass is null, and by Fries [18,19] in the
general case, as long as the shock is small. A rather new fact in the case of systems is that
a proÔ¨Åle of large amplitude may be dynamically unstable. The fact that all scalar shock are
stable can be viewed as a consequence of the Krein‚ÄìRutman theorem, applied to the eigen-
value Œª = 0 of L, noticing that the eigenfunction U‚Ä≤ has a constant sign. Two mechanisms

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
509
may be responsible for a dynamical instability. First of all, the instability of the underlying
inviscid shock is an obstacle to the stability of any reasonable kind of proÔ¨Åle (see Zumbrun
and Serre [74]). But, even when the inviscid shock is stable, a viscosity induces a kind of
Reynolds number, as noticed by Grenier and Gu√®s [24] and Serre ([62], Chapter 15.2), and
a large Re could cause a spectral instability. A Ô¨Årst such example in a conservative setting
is given in [64], while more realistic ones were built in Serre and Zumbrun [68]. In the sta-
bility analysis of large amplitude shock wave, one thus must assume the spectral stability.
The strategy that has been developed by Howard and Zumbrun [30] and followed by many
authors including Rousset [53] is to convert the spectral into linear stability (that is esti-
mates for the semigroup exp(tL)) and then into nonlinear stability. This is an outstandingly
difÔ¨Åcult program.
At last, let us mention a recent development that uses Logarithmic Sobolev inequalities
and relative entropy, which applies in the L1 context to the viscous Burgers‚Äô equation. With
such techniques, Francesco and Markovitch prove a trend to self-similar diffusion waves.
3.1. Preliminary observations

QUESTION. Let d = 1 and a ‚ààU +L1
0 be given. Prove (or disprove) the convergence (50).
This problem is solved in this paper. Again, asking the question assumes that the Cauchy
problem is well posed and that the semigroup satisÔ¨Åes the Co-properties. For instance, in
the relaxation model (3), (4), we also assume that the initial data takes values in a charac-
teristic box where the subcharacteristic condition (24) is fulÔ¨Ålled.
On the contrary, whenever d ‚©æ2, the difference œÑhU ‚àíU is not integrable (obvious) for
nonzero vectors h. Hence, a ‚ààU + L1 is not compatible with a ‚ààœÑhU + L1. Hence it is
not possible, starting from a general integrable perturbation of U, to restrict to a zero-mass
disturbance. Either the initial disturbance had zero-mass, or it had not. In the latter case,
the answer to the question is deÔ¨Ånitively no. Let us mention however the very interesting
results by Goodman and Miller [22] and Hoff and Zumbrun [29] about the viscous shocks
under small perturbations of nonzero mass. These will be describe in Section 5.
OPEN PROBLEM 2. Let d ‚©æ2 and a ‚ààU + L1

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws

Density arguments.

3.2. The dynamical system approach
From now on, we restrict to the one-dimensional case. In a Ô¨Årst instance, we focus on initial
data that lie between two shifts of the proÔ¨Åle U. Following Osher and Ralston [51], this
case can be treated by means of tools from dynamical systems theory: œâ-limit sets and
Lasalle‚Äôs invariance principle. Theorem 3 and Corollary 1 are due to Osher and Ralston
in the viscous case, under the unnecessary assumption that the underlying inviscid shock
satisÔ¨Åed the strict Lax inequalities.
Thus let U be a shock proÔ¨Åle and let a be an initial datum such that there exist two real
numbers j,k with
œÑjU ‚©Ωa ‚©ΩœÑkU.
(58)
Since œÑkU ‚àíœÑjU is integrable, (58) ensures that a ‚ààU + L1. Without loss of general-
ity, we may assume that a ‚ààU + L1
0. Up to the choice of a moving frame, we also may
assume that U is a standing wave, that is a steady solution. In the relaxation case, such a
choice changes slightly the system itself, but what is important is that it does not affect the
Co-properties.
The comparison principle ensures that Sta still satisÔ¨Åes (58) for every positive time.
In other words, Sta ‚àíU remains pointwise between the integrable functions œÑjU ‚àíU and
œÑkU ‚àíU. Hence, there exists an integrable function F such that
Sta(x) ‚àíU(x)
 ‚©ΩF(x)
‚àÄt ‚ààR.
(59)
Besides, the semigroup commutes with the space shifts. Hence, œÑhSta = StœÑha is another
solution, with initial datum œÑha, and the contraction principle gives
‚à•œÑhSta ‚àíSta‚à•1 ‚©Ω‚à•œÑha ‚àía‚à•1 =: Œ¥a(h).

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
513
Since a ‚àíU is integrable, the upper bound Œ¥a(h) tends to zero with h. In other words, the
family of integrable functions (Sta ‚àíU)t‚©æ0 is equiintegrable. Together with (59) that con-
stitutes the hypotheses of the Fr√©chet‚ÄìKolmogorov (see Br√©zis [5]) compactness theorem:
This family is relatively compact in L1(R). In other words, the solution trajectory (Sta)t‚©æ0
is relatively compact in U + L1(R), equipped with the distance d.
The asymptotic behavior of the solution, with respect to d, is thus entirely encoded in
the œâ-limit set, deÔ¨Åned as
Œ©(a) :=

T ‚©æ0
{Sta;t > T }.
In other words, Œ©a is the set of the strong limits of subsequences (Stma)tm‚Üí+‚àû. Important
properties of the œâ-limit set are the following:
‚Ä¢ Œ©a is a nonvoid compact subset of U + L1.
‚Ä¢ Œ©a is invariant under the semigroup, forward and backward, meaning that
StŒ©a = Œ©a.
‚Ä¢ Œ©a is a connected set.
‚Ä¢ The elements b of Œ©a satisfy
œÑjU ‚©Ωb ‚©ΩœÑkU.
(60)
Proving (50) amounts to showing that
Œ©a = {U}.
To do that, we apply the Lasalle‚Äôs invariance principle (see [40]), which we recall now.
Let J :U + L1 ‚ÜíR be a continuous Liapunov function for our semigroup. Then J takes
a constant value cJ on Œ©a. Since Œ©a consists in trajectories, these must be rather special
ones, for which the Liapunov functions are just constant. In general, there is no way to com-
pute cJ , and the only information that this principle gives is the constancy. For instance, if
there is some differentiability (but this will not be the case for us), that is, if
d
dt J[Sta] = ‚àíR[Sta]
for some dissipation rate R, then every element b of Œ©a must satisfy8 R[b] = 0. The
only situation where cJ is explicit is when J is a conserved quantity, in which case we
have cJ = J[a].
In our context, we have precisely one conservation law, namely the total mass of u ‚àíU.
Since

R(a ‚àíU)dx = 0, we deduce

R
(b ‚àíU)dx = 0
‚àÄb ‚ààŒ©a.
(61)
8We warn the reader that this property is a bit weaker than the constancy of J in general. See a striking example
in [66].

Viscous case.
Recall that Œ©a is backward invariant under the evolution, and that the semi-

of its derivative (b‚àíœÑhU)‚Ä≤. Varying the value of h, that means exactly that, for every points

œÑjU and œÑkU, it takes values in (u+,u‚àí). Thus it can be written as b = U ‚ó¶œÜ for some
smooth function œÜ. Applying (64) to the pair (x,y = œÜ(x)), we obtain on the one hand

for some h, or b = œÑhU.

Shi‚ÄìJin relaxation.
Theorem 3 was proved, in this case, by Mascia and Natalini [48].
The initial datum, being a pair of functions, is denoted by (a,b). Our assumption is that
a ‚àíU and b ‚àíV are integrable, and that the total mass of a ‚àíU is zero.
Denote by W,Z the Riemann invariants of the shock front (U,V ), and by (w,z) those
of a solution (u,v) under consideration. The Liapunov function Jh is deÔ¨Åned by
Jh[u,v] := ‚à•w ‚àíœÑhW‚à•1 + ‚à•z ‚àíœÑhZ‚à•1.
Its rate of decay is
Rh[u,v] =

This integral involves only the domain where

(65)
From the strict subcharacteristic condition (47), G is strictly increasing with respect to z
and decreasing with respect to w. Therefore, (65) implies that G(w,z) ‚àíG(œÑhW,œÑhZ) be
positive. Hence Rh[u,v] ‚©æ0 (the contraction property), and the equality holds if, and only
if z ‚àíœÑhZ and w ‚àíœÑhW have strictly the same sign (both positive, both negative, or both
zero), almost everywhere.
If (c,d) belongs to Œ©a,b, we must have Rh[c,d] = 0. Therefore, for every h, w ‚àíœÑhW
and z ‚àíœÑhZ have strictly the same sign. Moving h, this implies that, given two points
x,y ‚ààR, the following equivalence holds:
w(x) = W(y)

Radiative model.
The rate of decay of Jh is
Rh[u] =

|u ‚àíœÑhU| ‚àísgn(u ‚àíœÑhU)K ‚àó(u ‚àíœÑhU)

Since (sgn v)K ‚àóv ‚©ΩK ‚àó|v| with equality if, and only if, v has a constant sign, Rh[u] is
nonnegative(the contraction property) and vanishes only when u‚àíœÑhU has a constant sign.
Hence, every b in Œ©a is such that b ‚àíœÑhU has a constant sign for every h ‚ààR. As above,
this implies that b equals one of the shifted proÔ¨Åles. At last, the fact that Œ©a ‚äÇU +L1
0 tells
us that this proÔ¨Åle is U itself. Whence the Lemma.
3.4. Data with values beyond [u+,u‚àí]; inviscid case
Corollary 1 does not cover the case of general data a ‚ààU + L1
0, taking some values out-
side the interval [u+,u‚àí]. There does not seem possible to reach the same conclusion by
the use of dynamical systems tools only. As a matter of fact, we shall give an example,
with an inviscid equation, that the L1-stability does not hold. Such a phenomenon is actu-
ally due to the lack of diffusion, and will not occur in other models. We shall then show
that the inviscid stability does hold when the shock is noncharacteristic. At last, we shall
describe a general strategy, based on the diffusion properties of the linear operator L, to
show the L1-stability in other models; we shall explain why this method does not work in
the inviscid case.
In the sequel, it will be useful to denote by A(U) the set of initial data to which Corol-
lary 1 applies. It consists in the functions a ‚ààU + L1, taking values in the interval13
[u+,u‚àí].
Lack of stability for inviscid characteristic shocks.
Let U = (u‚àí,u+;0) be a steady in-
viscid strict shock with, say, u+ < u‚àí. Assume that it is characteristic at left, that is,
f ‚Ä≤(u‚àí) = 0.
13Exercise: Write down the correct deÔ¨Ånition of A(U,V ) in the case of Shi‚ÄìJin relaxation.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
519
Fig. 1. A shock that is characteristic at left.
Fig. 2. The shock is characteristic at left. The disturbance travels to the left with unchanged mass.
The Oleinik criterion implies that
f ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(u‚àí) ‚©Ω0
and, generically, the inequality is strict. Thus, assume
f ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(u‚àí) < 0.
(67)
Then there is some nontrivial interval (u‚àí,u‚àí+Œ¥) on which f ‚Ä≤ is negative. These assump-
tions are displayed in Figure 1.
Choose an initial datum a in the following way: It coincides with U, except on some
compact interval I ‚äÇ(‚àí‚àû,0), on which U ‚â°u‚àíand a takes values in (u‚àí,u‚àí+ Œ¥).
We may see a as the superposition U + b ‚àíu‚àíof two distinct data, namely U, and a
data b : R ‚Üí[u‚àí,u‚àí+ Œ¥], which equals u‚àíoutside of J. We claim that the solution Sta
equals the superposition of StU = U and Stb, that is, Sta = U + Stb ‚àíu‚àí(see Fig-
ure 2). For, by the maximum principle, u‚àí‚©ΩStb ‚©Ωu‚àí+ Œ¥. Hence, because of f ‚Ä≤ < 0

on (u‚àí,u‚àí+ Œ¥), the support of Stb ‚àíu‚àímoves to the left, implying that Stb ‚â°U at
the right of I. Therefore U + Stb ‚àíu‚àícoincides with Stb on (‚àí‚àû,0) and with U on
some (‚àíŒµ,+‚àû), and thus is an entropy solution. Since its initial value is U + b ‚àíu‚àí= a,
uniqueness gives the claim.

Up to our knowledge, Theorem 4 is new.
3.5. Data with values beyond [u+,u‚àí]; general case
The inviscid case studied above is rather speciÔ¨Åc, since it displays counter-examples to
the L1-stability of shock waves. It turns out that a small amount of dissipation is always
enough to ensure the stability. The proof of this fact is pretty long, because it has to be
done in the case-by-case. To begin with, there is a general argument, due to Freist√ºhler
and the author [16], which reduces the question to that of the stability of constant states
under zero-mass initial disturbances.14 The latter is an interesting problem in itself, and its
treatment highly depends on the nature of the dissipation process. It will be addressed in
Section 4.
The general argument.
For deÔ¨Åniteness, we assume s = 0, u+ < u‚àí, and that U is a
steady shock for a given diffusive model. Let a ‚ààU + L1
0 be an initial datum and u be the
corresponding solution to the Cauchy problem. Our goal is to prove that the L1-distance
of u(t) to the set

,
Àáa(x) := min

.



THEOREM 5. Assume that the diffusive model (in one space dimension) is such that
Claim 1 holds true. Given a shock wave U and a bounded initial datum a ‚ààU + L1
0,
one has
lim



COMMENTS.
‚Ä¢ For the Jin‚ÄìXin relaxation, the data and the shock wave are pairs (a,b) and (U,V ).
The assumptions are that (a,b) takes its values in a characteristic domain where the
subcharacteristic condition (47) holds strictly, and that a ‚àíU ‚ààL1
0.
‚Ä¢ Claim 1 does not hold true in the inviscid case. When f ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(u0) Ã∏= 0, zero-mass initial
disturbances develop in the form of ‚ÄúN-waves‚Äù, that are pairs of bumps of opposite
signs, going to inÔ¨Ånity from both sides. Their heights are of order 1/‚àöt, while their
supports have typical length ‚àöt. They carry nonzero masses, which may be computed
explicitly from the initial datum when f is either convex or concave. The propagation
of N-waves have been extensively studied, in the scalar case, by Liu and Pierre [46]
and Dafermos [12], Chapter XI.
4. The L1-stability of constants
This section is devoted to the analysis of Claim 1. It turns out that it holds true for the
viscous, relaxation and Rosenau models. The proof for the relaxation case is cumbersome
and will not be presented here; we refer to [57] for the details.
Remark that, up to the choice of a moving frame,15 we may always assume that
f (u0) = f ‚Ä≤(u0) = 0. Also, a translation in the unknown makes u0 = 0. Thus we shall only
treat the case where
b ‚ààL1
0(R),
f (0) = f ‚Ä≤(0) = 0.

4.2. The Rosenau model
The situation here is a bit more difÔ¨Åcult, in the sense that a bounded solution of the Rosenau
model
‚àÇtz + ‚àÇxf (z) = K ‚àóz ‚àíz
is not a mild solution in general: The integral term in the Duhamel‚Äôs formula does not
make sense in L1 because the semigroup does not convert the distribution ‚àÇxf (z) into an
ordinary function.
Our strategy is therefore different. The way to make use of the assumption of zero-mass
is to introduce the potential p such that
‚àÇtp = H ‚àóz ‚àíf (z),
‚àÇxp = z,
p(¬±‚àû,t) = 0.
Since z is bounded, p is Lipschitz, and one may apply the chain rule to derivatives of
nonlinear functions of p. In particular, using the entropy inequality

At this stage, we have proved the L1-stability for those data which have some regularity
and/or decay at inÔ¨Ånity, and that are small in L1. The smoothness and decay are non-
essential assumptions, because we know that the attraction basin of the null function is
closed in the L1-topology. Hence, there remains to get rid of the smallness assumption,
a goal that can be reached exactly in the same way as in the viscous case. This completes
the proof of the Claim, that we rewrite as follows.
THEOREM 7 [67]. Assume that the kernel K belongs to L1((1 + x2)dx) and satisÔ¨Åes
K ‚©æ0,

R
K(x)dx = 1.
Then the constants are L1-stable for the Rosenau model, under zero-mass initial distur-
bances: given a constant Œ≤ and a bounded initial datum b ‚ààŒ≤ + L1
0(R), the solution of the
Cauchy problem
‚àÇtz + ‚àÇxf (z) = K ‚àóz ‚àíz,
z(x,0) = b(x),
satisÔ¨Åes
lim
t‚Üí+‚àû
z(t) ‚àíŒ≤

1 = 0.
REMARK. Contrary to the viscous case, this proof does not extend to the multidimensional
setting, because it makes use of the primitive p of z.
OPEN PROBLEM 3. Prove that constants are L1-stable under zero-mass initial distur-
bances for the Rosenau model, when d ‚©æ2.
5. Multidimensional stability
Consider a viscous17 conservation law in dimension d ‚©æ2. For the sake of simplicity,
we limit ourselves to d = 2. We call x and y the space variables:
‚àÇtu + ‚àÇxf (u) + ‚àÇyg(u) = u.
(87)
The Ô¨Çuxes are smooth functions. We give a planar shock wave œÜ in the x direction and as-
sume as above that it is steady: œÜ = œÜ(x) satisÔ¨Åes œÜxx = (f ‚ó¶œÜ)x and œÜ(¬±‚àû) = u¬±.
17Much of the analysis of this section hold for various types of diffusion.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
531
The Rankine‚ÄìHugoniot condition tells that f (u+) = f (u‚àí), and we may assume that
f (u¬±) = 0, u+ < u‚àíand f (u) < 0 in (u+,u‚àí). Integrating once, we have
œÜx = f ‚ó¶œÜ.
(88)
At last, the possibility of choosing a frame moving uniformly in the y direction allows us
to substract a linear function to g, thus permits to Ô¨Åx
g(u¬±) = 0.
Given a bounded initial datum a ‚ààœÜ + L1(R2), the problem of L1-stability does not
receive the same answer as in the case of a single space dimension. For a shifted proÔ¨Åle œÑhœÜ,
in the x direction, does not belong to the same class œÜ +L1, while a shift in the y-direction
does not modify œÜ. Hence there is no mean to absorb the mass
m :=

R2(a ‚àíœÜ)dx dy
(89)
of the initial disturbance through a translation, as it happened for d = 1.
Therefore, while we still may hope for an L1-stability result when m = 0, we must turn
towards a more complicated description when m Ã∏= 0. We shall describe here, at a formal
level, the asymptotics that was proved by Goodman and Miller [22], and improved by Hoff
and Zumbrun [29]. We emphasize that the obstruction encountered here is strictly limited
to the L1 context; the asymptotics will involve correctors that tend to zero as t ‚Üí+‚àûin
every space Lp, but L1. However, taking in account these correctors allows for a better
decay rate in every Lp.
5.1. Formal asymptotics
The fundamental idea of Goodman and Miller is that, under the additional assumption
that the shock is not characteristic (there holds f ‚Ä≤(u+) < 0 < f ‚Ä≤(u‚àí)), the disturbances
are convected towards the shock front, and then remain in this zone where the front is
stiff, where they are diffused with respect to the y variable. Hence, we expect that the
disturbance will, as in the heat equation, be governed by some function
Œ¥(y,t) = 1
‚àöt D
 y
‚àöt

,
where D is smooth and has a rapid decay. Remark that the y integral of such a function is
constant in time.
Typically, Œ¥ acts as a translation: Our solution is asymptotic to œÜ(x + Œ¥(y,t)), or to
œÜ(x) + Œ¥(y,t)œÜ‚Ä≤(x), which amounts the same in L1. The following formula shows that
such a shift is well suited for absorbing the mass m:

R2
œÜx + Œ¥(y)	 ‚àíœÜ(x)	dx dy = [u]

R
Œ¥(y)dy.

D. Serre
We shall focus in this section on the derivation of Œ¥, through an asymptotic expansion.
The expansion that we are looking for deÔ¨Ånes an approximate solution v of (87), in the
sense that
N[v] := ‚àÇtv + ‚àÇxf (v) + ‚àÇyg(v) ‚àív
is integrable in space and time on R2 √ó (0,+‚àû). That goal needs to incorporate several
terms beyond those which are meaningful in L1. To be precise, we need taking into account
all the differential monomials in Œ¥ that are integrable in space and time:
v(x,y,t) := œÜ(x) + Œ¥(y,t)œÜx(x) + Œ¥yŒ∏(x) + 1

The coefÔ¨Åcients Œ∏,... are smooth functions with rapid decay at inÔ¨Ånity, so that all terms

the integrability properties are inherited from those of the monomials in Œ¥. Noting that

not decay in L1. The two next correctors decay like t‚àí1/2, while the last three ones decay
like t‚àí1. Higher-order terms, being integrable in space and time, would be useless for
our purpose.
When computing N[v], only terms of order at least t‚àí1/2 are present. Since we wish that

Since g(u¬±) = 0 and f ‚Ä≤(u¬±) Ã∏= 0, the function g/f is bounded over [u+,u‚àí] and z grows
at most linearly at inÔ¨Ånity. Hence Œ∏ inherits from œÜx a rapid decay. Notice that Œ∏ is deÔ¨Åned
up to a multiple of œÜx. Since

R œÜx dx = [u] is nonzero, we may normalize by

R Œ∏ dx = 0,
but this is compulsory.
More generally, given a function h(x) with exponential decay at inÔ¨Ånity, the equation
PK = h amounts to K = kœÜx with kx = h/œÜx. Though k might grow exponentially at
inÔ¨Ånity, its growth rate is less than the decay rate of œÜx, and thus K has a rapid decay at
inÔ¨Ånity. This has been well known in the spectral analysis of wave fronts since the seminal
work by Sattinger [55]: though the essential spectrum of P reaches the origin when the
operator is considered within Lp-spaces, it is shifted to the left when working in weighted
spaces with exponentially growing rates. In such spaces, P is onto.
The diffusion equation for Œ¥.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
535
5.2. Stability results
The previous analysis, though giving a formal asymptotics in L1 (and this asymptotics
can be continued up to every order), does not provide a rigorous proof. There are several
reasons for that Ô¨Çaw, one being the fact that u(t) ‚àíœÜ does not remain in a compact set
of L1, contrary to the one-dimensional case.
Therefore, the method followed in [22] and [29] uses the spectral analysis of the lin-
earized operator around the proÔ¨Åle:
Lv := v ‚àí‚àÇx

f ‚Ä≤(œÜ)v
	
‚àíg‚Ä≤(œÜ)‚àÇyv.
Since its coefÔ¨Åcients depend only on the x variable, it is conjugated to a collection of
one-dimensional operators, parametrized by the Fourier variable Œæ, dual to y
LŒæv :=

‚àÇ2
x ‚àíŒæ2	
v ‚àí‚àÇx

f ‚Ä≤(œÜ)v
	
‚àíig‚Ä≤(œÜ)Œæv,
that is,
LŒæ = ‚àÇxP ‚àíŒæ2 ‚àíig‚Ä≤(œÜ)Œæ.
Notice that L0 is precisely the linearized operator encountered in the stability analysis of
the one-dimensional case. It has the simple eigenvalue Œª = 0, as we have the equation
L0œÜx = 0,
and œÜx decays rapidly at inÔ¨Ånity.
A fundamental difÔ¨Åculty in the stability of viscous shock fronts is that this eigenvalue is
embedded in the essential spectrum, when L0 is associated to a domain Lp. As mentioned
above, Sattinger [55] found that the replacement of Lp by a weighted space shifts the
essential spectrum to the left, so that Œª = 0 becomes an isolated eigenvalue. In addition,
Krein‚ÄìRutman‚Äôs theorem and the fact that œÜx has a constant sign imply that zero is the
largest eigenvalue and is simple. Therefore standard perturbation theory shows that, within
weighted spaces, LŒæ has a unique small eigenvalue Œª(Œæ) when Œæ is small, which is simple.
A classical calculus that we leave to the reader gives
Œª(Œæ) ‚àº‚àíŒ≤Œæ2,
where Œ≤ is the diffusion coefÔ¨Åcient found above, conÔ¨Årming our formal asymptotics.
The spectral properties of L are then converted into estimates for the semigroup that it
generates. The nonlinear remainder in (87) is treated with the use of a Duhamel‚Äôs principle.
In [22] the linear estimates were obtained by a direct application of Sattinger‚Äôs method, so
that the stability result was proved under the assumption that the initial disturbance has a
rapid decay at inÔ¨Ånity. Also, for some obscure reason, the result held only for shocks of
moderate amplitude. These Ô¨Çaws were removed in [29], where the linear estimates were
established by a careful analysis of the elliptic and parabolic Green‚Äôs functions. There,

536
D. Serre
a stability result is obtained for every noncharacteristic viscous shocks, and for initial dis-
turbances that are small in L1 ‚à©L‚àûand have a Ô¨Ånite moment in the x direction. Addition-
ally, the stability result holds true for nonlinear and nonisotropic diffusions

j,k
‚àÇj
ajk(u)‚àÇku	
instead of the Laplacian.

front is L1-asymptotic stable, up to the corrector Œ¥m(y,t)œÜ‚Ä≤(x) described above, regardless
of the size of the integrable initial disturbance.
REMARKS.
‚Ä¢ The stability of constants holds true in every space dimension. See [58]; the proof is
easier in dimension d ‚©æ2 than in one space dimension, because of stronger disper-
sion. Therefore, it would be sufÔ¨Åcient to consider data a which satisfy comparisons

of the front obeys to a different asymptotic. Hence the problems:

Though we have considered in (96) only three-points difference schemes, the present sec-

points. The only important properties that we require are the translational invariance (clear
in Formula (96)), and the monotonicity in a strict form. The latter means that G is monotone
increasing with respect to each of its arguments. In particular, the derivatives of F satisfy20

Godunov scheme.
The Godunov scheme, described in Section 6.4, is a generalization of
the upwind scheme when the Ô¨Çux f is nonmonotone. It is monotone but not strictly, except
in the case where f is strictly monotone. We shall provide in Section 6.4 an extension of
the classical results to this scheme.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
539
Lax‚ÄìWendroff scheme.
The Lax‚ÄìWendroff scheme is second-order accurate. As such,
it cannot be monotone, even in a nonstrict form, according to a theorem of Harten, Hyman
and Lax [28].
6.1. Shock proÔ¨Åles
Given a shock (u‚àí,u+;s) of (97), a ‚Äúdiscrete‚Äù shock proÔ¨Åle is an exact solution of (96),
having the form of a traveling wave:
un
j = u(j ‚àísŒªn).
Such a solution depends only on the variable (j ‚àíŒªsn)x = x ‚àíst, hence it has the
velocity s. We shall see that the dimensionless parameter
Œ∑ := sŒª
plays a fundamental role in the analysis. We notice for the moment that (102) and the Lax
condition imply
|Œ∑| < 1.
(103)
Plugging our ansatz in (96), we obtain a functional difference equation for the proÔ¨Åle:
u(x ‚àíŒ∑) = u(x) + F

Œª;u(x ‚àí1),u(x)
	
‚àíF

Œª;u(x),u(x + 1)
	
.
(104)
This equation shows that the proÔ¨Åle u must be deÔ¨Åned a priori on a set of the form
X + Z + Œ∑Z. When Œ∑ is irrational, such a set is always dense in R, and is it reasonable21
to ask that u be deÔ¨Åned on R and satisfy (104) for every real number x.
When Œ∑ = p/q is rational, one may restrict the domain of u to a discrete subset of R,
for instance Z + Œ∑Z = 1
q Z. However, there is a good reason why the proÔ¨Åle would
actually be considered as a function of a real variable instead of a discrete variable.
Let us assume Œ∑ = 0 as a typical example of the rational case. Then (104) reduces to
F(Œª;u(x ‚àí1),u(x)) = F(Œª;u(x),u(x + 1)), which can be viewed as a discrete dynami-
cal system
F(Œª;uj‚àí1,uj) = F(Œª;uj,uj+1),
(105)
which tells that F(Œª;uj,uj+1) is independent of j. Letting j ‚Üí¬±‚àû, we Ô¨Ånd that its
constant value equals F(Œª;u¬±,u¬±) = Œª(f (u¬±) ‚àísu¬±). Hence, we recover the Rankine‚Äì
Hugoniot condition as a necessary condition for the existence of a proÔ¨Åle. Similarly, the
monotonicity assumption tells that (96) is compatible with some discrete form of entropy
21The name ‚Äúdiscrete shock proÔ¨Åle‚Äù is hardly satisfactory, since a proÔ¨Åle could have to be deÔ¨Åned on a
dense subset!

540
D. Serre
conditions. Using them as above, we Ô¨Ånd that the Oleinik condition, in its strict form, is
a necessary condition for the existence of a proÔ¨Åle.
Because of (99), the identity F(Œª;uj,uj+1) = Œª(f (u‚àí) ‚àísu‚àí) may be written in the
explicit form
uj+1 = g(Œª,u‚àí;uj),
(106)
where g(Œª,u‚àí;¬∑) is increasing. Since it Ô¨Åxes the points u¬±, it is a diffeomorphism of the
interval (u+,u‚àí). In addition, the Oleinik condition implies that g(Œª,u‚àí;¬∑) has no other
Ô¨Åxed point in this interval. Actually, there holds g(Œª,u‚àí;u) < u on (u+,u‚àí). Therefore,
every point u‚àó‚àà(u+,u‚àí) gives rise to a unique trajectory (a discrete shock proÔ¨Åle) such
that u0 = u‚àó. This trajectory is decreasing and tends to u¬± at ¬±‚àû. Given a decreasing
parametrization
y ‚àà[0,1] ‚Üíu(y) ‚àà[u0,u1],
(107)
we may deÔ¨Åne a continuous and monotone proÔ¨Åle u:R ‚Üí(u+,u‚àí), where u(k + y) is the
kth iterate of (106) from the initial value u(y) (k ‚ààZ,y ‚àà[0,1)).
The extension of the previous analysis to other rational values of Œ∑ is nontrivial, and
we skip the proof of Jennings‚Äô theorem (see also the work by Fan [26]):
THEOREM 9 [31]. Given a conservative, strictly monotone difference scheme (96) in an
interval I, and a strict shock (u‚àí,u+;s) of (97), with u¬± ‚ààI. Assume that Œ∑ := sŒª is
rational. Then there exists a continuous and monotone discrete shock proÔ¨Åle for this shock.
6.2. The function V
The previous construction does not provide a unique up-to-a-shift continuous discrete pro-
Ô¨Åle, since the parametrization (107) is arbitrary. We now show that a canonical proÔ¨Åle
can be Ô¨Åxed, up to a shift. To understand what is going on, we go back to the case of an
arbitrary Œ∑.
Applying the contraction property to u and shifts œÑhu, we Ô¨Ånd that (101) must be an
equality, and therefore each restriction of u to a set x0 +Z+Œ∑Z is monotonous nonincreas-
ing and two such restrictions are comparable. There follows that, up to a rearrangement œÅ
such that œÅ(x + h) = œÅ(x) + h for every h ‚ààZ + Œ∑Z, u may be chosen monotonous.
Given a shock proÔ¨Åle u:R ‚ÜíI, we deÔ¨Åne as in [59]

6.3. Existence of discrete shock proÔ¨Åles; irrational case
The existence of discrete shock proÔ¨Åles has been treated by Jennings [31], who proved it in
the rational case and claimed it in the irrational case. It is widely accepted that his argument
for the passage from rational to irrational values of Œ∑ is too light for being ‚Äúa proof‚Äù.
We Ô¨Åll below this gap, giving a complete proof of existence in the irrational case, taking
for granted Theorem 9. Our result actually extends that of Fan [25], which is proved for
the Godunov scheme with a convex Ô¨Çux.
For deÔ¨Åniteness, we may assume that Œ∑ > 0. Recall that Œ∑ < 1. DeÔ¨Åne22
