THEOREM 11. Given a conservative monotone difference scheme (96) in an interval I,
and a strict shock (u‚àí,u+;s) of (97), with u¬± ‚ààI, there exists a discrete shock proÔ¨Åle
u:R ‚ÜíI. Up to a rearrangement œÅ such that œÅ(y + h) = œÅ(y) + h for every h ‚ààZ + Œ∑Z
and y ‚ààR, it may be taken monotonous and such that (108) holds. Under both these prop-
erties, the proÔ¨Åle is unique up to a shift.
Continuous dependence.
From the uniqueness of a discrete shock proÔ¨Åle, we see that the
whole sequence un converges, locally uniformly, towards u. Likewise, we have seen that
un(¬±‚àû) tend to u(¬±‚àû). Viewing R ‚à™{¬±‚àû} as a compact interval on which un and u
are monotonous and continuous, we infer from Dini‚Äôs theorem that actually un converges
uniformly towards u. Hence, the proÔ¨Åle, considered as an element of Cb(R) and normalized
by u(0) = u‚àówith u‚àó‚àà(u+,u‚àí) (say u‚àó= (u‚àí+ u+)/2), depends continuously on the
strict shock (u‚àí,u+;s).
The tail of discrete proÔ¨Åles.
It is remarkable that the present context permits that the
proÔ¨Åles tend exponentially to their limits u¬±, even for irrational parameters, provided that
the shock satisÔ¨Åes the Lax inequalities in the strict form. This fact is far from clear in the
case of systems (see [47]).

contains u¬±. Then the discrete proÔ¨Åle associated to this shock tends exponentially to its
limits u¬± at inÔ¨Ånity.
6.4. The case of upwind scheme
When f is monotonous, say increasing, it may be advantageous to consider the scheme
deÔ¨Åned by the numerical Ô¨Çux F(Œª;u,v) := Œªf (u). For nonmonotonous functions f , it was
generalized by Godunov [21] in the following way:
F(Œª;u,v) = ŒªFG(u,v) := Œª
minz‚àà[u,v] f (z),
u ‚©Ωv,
maxz‚àà[v,u] f (z),
v ‚©Ωu.
This upwind scheme is monotonous, but not strictly. In particular, the construction done
above for steady shocks does not work because F is not invertible with respect to each
of its arguments u and v. A direct analysis of discrete proÔ¨Åles for steady shocks can be
done, however, even for systems of conservation laws. Under reasonable assumptions, the
proÔ¨Åle does exist, but it has the strange property of being equal to u‚àíor to u+, away from
an interval of unit length (see [59]). This reÔ¨Çects the lack of dissipation of the Godunov
scheme, precisely at rest points (namely at solutions of f ‚Ä≤(u) = 0).
The situation must change drastically as soon as Œ∑ is different from zero. The proÔ¨Åle,
if it exists, must not be ‚Äúcompactly supported‚Äù, contrary to the steady case. The existence

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
545
and uniqueness of a discrete shock proÔ¨Åle in this case is due to Fan [25]. We give here an
alternate, somehow simpler, proof that follows the strategy already used in Section 6.3.
In a Ô¨Årst instance, we modify the Godunov scheme by adding a small but positive amount
of dissipation Œµ. This means replacing the numerical Ô¨Çux by a new one
F Œµ(Œª;u,v) := F(Œª;u,v) + Œµ(u ‚àív).
In other words, the linear term v that is present in G(Œª;u,v,w) is replaced by
Œµu + (1 ‚àí2Œµ)v + Œµw. Because of the CFL condition, the new scheme is strictly monotone
for Œµ > 0 small enough.
Theorem 11 therefore applies to the modiÔ¨Åed scheme. Given a strict shock (u‚àí,u+;s),
there exists a unique shock proÔ¨Åle uŒµ with the normalization uŒµ(0) = u‚àó(u‚àóchosen in
(u+,u‚àí)) and V Œµ(h) = h[u]. It is monotone and Lipschitz continuous, the Lipschitz con-
stant being bounded by |[u]|. Again, we may extract a subsequence, still denoted uŒµ, con-
verging uniformly on every compact set. Denote by u the limit. Pass to the limit in the
integrated form (110) of the proÔ¨Åle equations, which contains the boundary conditions at
inÔ¨Ånity. We obtain that u satisÔ¨Åes the integrated form of the proÔ¨Åle equation of the Godunov
scheme. Arguing as in Section 6.3 gives that u is monotone with u(¬±‚àû) = u¬±.
REMARK. The same strategy can be employed in order to show the existence of semidis-
crete proÔ¨Åles. Consider the upwind semidiscretization

Hence, the uniform convergence on every compact set, up to extraction of a subsequence.

6.5. Stability of discrete shock proÔ¨Åles
In the sequel, we consider solutions and proÔ¨Åles that depend on a real variable x. One could
restrict to x ‚ààZ + Œ∑Z, especially if Œ∑ is rational. In that case, the word ‚Äúintegrable‚Äù must
be replaced by ‚Äúsummable‚Äù, and ‚à•¬∑ ‚à•1 becomes the ‚Ñì1-norm.
Let U be a discrete proÔ¨Åle of some shock: un
j := U(j ‚àíŒ∑n) solves (96) exactly. Hence,
U is a stationary solution of
un+1(x) = G

un(x + Œ∑ ‚àí1),un(x + Œ∑),un(x + Œ∑ + 1)
	
.
(115)
To begin with, let the initial datum a lie between œÑŒ±U and œÑŒ≤U. The arguments of Sec-
tion 3.2 work, and we only have to consider those data b that lie between œÑŒ±U and œÑŒ≤U,
such that the distance ‚à•Snb ‚àíœÑhU‚à•1 ‚â°‚à•b ‚àíœÑhU‚à•1, S being the iteration operator deÔ¨Åned
by (115). But this is easily seen to imply that b ‚àíœÑhU has a constant sign (see the de-
tails in [31]). This, being true for every real number h, implies that b equals some shift
of U. Hence the L1-stability holds true for such a‚Äôs. The standard density argument al-
lows to extend this result to data such that a ‚àíU is integrable, and that take values in the
interval [u+,u‚àí].
Going beyond requires proving the L1-stability of constant states under zero-mass initial
disturbances. Of course, this depends on the numerical scheme under consideration. For
instance, a scheme such that the one of Lax‚ÄìFriedrichs is likely to Ô¨Åt this property, because
of his rather strong dissipation. However, it is not so clear for the Godunov scheme, whom
dissipativeness vanishes at points ¬Øu such that f ‚Ä≤(¬Øu) = 0.
OPEN PROBLEM 8. Prove the L1-stability of constants under conservative monotone dif-
ference schemes.
7. Initial-boundary value problems
The previous sections dealt with the pure Cauchy problem, the space domain having
been Rd, with often d = 1. An other interesting situation is that of the initial boundary
value problem (IBVP). Let us consider for instance the viscous model
‚àÇtu + divf (u) = u
in a domain Œ©. We supplement it with a bounded initial datum a and a (nonnecessarily
homogeneous) Dirichlet boundary condition u(x,t) = ub on ‚àÇŒ©. Here, b may depend
on x ‚àà‚àÇŒ©, but not on the time variable since we are searching asymptotic stability results.
The proof that the IBVP generates a unique semigroup St that satisÔ¨Åes the comparison
principle and the L1-contraction property is straightforward. However, and it is important
in the analysis, St does no longer preserve the mass: When integrating the conservation
law on Œ©, we Ô¨Ånd that the mass varies with time, proportionally to the Ô¨Çux of ‚àáxu ‚àíf (u)
across the boundary. There is no reason why the latter would vanish.

L1-stability of nonlinear waves in scalar conservation laws
547
The asymptotic analysis is pretty easy when Œ© is bounded, because of the Poincar√©
inequality. The solution tends exponentially to the unique steady solution. Hence, we
shall concentrate on unbounded domains, and more speciÔ¨Åcally to the case of a half-space
H := (0,+‚àû) √ó Rd‚àí1 as a paradigm.
When Œ© = H , we distinguish the variable x normal to the boundary, and the tangen-
tial variables y ‚ààRd‚àí1. We Ô¨Åx a constant boundary value ub, and a value at inÔ¨Ånity, say
u‚àû= 0. Hence, we are interesting in bounded data that are integrable. Our problem is
to compare a solution Sta =: u(t) to a steady solution called ‚Äúboundary layer‚Äù, using the
L1-distance d.
The layer, denoted by U, is invariant under translations parallel to the boundary:
U = U(x). It thus satisÔ¨Åes the differential equation
U‚Ä≤(x) = f (U) ‚àíf (0),
(116)
together with the initial condition U(0) = ub. There does not always exist such a boundary
layer. On the one hand, if f ‚Ä≤
1(0) > 0, the origin is a repulsor for (116) and the only possible
boundary layer is obtained for ub = 0, when it is constant. On the other hand, if f ‚Ä≤(0) < 0,
then a boundary layer exists (and is unique) provided there is no zero of f ‚àíf (0) be-
tween ub and the origin. This dichotomy shows the important role played by the hyperbolic
wave velocity associated to the state at inÔ¨Ånity.
The borderline case f ‚Ä≤(0) = 0 corresponds to a characteristic boundary for the underly-
ing inviscid model. In general, it is expected to create complications. For instance, if we
were interested in decay rates,23 it would certainly weaken drastically the optimal results,
comparing to the noncharacteristic case. It turns out that, in the one-dimensional analy-
sis done by Freist√ºhler and the author [17], the proofs of L1-stability of constants (say of
the solution ¬Øu ‚â°0 with the homogeneous Dirichlet boundary condition) were signiÔ¨Åcantly
different, according to the case under consideration: characteristic (f ‚Ä≤(0) = 0) or outgoing
(f ‚Ä≤(0) < 0), while the result itself (instability) is different in the incoming case (f ‚Ä≤(0) > 0).
Surprisingly enough, the characteristic case was the easiest one, because it could be con-
verted in a pure Cauchy problem (see below). We give hereafter a new proof of stability of
the outgoing case, by a comparison with the characteristic one. It does not only simplify
the analysis, but it extends the stability result to several space dimensions.
7.1. Stability of constants
The one-dimensional case has been treated by Freist√ºhler and the author in [17]. There is
a complete description, as far as the L1-asymptotic stability is concerned. It turns out that,
as in the shock-stability problem, the L1-stability of constants plays a fundamental role.
Since constant are not solutions in general, this question makes sense only when ub = 0.
We notice also that the total mass is no longer a conserved quantity and therefore one must
not assume that the initial disturbance have a zero mass.
The dichotomy mentioned above reÔ¨Çects in the following statement.
23But we deliberately ignored this aspect in this article, focusing only on the stability itself.

548
D. Serre
THEOREM 13. Consider the viscous IBVP, with a homogeneous Dirichlet boundary con-
dition (ub = 0).
(i) Assume f ‚Ä≤
1(0) ‚©Ω0. Then the L1-stability of u0 ‚â°0 holds true: If a ‚ààL1(H), then
lim
t‚Üí+‚àû
u(t)

1 = 0.
(ii) Assume on the contrary that f ‚Ä≤
1(0) > 0. Then there exist bounded initial data
a ‚ààL1(H) such that
lim
t‚Üí+‚àû
u(t)

1 > 0.
PROOF. We shall treat the Ô¨Årst part (stability) of the theorem, and refer to [17] for the
second one (instability), since the corresponding proof has a straightforward extension to
the multidimensional setting.
Given a bounded integrable data a, the comparison principle tells that Sta‚àí‚©Ω

Therefore it is enough to consider data of constant signs. For instance, we focus on non-
negative data. Corresponding solutions will be nonnegative.

‚ñ°
7.2. Stability of boundary layers
Using Theorem 13, plus arguments of dynamical systems theory, one obtains the same kind
of one-dimensional stability result than for viscous shocks:
THEOREM 14 (d = 1 [17]). Let U(x) be a nontrivial (that is, ub Ã∏= u(+‚àû)) bound-
ary layer for the viscous model. Then it is L1-stable: Given any bounded initial data
a ‚ààU + L1, one has
lim
t‚Üí+‚àû
u(t) ‚àíU

1 = 0.
REMARKS.
1. Since U is nontrivial, f ‚Ä≤(0) must be nonpositive. Hence, the Ô¨Årst part of Theorem 13
can be used.
2. Theorem 14 could not be true for constant U in general, because of the second part
of Theorem 13.
3. When f ‚Ä≤(0) < 0, U is itself integrable (say that u(+‚àû) = 0) because it decays ex-
ponentially. Hence the assumption on the data is really that a is integrable. However,
in the characteristic case, the boundary layer is not integrable, because it decays at
best as 1/x. Hence, the data are not integrable in this case. It would be interesting of
course to prove Lp-stability results in this case, with p such that U ‚ààLp(0,+‚àû).
For instance, p > 1 is relevant when f ‚Ä≤(0) = 0 Ã∏= f ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(0).

550
D. Serre
In several space dimensions, the situation is curious. Remember that, when studying the
L1-stability of viscous shock waves, we encountered a difÔ¨Åculty caused by the conserva-
tion of mass: The convergence ‚à•u(t) ‚àíU(¬∑ ‚àíst)‚à•1 ‚Üí0 could not hold unless the initial
disturbance had zero mass. This is no longer true for boundary layers since mass conserva-
tion does not hold. Hence, we may expect a general stability result, regardless the mass of
initial disturbance. However, we still miss a compactness argument, due to the translational
invariance along directions that are parallel to the boundary. Thus we left the following
OPEN PROBLEM 9. Prove the stability of multidimensional viscous boundary layers, un-
der bounded integrable initial disturbances.
Acknowledgments
I am happy to express my gratitude to Constantine Dafermos. I should not have found
the courage to write this review without his constant interest. Also, he made me aware of
techniques in dynamical systems theory, which have proved their efÔ¨Åciency in this domain.
Thanks to his friendly pressure, this topic is now presented in a uniÔ¨Åed way, after having
been disseminated in several smaller papers. This writing gave me the occasion to solve a
few open question and to Ô¨Åx a few points of which the difÔ¨Åculty was underestimated in the
literature. Special thanks go to H. Freist√ºhler, whose collaboration was precious at some
stage of this research. Last but not least, this article was polished during my stay in Isaac
Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences, in a warm atmosphere24 and perfect technical
as well as scientiÔ¨Åc environment.
This research was done from one part in accomplishment of the European IHP project
‚ÄúHYKE‚Äù, contract HPRN-CT-2002-00282.
